## sacrifice paddock
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Aug 14, 1958</b> The farming technique known as the `sacrifice' paddock, in which one paddock on a farm is heavily stocked during the winter to save pastures elsewhere on the farm for use by cattle after calving was criticised by the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals in the Palmerston North Magistrates' Court today. ... in Dalefield's case it had been the stock rather than the paddock which had been `sacrificed' (Christchurch Star-Sun,13)

>  <b>1982</b> <i>sacrifice paddock n. N.Z.</i> a grassed field which is allowed to be grazed completely, so that it can be cultivated and resown later. (Collins Concise English Dictionary,1015) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 428]]

>  <b>Sep 9, 2004</b> His practice of putting his herd in a "sacrifice" paddock is common among dairy farmers. Rather than damage all his farm moving his herd around in the mud, he opts to sacrifice poorly performing paddocks and later cultivate and resow them with a crop followed by new grass when the weather improves. (Dominion Post,C7)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a fenced area on which a farmer will bring in silage, hay or other feed to stock in very wet weather , causing the sward to be pugged and trampled.

>  <b>Jun 10, 1958</b> We fed 118 cows for a full month on this crop, supplemented by a 'sacrifice' paddock adjoining.. In wet weather we left the cows in the sacrifice paddock and fed hay out to them. (NZ Dairy Exporter,29)

>  <b>1960</b> <i>MCMEEKAN</i> The 'sacrifice paddock' system of wintering would be employed for the feeding-out of hay and silage during winter. (Grass to Milk,187)

>  <b>Sep 10, 1970</b> I used to think sacrifice paddocks were bound to be very fertile the next year and the heavier the stocking, the richer they'd be. (NZ Farmer,61)

>  <b>Sep 1973</b> Fortunately, the herd had to walk some distance from a 'sacrifice' paddock to the barn through a shingle bottomed stream, which is a first-class indicator of founder, or overheating of the feet. (NZ Journal of Agriculture,61)

>  <b>Sep 27, 1973</b> Sacrifice paddocks with feeding racks on platforms on the race-side border may be worth considering. (NZ Farmer,7)

>  <b>Jul 1983</b> I intend to throw away the backing wire, revert to the old 1950s practice of a 'sacrifice paddock' on the bad grub areas and really trample hell out of them. (NZ Journal of Agriculture,69)

>  <b>Aug 1, 1996</b> MAF is encouraging farmers to watch their image after complaints from townies and tourists over cattle being held in muddy sacrifice paddocks. (NZ Farmer,4)

## safen
 
 <i>v.</i> to make safe

>  <b>Apr 28, 2004</b> David Gregorie of Waikanae quotes a letter in his local paper from Niki Trotter, of Raumati Beach: "I find it hard to see why anyone would be against safening a very dangerous piece of road with an extremely bad accident history." Now that's a truly marvellous word. "Safen". to "make safe", follows all the best precedents, using that Germanic -en ending to make a verb out of an adjective. It mimics fasten, worsen, harden, sweeten, sharpen, shorten, stiffen etc. (Dominion Post,B5)

## sale
 
 <i>v.</i> to vomit (cf. sell out) [ca1945 I saled on my twentieth beer.]

>  <b>1988</b> <i>McGILL</i> <i> sale</i> to vomit; often <i>make a sale</i> . (Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,96)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> spew(usually from a surfeit of liquor) and in various constructions, from ca1940 at least (Les Cleveland) and in various expressions [ca1945 I slipped in a mess of sale outside the pub.]



## sale crutch
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a removal of dirty wool from rear ends of lambs or sheep prior to sale.

>  <b>Jun 1982</b> The job may be small, such as ring crutching, but those heavy sheep have to be handled. Ideal for full crutch, ringing and wigging, dagging or sale crutch of prime lambs. (NZ Journal of Agriculture,49)



## sale day
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a regular day of the week on which a stock sale is held at a particular venue. [also saleday]

>  <b>1987</b> <i>Batistich</i> The casuals came and went as usual, the Sale Day visitants flooded us briefly. (Sing Vila in the Mountain,156)

>  <b>1923</b> <i>SILK</i> For the last few years, the farmers in general found that sale-days were by no means 'Red Letter Days', but days of gloom and disappointment. (History of Puhoi,85)

>  <b>1970</b> <i>MCNAUGHTON</i> Next morning was sale day, and Stewart went to the saleyards with his hack and his dogs. (Tat,104)

>  <b>1974</b> <i>MACINTOSH</i> The busiest day was on 'saleday' when farmers and agents gathered for the fortnightly stock sale. (Never a Dull Moment,18)

>  <b>1974</b> <i>MACINTOSH</i> Saledays often brought added diversions ... (Never a Dull Moment,35)

>  <b>1976</b> <i>WATERS</i> Stock sale days from the mid-1920s were quite a cockies' gathering. (Mostly a Farmer,105)

>  <b>1991</b> <i>RICHARDS</i> If the weather was suitable, sale days turned into a 'picnic day' or a get-together for all the families. [saleday] (Off the Sheep's Back,54)



 
 <i>n.</i> in country towns, the day on which a farm livestock sale is held [also saleday]

>  <b>Dec 10, 1929</b> ROBT. SCOTT, DENTIST, TAY STREET, INVERCARGILL. VISITS Otautau every fortnight, and may be consulted at Mrs Jaquiery's Buildings on Sale Day and second and fourth Fridays. (Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,4)

>  <b>Mar 29, 1932</b> Why, Sale day was Otautau's Gala day! (Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,4)

>  <b>Apr 4, 1896</b> Stratfordites are beginning to recognise the necessity of having a more substantial bridge over the Patea river, and teamsters are a bit frightened about crossing over with a load of medium weight. And no wonder. It is surprising to many it has not collapsed before this. At all events to a town like Stratford it is an unsightly structure, whether fit to carry the traffic or not, and it is a menace to pedestrians when there is much traffic in the streets, especially on sale days, when cattle are being driven across. (Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

>  <b>Jan 13, 1875</b> The supply of medium horses has been good, but vendors looked for an advance; whereas prices ruled, upon the whole, lower. Consequently, a smaller number than is usual on a regular sale-day, was disposed of. (Taranaki Herald,2)

>  <b>Oct 9, 1868</b> The required quorum of 10 ratepayers not being present at the annual meeting called for Tuesday, the chairman (Mr. E. Constable) adjourned the meeting to Wednesday, the 14th instant, the cattle sale day. (Daily Southern Cross,3)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>TURNER</i> (English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,150)

>  <b>Mar 12, 1918</b> An owner is wanted for a Hereford calf, left in the yards last sale day. (Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,3)

>  <b>1988</b> September 2: first cattle sale day. (From Bush-Burn to Butter,52) [NOTES: 1881 John Hurndall's Diary in 1988 Warr From Bush-burn to Butter 52]

>  <b>Dec 1904</b> Sale day, Christmas week, and not a beast to be got for love or money. (NZ Illustrated Magazine,251)

>  <b>1949</b> <i>SCANLAN</i> The little market town, with its handful of shops, its public house, its saleyards, was only two miles away. Thursday was Sale Day, when the farmers came in to buy and sell sheep or calves, heifers and pigs, and the farmer's wife to trade her butter and eggs at the grocer's for stores, and to buy towels and sheets and shoes. Market day, they would call it in England, but there was no market in these small New Zealand towns. There were no stalls in the street or square, where the farmer and his wife sold poultry and apples, eggs and butter, fruit and cream. The cows and sheep and horses and other farm stock were gathered into pens at the saleyard, and sold by auction. (Rusty Road,10)

>  <b>1978</b> Tell him I'll be wanting another pup and I'll look him up next saleday. (Listener Short Stories,2/40) [NOTES: 1956 Middleton in 1978 Listener Short Stories Vol 2 40]

>  <b>1966</b> <i>TURNER</i> [In winter] a farmer does not have to be mindful of <i>cow-time</i> or milking time on <i>town day</i>(or <i>sale day</i>, equivalent to English `market day'). (English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,161)

>  <b>1970</b> <i>McNAUGHTON</i> Next morning was sale day, and Stewart went to the saleyards with his hack and his dogs. (Tat,104)

>  <b>1982</b> <i>KEENE</i> Sale Day was always exciting in Kaitaia - especially in those early times when wild frightened cattle from the most northerly stations - cattle that had seen few human beings - were driven down the main road to the saleyards, then into the A. & P. grounds. (Myrtle and Sophia,45)

>  <b>Dec 1, 1945</b> Sale Day causes a hive of activity in our village. (NZ Dairy Exporter,63)

>  <b>1987</b> Sale Day was the big day for business in town. The farmers drove in with their families and the four roads that met at Aorangi House resounded to the ring of sulky wheels along the macadam. (Sing Vila in the Mountain,43)

>  <b>1967</b> <i>HENDERSON</i> I came to appreciate the farmers' saleday when I was running a small country town bakery and tearooms. (Return of Joe,172)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>KENNEALLY</i> Fences, gardens and residents suffered just prior to saleday. (Johnsonville Yesterday,35)



## sale draft
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a group of livestock for sale that are separated from a larger group.

>  <b>1972</b> <i>NEWTON</i> Unless they are aged sheep they aren't likely to be in his sale draft ... (Sheep Thief,127)



## sale muster
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the gathering of stock in preparation for drafting or a clearing sale.

>  <b>1962</b> <i>SHARPE</i> One the rare occasions on which a back-country property changes hands the sale muster, in which the sheep are brought in for counting, leads itself to all sorts of devilment. (Country Occasions,129)



## sale night
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an evening following a stock sale day [usually a social occasion in a rural area.]

>  <b>Jul 25, 1914</b> <i>WESTMACOTT</i> I woke up the boarding house keeper, to find that, being sale night, there was not a bed in the house. (Letter,190) [NOTES: in Westmacott (1977) The After-Breakfast Cigar]



## sale stock
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) farm livestock to be sold on the hoof.

>  <b>1993</b> <i>ASPINALL</i> There .. sale stock to get away. (Farming Under Aspiring,76)

>  <b>1994</b> <i>SALISBURY</i> Most of the sale stock off Te Rata were sold on the place. The sale stock was duly collected by a drover who would take the mob to Gisborne. [sale lambs] (I Was So Lucky,107)



## salesman
 
 <i>n.</i> to be a (good etc.) salesman: to be given to vomiting (after booze) (See [sale](../S#sale))



## saleyard
 
 <i>n.</i> a pen or set of pens where farm livestock is sold [1946 Peng. N.W. 27/48] (See [also saleyards](../A#also-saleyards))

>  <b>1969</b> <i>HENDERSON</i> The mob had baulked at the saleyard gateway ... (Open Country Calling,42)

>  <b>1870</b> The means for draining the swamp near the Remuera saleyards ... have been provided .. (TrNZI,2/219)

>  <b>1899</b> (Department of Agriculture Report,17) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)hyphenated]

>  <b>1934</b> <i>LILICO</i> A bitch pup I sold ... went direct to freezing works to pen up and developed into a first class forcer and backer ... The finest backing dogs I have ever seen are in the saleyards at Addington ... (Sheep Dog Memoirs,26)

>  <b>1950</b> (NZ Journal of Agriculture,26/3)

>  <b>1948</b> <i>BALLANTYNE</i> (Cunninghams, The,85)

>  <b>Feb 21, 1951</b> <i>DUFF</i> I bought her [an old ewe] in the sale-yards with [23] other odds and ends, and she was in charge in twenty-four hours. Fortunately she is not a fencer. (Shepherd's Calendar,22)

>  <b>Jan 1952</b> Now, at the saleyards, they would ask him if he was going out that evening, ... (Here & Now,27)

>  <b>1986</b> <i>RICHARDS</i> Before leaving home for the sale Dad would have arranged for a holding paddock reasonably close to the saleyards where the mustered sheep could have a feed and a rest for the night. (Off the Sheep's Back,53)

>  <b>1988</b> <i>HILL</i> Home players on the Moaville Tennis Courts have also learned the wisdom of offering to take the saleyards end. From here, they canserve against a background of dust ... raised by stock trucks taking off ... (More from Moaville,23)

>  <b>1979</b> (Heinemann Dictionary of NZ Quotations,2 ed.)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>CRUMP</i> (Hang on a Minute, Mate,64)

>  <b>1955</b> <i>DUFF</i> (New Zealand Now,1941)

>  <b>1961</b> <i>REID</i> (Kiwi Laughs, The)

>  <b>1939</b> <i>BEATTIE</i> A saleyard had been newly made of green maple [in Central Otago c 1860s], and as the logs had been recently hauled out of the bush they were still thick with clay and mud ... (First White Boy Born in Otago,151)

>  <b>1949</b> <i>SCANLON</i> The little market town, with its handful of shops, its public house, its saleyards, was only two miles away. Thursday was Sale Day, when the farmers came in to buy and sell sheep or calves, heifers and pigs, and the farmer's wife to trade her butter and eggs at the grocer's for stores, and to buy towels and sheets and shoes. (Rusty Road,10)

## saleyard rig
 
 <i>n.</i> a countryman's best clothes: ?typical saleyard clothes - tweed coats and trousers and hats, or wide- brimmed hats

## saleyards
 
 <i>n.</i>

## sally up
 
 <i>v.</i> berate, reprimand [also sally-up; ca1900 He sallied him about the way he treated his wife; also as a n or vbl n He gave her a sallying/sally-up.]

>  <b>Nov 20, 1930</b> Dunedin, on its home green, "sallied up" Green Island in the Four Rink game, due chiefly to the great showing by Geo. Nelson's rink. (NZ Truth,16)



 
 <i>n.</i> brisk reprimand [also sally-up]

>  <b>1974</b> <i>SYDER & HODGETTS</i> Brisk urging to hurry.;`I'll go back and give those stragglers a sally-up and try to hurry them along.' (Australian & NZ English [TS],944,1962-63 ed.)

>  <b>Jul 26, 1919</b> The Smith Family Have a Sally up. THE UNKIND AND BITTER TONGUES OF FIERCE FEMALES. (NZ Truth,3)

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) matagouri [mainly Central Otago]

## salmon
 
 <i>n.</i> New Zealand salmon, see KAHAWAI. (obsolesc) usu. with descriptive epithet MAORI, NATIVE, NEW ZEALAND salar, =KAHAWAI [cf AND <i>Arripis trutta </i> 1790 Collins (1798); salmon trout young of A <i> trutta or <i> A esper 1848 Tasmania]

>  <b>1841</b> <i>BIDWILL</i> Other shell-fish are also abundant, particularly Cockles - of these I have seen more than a man could carry collected by one woman during the space of a tide; Scallops are also tolerably abundant, and are most delicious eating. There are no Lobsters nor Crabs, but a great abundance of fish of all kinds; one, the Salmon of the English, or Carwai (Carwhy), is a most excellent fish, the best I have tasted in the Southern Hemisphere; ... (Rambles in NZ,115,1952 ed.)

>  <b>1840</b> <i>POLACK</i> Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called <i>para[as-acute]<i> paraua</i> [a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, <i> mungu nui</i> (black physeter); right whale, <i>tohora</i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, <i> mango</i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes. (Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202 fn)

>  <b>1898</b> <i>MORRIS</i> <i> Salmon, n</i> . The English Salmon is being acclimatised with difficulty in Tasmania and New Zealand; the <i>Trout</i> more successfully. But in all Australian, New Zealand, and Tasmanian waters there is a marine fish which is called Salmon; it is not the true Salmon of the Old World, but <i>Arripis salar</i> , Gunth., and called in New Zealand by the Maori name <i>Kahawai</i> . The fish is often called also <i> Salmon-Trout.</i> The young is called <i> Samson-fish</i> (q.v.). (Austral English,400)

>  <b>Apr 20, 1840</b> <i>SARAH MATHEW</i> ... very fine fish they are [off Whangarei] - schnappers, gurnet and what is called salmon in these seas. (Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Apr 20 Sarah Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 121]

>  <b>1877</b> [Native or Common Name] Kahawai, Salmon .. [Scientific Name]<i> Arripis salar </i> (TrNZI,9/485) [NOTES: (P. Thomson, Otago)]

>  <b>1798</b> <i>COLLINS</i> (Account of English Colony in NSW,136) [NOTES: [check this ??NZ: unlikely]]

>  <b>1966</b> <i>DOOGUE & MORELAND</i> KAHAWAI ... <i> Other names: Arripis trutta</i> ; sea salmon, salmon, Australian salmon (Australia). Kopapa is used for half-grown, coarsely-spotted examples in Taranaki and on parts of the Auckland west coast. (Sea Anglers' Guide,236)

>  <b>1967</b> <i>MORELAND</i> KAHAWAI [<i> Arripis trutta</i> ] ... In Australia it is known as salmon, sea salmon, and Australian salmon. Small examples are known as kopapa in northern New Zealand. (Marine Fishes,50)

>  <b>1967</b> <i>MORELAND</i> <i> salmon 1 n.</i> (pl. usu. same) large fish with orange-pink flesh highly valued for food and sport; the colour of its flesh; similar unrelated NZ and Australian fish. (Marine Fishes,50)

(Cook's Journals,3/808) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/808 (Queen Charlotte Sound)]

## salube
 
 <i>adj.</i>

>  <b>Sep 1958</b> To offset these rather gloomy expressions there are those that derive from <i> salubrious.</i> They are J.D. Pascoe terms and were brought by him from Canterbury to Wellington. They obviously arose from the habit of describing sunny, pleasant weather or places as `salubrious'. First is the <i> salubrium</i> , a rest or sunbake in salubrious conditions. This first appeared in <i> The Tramper</i> in 1937. About 1939 people were <i> salubriating</i> , or taking a <i> salube</i> in the sun. The previous year Te Matawai was described as a `salube hut'. By 1943 trampers were sunbathing and <i> salubing</i> . So far as Tararuas are concerned,<i> salube</i> as a noun and a verb is the word that has survived. (Tararua,28) [NOTES: 1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' in Tararua 28]



 
 <i>n.</i> a period of relaxation (in the sun) [(Ruth Mason: from <i> salubrious</i>)]

## Save Manapouri
 
 <i>n.</i> (Environment) a term used from 1959 for a nationwide protest against the raising of Lake Manapouri to high levels for hydroelectricity generation. [also Save Manapouri campaign]

>  <b>Mar 2, 1970</b> MANAPOURI stickers seem to come in a number of different forms. There is the common "Save Manapouri," a simple plea from the heart. "Help Save Manapouri," a call not to be just sympathetic but do something about it. Then there is "I Want to Save Manapouri," a pitiful cry by someone who feels impotent to do anything. But my favourite is the cynic's sticker indicating that he is tired of the whole business: "Drain Manapouri." (Evening Post,32)

>  <b>Aug 1970</b> The 1970 Save Manapouri petition was the third to be drawn up with the object of preserving the lake and was the largest petititon ever to be presented to Parliament. (Forest & Bird,8)

>  <b>May 1970</b> Within the past 12 months we have received powerful support from "Save Manapouri" committees, which have been organised throughout the country. (Forest & Bird,10)

>  <b>1994</b> <i>Neville PEAT</i> Save Manapouri is a cry deeply embedded in the collective consciousness of New Zealanders and is still capable of being dusted off. (Manapouri Saved,10)

>  <b>Oct 21, 1959</b> PLEA MADE FOR PRESERVATION. 'Swift Action Needed to Save Manapouri' [hdg]. (Evening Post,22)

>  <b>Jan 20, 1970</b> Exploratory Talks Here on How to Save Manapouri [hdg] Substantial interest had been shown in the activities of the Save Manapouri Committee ... (Evening Post,15)

>  <b>1982</b> <i>Roger WILSON</i> The turning point of the opposition to the raising of the lake came when a crowded and lively public meeting was held in Invercargill on 30 October [1969]. As a result of that meeting, the first "Save Manapouri" committee was set up. Similar groups were quickly established in other centres around the country. (From Manapouri to Aramoana,15)

>  <b>Apr 1970</b> The movement to "Save Manapouri" is a case book example of how trends are adopted in a democratic society. (Comment,4)



## Save Manapouri campaign
 
 <i>n.</i> (Environment) an extensive nationwide campaign to prevent high level raising of Lake Manapouri for hydroelectricity generation.

>  <b>May 7, 2008</b> The Save Manapouri campaign has been lauded as "the birth of the modern conservation movement" in New Zealand. The Save Manapouri campaign began in the late 1950s with the proposal to build a power station to supply power to an aluminium smelter in the far south of New Zealand and gained momentum in the 1960s when it was proposed that the level of Lake Manapouri would be raised 8.2 metres to harness its hydro-electric potential for the project. (Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.forestandbird.org.nz/what-we-do/publications/forest-bird-magazine/article]

>  <b>Feb 26, 2009</b> Among other things he was - with his wife - a driver of the Save Manapouri campaign, which succeeded in preventing the Crown from raising the level of the lake by some eight metres to generate electricity for the Bluff smelter. (Dominion Post,B3) [NOTES: from obituary of Dr Ian Prior - refer dawn raid and overstayer]

>  <b>1994</b> <i>Neville PEAT</i> The Save Manapouri Campaign lifted the lid. New Zealand had seen nothing of its kind before. It was a phenomenon in public awareness, concern and agitation. (Manapouri Saved,3)

>  <b>Aug 21, 1972</b> In an effort to discern basic attitudes to the issue of the southern lakes' exploitation for power, members of Parliament are to be sent questionnaires by the Save Manapouri Campaign. (Evening Post,3)

>  <b>Feb 21, 1970</b> And he [Mr R J McLean] said he thought that out of the Save Manapouri Campaign would evolve a permanent organisation to fight for the people of New Zealand when their natural environment was threatened by foreign or local industrialists, local bodies, or by their own Government. (Evening Post,7)

>  <b>1982</b> <i>Roger WILSON</i> The Save Manapouri Campaign was well funded and had a professional approach to publicity. (From Manapouri to Aramoana,11)

## schnapper
 
 <i>n.</i> variant of snapper q.v.

>  <b>1981</b> <i>WILSON</i> SNAPPER ... The common name `snapper' was given to the fish by Captain Cook in 1770. Although he did mistake the fish Captain Cook spelt the name correctly, whereas many subsequent writers have used `schnapper' - an erroneous spelling of unknown origin. Perhaps some of the early snapper fishermen took bottles of schnapps along on their outings, hence going `schnapping'! (Fisherman's Bible,226)

>  <b>1957</b> <i>PARROTT</i> The name `Snapper' is frequently spelled `Schnapper', but there appears no sound reason for this spelling; older authors especially, have used the spelling, but it is seldom seen in modern works on fishes. <i>Ibid.</i> 170 Snapper Chrysophrys auratus Schnapper (Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,99)

>  <b>1958</b> schnapper A large common edible sea fish of Australia and New Zealand. (Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),355)

>  <b>Apr 26, 1890</b> Wilkins went down town to.. beg the necessary meat for bait with which we were to catch the unsuspecting schnapper. (NZ Observer,12)

>  <b>Jun 29, 2002</b> ...I thought I should economise and not buy schnapper, which is ridiculously expensive and which I still can't spell. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

>  <b>Mar 5, 1904</b> His sorrow at the struggles of the dying schnapper was pitiful to behold. (NZ Observer,7)

>  <b>Oct 6, 2001</b> Instead, I got some freshly cooked pipi and raw schnapper. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),93)

>  <b>Mar 5, 1956</b> Bellamy's menu has qualified as the most snobbish of all State papers. Whenever the well-known New Zealand fish called snapper is an item of Parliamentary diet it is invariable [sic] spelled `schnapper.' The gourmets of the Food and Wine Society could be forgiven for such literary heresy, but the old prosaic spelling should be good enough for the dining-room in Parliament House. Incidentally, the legend is that the fish was given the name `snapper' by Captain Cook when he was here on his voyage of exploration in 1770. As he and the members of his crew leaned over the side of their galleon two centuries ago and threw their fishing lines into the waters off the New Zealand coast the fish used to snap at the bait. Hence the name snapper. (Dominion,8)

>  <b>Mar 12, 1956</b> My reference in last week's column to the snobbishness of Bellamy's in using the spelling `schnapper' when that fish was on its menu has brought `bites' galore - from fish merchants to schoolmasters. Most of them, it is fair to say, have taken up the cudgels on behalf of Bellamy's, but none of them has disproved my argument that the correct spelling is `snapper.' ... Some historians support my Captain Cook theory, though there are others who place the first use of the name `snapper' at a later date, certainly not earlier. They think the name may have been given the fish by Captain W. L. Edwardson, the commander of a New South Wales Government cutter called the Snapper which was in New Zealand waters in 1822 and 1823 investigating sealing prospects. He gave the name Port Snapper to an inlet on Ruapuke Island in Foveaux Strait. Whatever the origin of the word, the fish served at Bellamy's is indigenous to New Zealand and is spelt `snapper.' (Dominion,8)

>  <b>1885</b> The fishing off the island is very good, there being abundance of hapuku, kohikohi, maumau, schnapper, kahawai, tarakihi, in addition to plenty of shell-fish such as koura or cray-fish, crabs, paua,etc. (TrNZI,17/419) [NOTES: (Goldsmith)]

## scotia
 
 <i>n.</i> a (usually concave) moulding between a wall and a ceiling. [Jim Cameron writes: NSOD, Collins and Chambers define <i>scotia</i> as a concave/hollow moulding, esp. at the base of an (ionic) column. The OED definition is "a hollow moulding = casement". The latest citation (1878) reads "another kind of base is frequent in which a bead is subsituted for the scotia". <i>Casement</i> in turn is defined in the relevant sense as "a hollow moulding, a cavetto, not exceding one quarter round". <i>Cavettos</i>, it appears, are "principally used in cornices". All this is a bit obscure, but the definitions in NSOD etc would suggest a fairly uncommon word. The ordinary NZ use is specialised though common, and familar to most homeowners - a (usually concave) moulding between a wall and a ceiling. In NZ, it is standard and as well-known as <i>skirting board</i>.]

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> washing wool to remove the natural impurities of wax, suint, and dirt

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> place where scouring is carried on

## scow
 
 <i>n.</i> (formerly) in New Zealand, usually a sailing scow, any of various flat-bottomed centreboard craft engaged in coastal trade. ; in NZ always a `sailing scow' ;

>  <b>Aug 2004</b> It came as no surprise to anyone in Blenheim that Tom Eckford's old auxiliary scow <i>Echo</i> was soon to make her last Cook Stait crossing, but locals' prescience could not alleviate to any degree the sadness of that final sailing on 21 August 1965, the day after trading officially ceased. (NZ Memories,No. 49/44)

(Phantom Fleet,133 (CHECK))

In 1917 a daring German prisoner of war, Count Von Luckner, escaped from captivity on Motuihe Islkand, and hijacked the laden scow <i>Moa</i>... The <i>Moa</i> was the largest two-mast scow ever built at 94.5 feet. (NZ Memories,No. 41/49)

>  <b>1948</b> There she lay, this scow called Pono. <i>Ibid.</i>14 Most of the things he told us about the scow Pono were more suitable for the wheelhouse than for print. (Our Own Country,11)

These vessels are copied from those in use on American lakes, and were first introduced for harbour work here, but being found so suitable for carrying large logs that their shape has rapidly improved, so much that some of them are now fit to go to any part of the world, and are large enough to carry cargoes of up to 50,000 and 60,000 feet of timber. (Auckland Weekly News,30)

The first scows that were built had lee-boards to hold them on the wind, like a Dutch barge - that's where the idea came from. ...  <i>n.</i> a children's game

Scrag, Diabolo, Bumble Puppy, Homai, Fives; <i>Auckland</i>: My Fair Young Lady, Rushes and Reeds, Surrender the Tower, Walls, Ball Hopscotch, ball games, Solomon Says; <i>Hawkes Bay:</i> Wolf Wolf Go Home, Homai; <i>Canterbury:</i> Poor Old Tom, Rats and Rabbits and Rips, Steps, Skin the Snake, Steal a Peg, Toodle-em-Buck, The Gag; <i>Golden Bay</i>: Who's That Walking Round My House Tonight, I've Come to See Poor Mary Jane, Steps and Stairs, Creeping, Branding, O'Leary; <i>Otago</i>: Sir Roger de Coverley, Who's That Knocking at My Door. (History of Children's Play,231)

>  <b>1978</b> <i>SUTHERLAND</i> `Do you play Bull Rush at your school?' John asked. `Bull Rush?' said Ewan. ... `You get out on the field and draw a line at the ends. You pick someone to be He to stand in the middle. He calls out someone's name, and he has to get across to the other end. The guard has to try to tackle the runner and hit him three times. But if the runner gets across he calls out Bull Rush and everyone runs ...[sic]' `That's King-a-Sene!' said Ewan. `But we're only allowed to tag the player, we're not allowed to tackle him ...'[sic] ... `Do you play with the girls at all?' `Sometimes we play Drop the Hnadkerchief. The girls can join in. But most of the time they play Eely Ily Oh, or Queenie, or some cissy game like that...'[sic] `Do you play shinty or football?' `Yeah. Football. And we play scrag in the winter and tippeny runs in the summer...'[sic] (Elver, The,61)



 
 <i>v.</i> to cut over bush that has been cut over before in the hope of getting some good timber.

 <i>n.</i> an inferior whale deficient in blubber [OED lean person or animal 1542. 5. scrag-whale (Nth ?) =scrag-tail whale 1701: EDD. various dial. meanings all connoting residue, useless remainder, rejects. eg wood, offal of meat, small, inferior apples.]

 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1845</b> <i>WAKEFIELD</i> Into [the try-works] the blubber is put .... and the oil is boiled out. The residue is called scrag, and serves to feed the fire. (Adventure in NZ,1/145)

The residue, called scrag, then served to feed the fires. (Marlborough,43)

They tore out the fibres, rubbed them together in their hands to open the bundles, and removed the small tissue that remained by scraping it with their nails. The inferior kind they prepared somewhat differently. They scraped it with a shell, having sometimes previously steeped it in water to soften the skin; they then soaked it in water for from two to four days, heated it with stones while it was wet, and scraped it again, then soaked it again, and then bleached it and dried it on poles ... ## scraper
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a horse with the habit of scraping alongside gates and fences, thus crushing the rider's knees.

>  <b>1962</b> <i>SHARPE</i> If his horse was a 'scraper' it would try to scrape him off at every gatepost. As this trick crushes your knee between the post and the saddle flap, it is unpopular. (Country Occasions,28)



## scraping
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Mar 1904</b> `Ye might try Jim Jackson's tent over there, Missus. ... He's doin' a bit of scraping to-day.' (NZ Illustrated Magazine,431)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1888</b> <i>BARLOW</i> .. the more successful his day's digging, the more scraping lies before him in the evening, and it is considered a good ten hours' work to scrape a hundredweight of gum. (Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,151)



## scrapings
 
 <i>n.</i> sc. of kauri gum

## scrapper
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a dog that picks fights with other dogs.

## scraps
 
 <i>n.</i> (See [cf. scrag](../S#scrag))

(New Zealand  (Polack),1/398)



## scrat
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1904</b> <i>CRADDOCK</i> A new rabbit `scrat' in the middle of one's croquet lawn attracts other rabbits. (Sport in NZ,13)



## scratch
 
 <i>n.</i> money, dough

>  <b>Oct 17, 1952</b> This guy has plenty of scratch (dough to you). (Listener (New Zealand Listener),20) [NOTES: [Owen Jensen]]



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to muster stock known to have been left in a particular locality [usually carried out by a lone musterer.]

>  <b>1947</b> The season at Mesopotamia finished when snow drove us off the hill, while scratching for sheep that had been missed after the autumn muster. (Wayleggo,63)

>  <b>1949</b> <i>NEWTON</i> Although their instructions were to 'just scratch the bottoms' it was inevitable that the top man would have some long hard 'heads' catching sheep up in the basins. 177 They had gone up the river for a week to 'scratch' the wether summer country. (High Country Days,70)

 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1988</b> <i>McGILL</i> <i>scratch cat</.i> sour-tempered female; c.1910. (Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,97)



## scratch factor
 
 <i>n.</i> the provision of conditions for the development of a rumen in calves.

>  <b>2000</b> <i>WESTWOOD</i> Roughage will maintain rumen health, stimulate cud chewing and provide 'scratch factor' for stimulating ongoing rumen development. (Rearing Healthy Calves,5)



## scratch gang
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a team of musterers made up from neighbouring stations or the local workforce, rather than a regular team.

>  <b>1971</b> <i>NEWTON</i> It took four men to muster that country and although it was only a scratch gang - local men who helped out - to me these musterers were the real 'McKay.' (Ten Thousand Dogs,21)

## scratch muster
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1953</b> <i>STRONACH</i> Usually it is mustered by two gangs, one of six and one of four men. ... But this was a scratch muster and we were all together. (Musterer on Molesworth,9)



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to muster stock known to be left in a specific locality.

>  <b>1969</b> <i>NEWTON</i> It meant a lot of poking about, "scratch " mustering, but they just kept on scratching and going back over the country until they found them. (Big Country of the North Island,230)

>  <b>1975</b> <i>NEWTON</i> Every autumn the Rocklands men had to scratch-muster the back of both Beaumont and Gladbrook for straying cattle and it was not uncommon to run across odd bunches of 'cleanskins' - unmarked cattle. (Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,161)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>LOUGHNAN</i> scratch or scratch muster: (n and v) as distinct from straggling or straggle-mustering, which is a full-scale operation to gather in stock previously missed, scratching - often just a one-man operation - is the task of seeking out pockets of stock known to have been missed. [scratch-muster] (Loughnan Glossary,69)



## scratch mustering
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1966</b> It was a job I always liked - scratch mustering or "scratching. (Boss's Story, The,84)



## scratch shingle
 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to muster stock on extreme high country in the South Island.

>  <b>1964</b> <i>NEWTON</i> I've scratched shingle longer than most blokes. (Straggle Muster,19)

>  <b>1964</b> <i>NEWTON</i> Scratched shingle: Mustered on high country - shingle country. So and so may be said to have 'scratched shingle' for a number of years. (Straggle Muster,165)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>LOUGHNAN</i> scratch shingle, to: to muster on hard or high country. (Loughnan Glossary,69)



## scratcher
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a bunk or bedding in a musterers' or hunters' hut.

>  <b>1981</b> <i>LOUGHNAN</i> scratcher: a bed; a bed-roll; a sack. (Loughnan Glossary,70)

>  <b>1983</b> <i>GORDON</i> These [mustering] gangs were made up of men who'd taken up the "burnt chops," ate "hockey sticks" wore "Bill Masseys', slept in a scratcher and rode pigskin. A scratcher's a bunk and when you're riding pigskin, you're in a saddle. (Other Side of Farming, The,1)

>  <b>1997</b> <i>CURTIS</i> I had that S.A.S [sub-area supervisor] bloke out of his 'scratcher' as we called our sleeping bags. (Murphy's Law and the Hunter,50)



 
 <i>n.</i> (informal) bed; a (makeshift) bed, bunk, sleeping bag;(also phrase HIT THE SCRATCHER = hit the sack) [ca1940 Les Cleveland espec. trampers', but also WW2 in 2NZEF (? from fern beds in tramping huts) --ca1945-48 popular in Weir House, VUW.]

>  <b>Apr 13, 1999</b> Take one cuddly middle-aged couple clutching each other's hands over the marital scratcher. (Dominion,21)

>  <b>1959</b> <i>SLATTER</i> Mich efficiently putting me to bed in my blankets on the hard stone floor. _ Come on stick your feet down there. Get into the scratcher. (Gun in My Hand, A,92)

>  <b>1960</b> <i>CRUMP</i> We lit a fire and discussed how we were going to get our sleeping-bags. Jack said someone should ... distract Allan's attention while the others zipped in [to the hut] and grabbed our scratchers. (Good Keen Man, A,33)

>  <b>1964</b> <i>HELMER</i> [sleeping bag] `After all, getting out of this old scratcher takes a lot of effort.' He hopped back to his bunk ... Then we wash up and crawl into our scratchers. Scuppers has a surplus American Army mummy bag that zips up tight around the head, eh? (Stag Party,56)

>  <b>1980</b> <i>LELAND</i> <i> scratcher</i>: or Grunter After along and tiring day when you finally lay your wearly bones to rest, you do it on a scratcher. BEDS can of course be used for other activities. (Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,89)

>  <b>Jun 17, 2003</b> By this time I was far too heavy of lid to stay up and retired to the scratcher... (Dominion Post,B7)



 
 <i>n.</i> someone/something disliked [1984 17 M E101Pakuranga Coll. 3 SCRATCHER]

## scratching, be
 
 <i>v.</i> 1. to be unable to be able to find enough money for a particular purpose, or in analogous difficulty; to be short of something (esp. money), to find it difficult to make up a required amount. -->ca1930; 2. to be hunting desperately for excuses or explanations; be caught out. cf P: be in a dilemma Austr. ca1910 B 1942 AC 1930. -->ca1941 [Jim writes e.g. "He says he's buying a new boat. He'll be scratching." This is not in any dictionary I have seen; it appears to be an extension of scratch as in "scratch a living".]

## screw
 
 <i>n.</i> a person in authority, teacher, police officer [1984 16 F E30 Pakuranga Coll. 24C SCREWS -->1984 14 F E136 Wgton Girls C. 24C SCREWS [4]]



 
 <i>v.</i> to make a crock of (a horse) (See [cf. AND screwed](../A#and-screwed))

 <i>v.</i> to speed

 <i>v.</i>

>  <b>1948</b> `Captain' Scotland personally supervised the stowing [of the wool-cargo] `screwing' the bales into the hold to the singing of sea shanties. The bales were stowed by hand until the last in each row, when `screw-jacks' were used, based on `samson posts', to screw the last bale of the tier into position ..... This method of stowing wool was sometimes referred to as `wool-jamming' or `screwing' (Port Chalmers,43)



 
 <i>n.</i> a look

>  <b>1968</b> <i> screw n. </i>a look; <i>(Phr.) have, or take a screw at. </i> (NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),17)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> a guard

<b>3</b> <i>n.</i> a mean man who `screws' his workers

<b>4</b> <i>n.</i> (Marist Fathers' Colleges) a toady; a boy who curries favour with the masters (cf BUM, BUMMER, from BUM-SCREW) [this should be separate as coming from a different metaphor (or rather metonymy -?or synecdoche - part for a whole -) to BUM SCREW, rather than PUT THE SCREWS ON] [ca1931 St Patrick's College, Wellington (p.c. Fr Scully) -->ca1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream -->1951 14-15 M 14 St Bede's, Chch 7 SCREW [something not good] -->1951 14 M 10 St Bede's, Chch 3 SCREW [someone disliked -->1951 14 M 14 St Bede's, Chch 17 SCREW [boasting] -->1951 15 M 9 St Bede's, Chch 25 SCREWS [new kids] -->1957 Nov 26 Rev. >  <b>Sep 1958</b> If any word originating in the mountain clubs deserves to be incorporated in the language it is perhaps scroggin. That mixture of raisins, sultanas, chocolate, nuts, boiled lollies, a mixture of bits and pieces of whatever one fancies, was evolved to fill the need for a sustaining, palatable, easily-carried food, one as readily available for a bite snatched in a cold, wet, momentary halt as for a welcome spell in the warmth and sun. The word seems to come from Otago but its derivation is not clear. There is a Scotch and North of England dialect word scrog which refers to stunted bushes, and if some Otago Scot had this in mind it prompts dark thoughts as to what the original comestible may have been like. Perhaps it is one of those words that have no known ancestry, that come out of the blue, such as children sometimes so happily coin. (Tararua,26) [NOTES: 1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' in Tararua 26]

<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to treat or regard a thing or idea as worthless; cancel irrevocably, write off; wipe; wash out, in racing (of a horse) `to scratch; write off' esp. exclamation: scrub it `forget (all about) it; wipe it; `it doesn't matter'. [[The NZ senses, if not variants of imported Austr (cf P. above) would seem to be orig. associated with, if not originated in, the racing slang: (phs cleaning the bookmaker's slate): scrubbed or scrub (a horse) to have lost; be scratched: or scratch. But the senses also parallel those of words with similar meanings: to wipe (off) (a person or thing), get wiped; wash out (sthg), a wash-out; to write off (sbdy or sthg), a write-off. The word seems noticeable after WW2, so perhaps it was popularised by NZ servicemen who may have picked it up from British Servicemen (or Australians): cf P.4. The connotation of contempt may have derived in part by association with SCRUB n and aj `poor, mean' etc, scrubby etc; and the particular uses of this in Australasia: scrub-bull; scrubber, scrub along.]]

## scrum
 
 <i>n.</i> transferred usage for "tribe" or "iwi".

>  <b>Jun 27, 1998</b> Since Sir Tipene O'Regan identified his Ngai Tahu as a scrum, I've several times heard the word picked up and used for South Island Maoris. (Dominion,14)



 
 <i>n.</i> rhyming slang for THRUM, threepenny-bit

>  <b>Nov 4, 1905</b> ... they would find more people ready to chuck a scrum in the [church] plate. (NZ Truth,20/3/6)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> collective `cash;' (Perhaps `silver' as distinct from `copper' money.)

>  <b>Sep 16, 1905</b> ... couple who did not possess the necessary `brown' or `scrum' would recline on the grass [instead of paying for seats]. (NZ Truth,13/5/2)



## scrum machine
 
 <i>n.</i> device to simulate an opposition for scrummaging practice

>  <b>Jun 2005</b> This was the rugby scrum machine, an almost standard item of equipment at any rugby practice today. The first mention of a rugby scrum machine occurred at Auckland in 1926. The Varsity Colts club team, coached by Athol Miller, used to train each week at a shed in Parnell. Miller rigged up chaff bags on a wooden frame for the forwards to scrum against - it was a functional and rather crude arrangement. (NZ Memories,No. 54, p. 47)

## scrunch
 
 <i>n.</i> baked bread slices

 <i>n.</i>

## scud
 
 <i>n.</i> cellular debris from the skin of sheep (found in DEAD WOOL)



## scudding
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Aug 1921</b> The process of fleshing is usually carried out by machines operating a right-and-left spiral knife-cylinder ... flesh side to the knife cylinder. A process similar to fleshing is also carried out in order to remove as much as possible of the hair root-sheaths and fat glands upon the grain side of the pelt. This process is known as `scudding', the skins being fed into the machine, grain side to the knife cylinder. (NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/159) [NOTES: (Wright)]



## scuffler
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1892</b> So soon as the turnip-plants reach the third or fourth leaf, they are thinned in a primitive and yet in a thoroughly-efficient method. A scuffler, made for the purpose , is drawn across the drills, bunching the turnips and loosening the soil in a thorough manner. (NZ Official Handbook,118)



## scull
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Mar 1992</b> The record for a jug scull stands at about one second flat - which defies the laws of nature. (Metro,10)



 
 <i>v.</i> drink rapidly or in a single draught (See [also skull](../A#also-skull))

>  <b>Oct 16, 1993</b> The days of sculling back pints allnight, getting into your car, drivinghome and bashing up your partner areover. (Dominion,12)

>  <b>Sep 2, 2000</b> Which 1962 Labour backbencher skulled 15 beers in Bellamy's during one division on the Maritime Shipping Amendment Bill and upchecked over the Speaker's sheepskin? (Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

>  <b>May 20, 1989</b> A tough job when you're sculling beer with the lads after work. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

>  <b>Sep 21, 1998</b> She can snigger about "trashy" price ranges and European culture, scull expensive alcohol, hobnob with intellectuals and still find time in her transient champagne lifestyle to give us her qualified thoughts on what it's like to be a single young woman. (Dominion,8)

>  <b>Apr 7, 2004</b> [She] found herself sculling half of her two-litre bottle of L&P, just to get it through the gate. (Dominion Post,A5)

>  <b>Dec 26, 1998</b> I'm definitely not anti-drinking, but remember to ask yourself when you skull down that beer, "Where is that drink taking you?" (Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

>  <b>2007</b> <i>Dave Armstrong</i> Norman Kinghorn sculled his beer, wiped his face with a serviette..., and let out a very satisfied burp. (Six Pack 2, The,118)

>  <b>Feb 13, 1999</b> When we were younger, my friends and I would pour a bit out of each of our parents' liqueurs into a communal bottle, which we would then skull straight. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),93)

>  <b>1985</b> <i>JONES</i> Later he stopped by the dairy to scull a milkshake ... (Gilmore's Dairy,56) [NOTES: [xref needed under DAIRY???]]

>  <b>Jun 3, 1986</b> Some [student association] presidents manage better than others at jug sculls! With suitable decorum and dignity, one nameless Auckland Prez managed to scull a jug in the public bar of a venerable Auckland drinking establishment, whereupon he escaped, or so he thought, to the sanctuary of the lounge bar. However, he was pressed into sculling another jug - which he did, maintaining his dignity, and most importantly of all, his liquor, all the while. <i>jug sculls </i>, a simple matter of either <i>being able to or not being able to </i>were won by a Canterbury drinker. The University of Canterbury Student's Association had sent down a team for this event and the <i>boat races.</i> (Campus News,14)

>  <b>Apr 18, 1988</b> You're still there, with your cup of coffee. ... It's cold by now, so you scull the rest. (Salient)

>  <b>1988</b> <i>McGILL</i> <i>scull </i>to drink ; eg `I wish I hadn't sculled so much beer, it didn't do me any good. Just look at my stomach!' <i>[Alison Gray] </i> (Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,97)

>  <b>Jul 19, 2002</b> "Sometimes I would get really thirsty and I would want to skull their beer". (Capital Times,11)

>  <b>Sep 18, 2001</b> Pull yourself together / skull this beer down, mate. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

>  <b>Dec 18, 2002</b> Undergraduates swilling tonic water not only acted drunk after being told they were sculling vodka and tonic, but were also more susceptible to misleading information, two Victoria University Researchers have found. (Capital Times,2)



 
 <i>v.</i> to move

>  <b>Jul 20, 1942</b> The tanks sculled around and swept away from the path of the New Zealanders in their surprise. (NZEF Times,II/56 : 1)



## sculling/skulling
 
 <i>n.</i> a drinking game (See [scull](../S#scull))

>  <b>Dec 20, 1986</b> The best-known primer for this kind of activity, and indeed an integral part of the hoon-ethos itself, is the drinking game. Designed to take the monotony out of rapid, heavy drinking, the drinking game perhaps found its purest expression in the version entitled Next. Down a drink as fast as possible (commonly known as `sculling'), turn to the bloke on your left and say `Next', whereupon he does the same ... very efficient. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

>  <b>Sep 12, 1986</b> Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke astonished students at the New England University here tonight with a display of his drinking prowess. Mr Hawke, who at one stage held the world record for beer drinking, was called upon to take part in a traditional sculling competition during a dinner at the University's Sir Earle Page College. (Evening Post,24)

>  <b>Jul 19, 2002</b> So how does she reconcile her angelic voice and image with this stubbie-wearing-beer-skulling woman? (Capital Times,11)

## scunge

## scunner
 
 <i>v.</i> (with to) shrink or flinch from [ORIGIN: British dialect, in SOED6 as Scots and N. English]

>  <b>Nov 13, 1901</b> Most of the fishing in the large streams at present is done with the minnow, and with what local anglers call worms, but which one might be pardoned for mistaking for young eels or snakes, huge reptiles that an Otago angler would scunner to look at, let alone handle. (Otago Witness,44)



 
 <i>v.</i> to overcome; destroy; knock out

>  <b>Jun 6, 1979</b> <i>IAN MCGREGOR</i> It's enough to scunner a pig (Personal Communication)



 
 <i>n.</i> a (strong) dislike [ca1930]

>  <b>Apr 18, 1867</b> The pigs had eaten nearly all the flesh off the limbs, and to look at the bodies would have given one a "scunner" at pork, if there had been anything else to eat. (Daily Southern Cross,5)

>  <b>Oct 5, 1878</b> He has evidently taken a "scunner" at the Templars. They have not backed up his political prospects as he expected. (Otago Witness,14)

>  <b>Oct 11, 1890</b> A 'scunner' is (in the vocabulary of the Scot) a feeling of sickening, loathing disgust - worse than sea-sickness or nausea of any kind - therefore is most applicable to the epidemic revolt against Parliamentary Government which prevails as universally as la grippe did a few months ago. (Observer (Auckland),3)

>  <b>Jun 12, 1913</b> Every horse has his own way of galloping, and though English trainers have a scunner upon any colt which keeps his head up, Craganour must be taken as an exception from their rule. (Poverty Bay Herald,5)

>  <b>Sep 3, 1921</b> Sex is one of the great facts of life, and the public never will cease to be interested in sex, but to blame the public for the orgies of riotous sex portrayed in the movies is too much. The fact is the public is fed on this stuff until it is a marvel a "scunner" has not set in. (NZ Truth,1)

>  <b>1992</b> <i>PARK</i> Disliking [Te Kuiti] on earlier, briefer visits, she now took a scunner to the town that lasted till her dying day. (Fence Around the Cuckoo,13)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> a look at , a scan

>  <b>1939</b> <i>BEATTIE</i> The sale was at Invercargill, but I did not go down as I had got what the Scot calls a `scunner' at the district. (First White Boy Born in Otago,188)

## sea ear
 
 <i>n.</i> a former name for paua

>  <b>1840</b> <i>POLACK</i> Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called <i>para </i>[as-acute] <i>paraua </i>[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, <i>mungu nui </i> (black physeter); right whale, <i>tohora </i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, <i>mango </i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes. (Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202 fn)

>  <b>Feb 1777</b> <i>ANDERSON</i> Of other shellfish there are ten or twelve sorts such as periwinkles, wilks, limpets, and some very beautiful sea Ears and another sort that sticks to the weeds , with some other things as sea eggs, starfish ... ed. fn Periwinkles, <i>Melarhapa</i> spp. (2), and probably <i>Zediloma</i> and <i>Melagraphia</i> spp. Whelks, <i>Cominella</i> sp. Limpets, <i>Cellana</i> spp. The `very beautiful sea Ears' were certainly the Paua, <i>Haliotis iris; ... </i> (Journal,3/808,1967 ed.) [NOTES: (Queen Charlotte Sound) 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967)]

>  <b>Mar 1777</b> ... an od design'd figure of a man with ... large white eys made of the Shells of sea ears. (Cook's Journals,1/284)

>  <b>1848</b> <i>WAKEFIELD</i> The natives fish for them [kawai] with a hook lined with pieces of the parti-coloured shell of the <i>haliotus </i> or sea-ear. (Handbook for New Zealand, The,160)

>  <b>1871</b> <i>WILLIAMS</i> <i>Marapeka </i> n. <i>haliotis virginica </i> , a small species of sea-ear called also <i>kororiwha. </i> (Dictionary of the NZ Language,76)

>  <b>1892</b> <i>WILLIAMS</i> <i>Kororiwha, ...haliotis virginica </i> ; a small species of <i>sea-ear</i>; (Dictionary of the NZ Language,74)

>  <b>1942</b> <i>ANDERSEN</i> paua (sea-ear, or mutton-fish-Haliotis) (Maori Place Names,14)

>  <b>1942</b> <i>ANDERSEN</i> We dived for a few paua - abalone, ormer, or sea-ear (Maori Place Names,14)

>  <b>1957</b> <i>WILLIAMS</i> <i>Paua,</i> n. 1. <i>Haliotis </i> of several species, <i>sea-ear, mutton-fish; </i> (Dictionary of the Maori Language,273)

>  <b>1977</b> <i>BUSH & SCOTT</i> We dived for a few paua - abalone, ormer, or sea-ear. (Auckland at Full Stretch,29) [NOTES: 1977 Keith Sinclair `Experiences of Auckland ...' in Bush and Scott (ed) Auckland at Full Stretch 29]

## sea elephant
 
 <i>n.</i> = elephant seal

>  <b>Jan 22, 1945</b> A bull sea elephant.. came ashore on the rocks early on Christmas Day. (NZEF Times,IV/187 : 7)

>  <b>Apr 2, 1945</b> Billy, a sea elephant, who recently adopted the Hutt River as his regular habitat, is dead. (NZEF Times,IV/197)

>  <b>Sep 16, 1848</b> There is a small settlement on Tristan D'Achunha [sic] (which is probably of volcanic origin), formed for the purpose of preparing oil from the fat of the sea-elephant ... (Daily Southern Cross,4)

>  <b>Mar 23, 1850</b> The captain, mate, five seamen, and four Sappers and Miners, contrived to reach the shore (bound by high precipitous cliffs), and after enduring the extremities of cold and hunger, were at length (August 1st) relieved by a party of men from the Cape of Good Hope, who had been some months on the island, engaged in killing sea-elephants. (Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,14)

>  <b>Jul 18, 1889</b> ".. Months elapse between the visits of Government cruisers, and during these intervals there is not a man anywhere on the coast even to warn off errant whalers or sea-elephant hunter from the rookeries ..." (Otago Witness,28)

>  <b>Feb 5, 1875</b> Sea-elephant hunting at the Macquaries, on the other hand, has not had such success, attributable, however, not to the scarcity of these animals, but to the recent stormy weather. (Grey River Argus,2)

>  <b>Sep 8, 1913</b> Mr. Sawyer said that although they were able to subsist on sea-elephants' meat, it was not the best of fare as far as the general health was concerned, and several of the Mawson party had been "off colour" at different times owing to their rough diet. (Grey River Argus,4)

>  <b>Jul 18, 1840</b> The southern whale fishery consists of three distinct branches; first, that of the spermaceti whale; second, that of the common black whale of the southern seas; and third, that of the sea elephant, or southern walrus. (New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

>  <b>Sep 28, 1867</b> The land was dotted with birds, and the water alive with seals and sea elephants. (Taranaki Herald,4)

>  <b>Apr 8, 1921</b> There are various members of the seal family, such as the common seal, the walrus, the sea elephant, the sea lion, and the fur seal. (Ashburton Guardian,5)

>  <b>Apr 20, 1938</b> Besides the fur seals,.. sea leopards and see elephants, thronged the reefs and cliffs, rocks and beaches on the Solanders. (Auckland Weekly News,96)

>  <b>1893</b> SEA-ELEPHANTS. These are massive, unwieldy, and gigantic animals, which have a very restricted distribution, being confined to the islands in the extreme south. They are chiefly prized for the large quantity and fine quality of oil which they produce. <i>Ibid.</i> 25/258 SEA-ELEPHANT (<i>Macrorhinus elephantina</i>).This huge seal was formerly abundant on many of the Antarctic islands, but is now almost confined to Kerguelen's Land, Hood Island, and the Macquarie Islands. (TrNZI,25/256) [NOTES: (Hector)]

>  <b>1986</b> <i>GRADY</i> The principal place where southern elephant seals, or sea elephants, have been slaughtered in large numbers near New Zealand has been Macquarie Island. The name `sea elephant' comes from the inflatable, trunk-like proboscis which is very conspicuous in bulls. Early sealers simply called them `elephants'. (Sealers and Whalers,53)

>  <b>1956</b> <i>GRAHAM</i> JOHN DORY (KUPARU)<i> Zeus australis</i> Richardson <i>Ibid.</i> 180. For some obscure reason the local abundant Seaperch, or Jock Stuart, has been termed the John Dory by Otago commercial and sport fishermen and others. (NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,178)

>  <b>1956</b> <i>GRAHAM</i> SEAPERCH (POHUIAKAROA) JOCK STUART, HIGHLANDER, FIVEFINGER, SOLDIERFISH or SCRODDIE <i>Helicolenus papillosus</i> (Bloch and Schneider) The seaperch is a fish well known to all fishermen both sports and commercial fishermen alike, who give it quite a number of vernacular names, a few of which are as follows: Jock Stuart, Highlander, Fivefinger and Soldierfish. These names have a bearing on some distinguishing characteristic of the fish. For instance the first two names are supposed to be given on account of the colouring of the fish resembling, in some ways, the tartan of a Scot; while Fivefingers is given on account of the so-called five (really more) fingers (rays) of the pectoral fins, on which the fish has a habit of resting on the floor of the aquarium tank. The name Soldierfish is derived from the similarities of this fish to the activities of a soldier or picket on sentinel duty. I have often seen Seaperch stand or, rather, rest at attention on its pectoral fins for lengthy periods. When it did move, it moved to the right or to the left with the precision of a well-trained soldier. The name Scroddie, commonly used at the northern end of the South Island, is derived from the word Scrod which means a young Dogfish. It appears from my researches that when the early colonists first saw a small Seaperch they at once named it Scrod and later the `ie' was tacked on to make Scroddie. (NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,344)

## seal's ballast
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1871</b> Anyone who had ever been about old whaling and sealing stations must have seen collections of round smooth stones of various sizes but mostly about the size of cannon-balls, lying on the beach. On asking any of the `old hands' what these are, you will at once be told that they are `seal's ballast' ... You will probably be gravely told that the seal is a migratory animal, and that when it is about to take a long journey it will trim itself to exactly the proper weight for long and easy locomotion through the water. It picks up one of these stones and swallows it and goes into the water to try the effect. If it finds it requires more ballast it comes ashore again and repeats the dose. If it has too much weight .... it vomits one or two of the stones out on the beach. Hence the stones are always termed `seals' ballast' (TrNZI,4/417) [NOTES: (Otago)]

If the Company had appointed a proper officer here to purchase the land from the natives, and see possession given to the sectionists, they might by all this time have been settled. ## self reliance

(History of New Zealand,140)

## selling a horse
 
 <i>phr.</i> a bar game to determine who in a group is to pay for drinks [ca1920s p.c. W.H.B. Orsman (Marlborough): similar to Hokitika Swindle.]

>  <b>Jan 7, 1909</b> A riot occurred at an hotel about 5 p.m. yesterday, when a young man from the country entered into a game called "selling a horse," but then withdrew. (Wanganui Herald,5)

>  <b>1948</b> Another form of gambling ... is that known as `selling a horse' ... A member of the party thinks of, or writes down a number and another member starts counting, beginning at any number below ten, and the party takes it in turn to count, much as in the Army a platoon is numbered off. The member saying the number thought of or written down collects the pool. (Auckland Capping Book,16)

>  <b>1939</b> <i>BELTON</i> The procedure is sometimes referred to as `selling a horse' Each person pools so much money and a number is written down and hidden from view. The person who writes a number down requests one of the others to start counting, commencing at any number desired, provided that it is lower than the winning number. The counting is then carried on in rotation and stops when the written number is reached. The winner then takes the pool and pays for whatever has been purchased .... (Outside the Law,139)

>  <b>1938</b> <i>HYDE</i> `That doesn't buy our drinks,' said Sam. Another man said: `We'll sell a horse, and find out who pays.' They were selling the horse, when a big black car slid up against the kerb. A voice called: `What's the trouble, you men?' (Nor the Years Condemn,85)

>  <b>1928</b> Another form of gambling which I view much less harshly is that known as `selling a horse.' The process is as follows. A member of the party thinks of, or writes down a number and another member starts counting, beginning at any number below ten, and the party takes it in turn to count, much as in the Army a platoon is numbered off. The member saying the number thought of or written down collects the pool. This game, though coming under the heading Games of Chance is probably the one really honest game in that category. I myself usually win it, especially in parties where there is no one with a pencil and I think of the number. (Auckland University Carnival Book,16) [NOTES: 1928 Auckland U.C. Students' Association Souvenir Programme Revue `Tilly in the City' 16-17]

## servantgalism
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>May 25, 2002</b> Amazing, the words people find buried in unlikely websites. Geoff Sommerville was browsing through Papers Past last 19th-century section of the National Library's site, and chanced on servantgalism. He reports the context told him it was a term for servants who got too big for their boots. Servantgalism, and its male equivalent flunkeiana, were slang words in use in colonial Australia when servants were hard to come by. <i>Melbourne Punch</i> in 1861, for instance, ran a cartoon of a prospective employer offering to drown a few of his children to accommodate a maid who found looking after seven would be too much. (Dominion,14)

## shagroon
 
 <i>n.</i> an immigrant esp. from Australia, but also from other settlements) to the early Canterbury settlement, often applied to one settled there before the main influx of PILGRIMS (contrast PILGRIM, PRE-ADAMITE, PROPHET) [History: an early non-Canterbury Association settler in Canterbury. (hist) [OED2 (following Morris) Phs f. Irish <i>seachra'n </i>wandering.:<i> searchan</i> transliterates <i>shaughraun </i>=?/sh |r n/: I have not been able to find Walls's<i> shabberoon</i>, etc., but if these forms exist they are more likely to be alterations of <i>shagroon</i> towards a play on<i> shab</i>, a common English dialect variant of <i>scab</i>, the dread sheep disease of early NZ, which would fit in with the usu.derogatory or dismissive connotations of the word.b But <i>shab, shabbaroon </i>are not yet otherwise attested in NZ contexts and must be ruled out; as must Sinclair's suggestion of <i>shagreen</i> (rough exterior) spg also <i>shagaroon, shagrun;</i> ?erron. spg or misprint <i>shaproon</i>; cf Walls's <i>shabberoon etc</i>. occas. cap. Morris 1898]

>  <b>Sep 15, 1892</b> In a letter dated 8th March 1850, in mentioning a visit to the Taieri Plain, the writer says: "We visited the warri or hut of a Shaproon - <i>ie.,</i> one of the retired whalers 'who have married Maori wives.' Can you tell me the meaning and derivation of the word Shaproon, and why the retired whalers were so called?" <i>Ibid</i> 22 September. 24 Shaproon is from the French <i>chaperon</i>, and originally meant "little captain." ..There is no doubt that the term was used by French sailors and those in contact with them with the same meaning as English sailors use the word mate. Mispronounced and misspelt by its adoption into the English of rough-and-ready sea-faring men, shaproon would have this signification, and even under certain circumstances might reassume its original acceptation of little leader, and be addressed to the captain of a small band, and become equivalent in a new country, as this was 50 years ago, to the word pioneer. (Otago Witness,24)

>  <b>1949</b> <i>PARTRIDGE</i> <i>Shagroons.</i> Australian settlers that went<i> en masse</i>, to Canterbury, New Zealand, in 1851-2: Australian and New Zealand: ca. 1851-70. B., 1942. With a pun on <i>shagreen</i>, the rough skin of<i> sharks. </i> (Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1165)

>  <b>May 7, 1851</b> Apr 19 <i>Lyttelton Times </i>`Government might have founded a colony composed of stragglers from other settlements, of whale-fishers and stock-drivers, but would they have persuaded a body of English gentlemen to transfer their homes to these shores?' The following was written in reply:] `Dream of Shagroon' [title] I saw men of another aspect arrive at the pilgrim-land. ... The Pilgrims looked with contemptuous eye on this people of strange aspect and impure blood, and did despise them. ... I awoke - and lo! the land which was to have been sacred to the orthodox foot only of a `body of English gentlemen', was in possession of the `stragglers, the whalers, and the stock-drivers from other settlements'. Alas! for the goodly land, - the land of the Canterbury Pilgrims. (NZ Spectator) [NOTES: 1851 May 7 NZ Spectator and Cook's Strait Guardian (Wellington) in 1947 Reed Story of Canterbury 111 [1851]

>  <b>Jul 4, 1851</b> The Eudora and Raven have arrived with a good stock of Shagroons who will soon infuse a new vitality into the drooping pilgrims. It is true the Shagroons don't know what to think at the great change between the arid plains of Australia, and the moist green sward of New Zealand, nor will they be able to draw any comparison if they should stay until mid-summer and behold the verdant plains, .... [Autograph marginal note `beachcombers'] (Australian & NZ Gazette,30/483) [NOTES: (Letter from Christchurch)]

(Lyttelton Times,6)

(Lyttelton Times) [NOTES: 1852 May 8 Lyttelton Times, in 1866 Canterbury Rhymes 8, and 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station jVerse 5 (M.P. Stoddart)]

>  <b>Nov 25, 1948</b> <i>WALL</i> Who first called these immigrants by this opprobrious name is not stated, but it seems to me most probable that the Pilgrims used it as a term of contempt, and [110] that the immigrants took it to themselves much as the `Old Contemptibles' ... adopted their enemies' names in a spirit of defiance. ... There arises the further question as to the origin of the word which ... has been explained as an Irish `shaughraun'. Now why should an Irish word have been used at that time by the English settlers in Canterbury? ... My belief is that the word was not originally `Shagroon' but `Shabroon', `shabberoon', `shabbaroon' (all spellings occur) which is on record from the 18th century onwards, meaning `a mean, shabby fellow', `a disreputable or mean-spirited fellow', and this, which would be probably familiar to the English Pilgrims, is just the sort of term which would naturally be used to describe their rivals. This `shabroon' derives from the slang `shab', a low fellow, recorded as early as 1637, and no doubt closely alied to the standard `shabby', and ultimately from `shab' and `scab', two forms of the old English word. ... I conjecture that the `shabroon' [?does Wall mean `shagroon] of the English Pilgrims was by some pronounced with the `b' and by others with the `g', nobody ever having seen the word written or printed. [EDD records only `shaggareen' from east Yorkshire `an untidy, slovenly person'; possibly f. shabrag] (Letter) [NOTES: 1948 Nov 25 Arnold Wall letter in 1947 Reed Story of Canterbury 109-110]

>  <b>1947</b> <i>REED</i> It appears to have been the Australian squatters [let in to Canterbury by Godley to provide capital and flocks for unsold land] who jocularly termed the pioneer English settlers the `Canterbury Pilgrims', ... [Quotes Webster and Funk and Wagnall: both definitions erroneous] (Story of Canterbury, The,109)

(Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>1859</b> <i>THOMSON</i> ...An old Australian squatter, who visited the Canterbury settlement in 1851, divided the inhabitants into pilgrims, shagruns, and prophets; the first were the original colonists, the second were people from other parts of New Zealand, and the last were settlers from Australia. (Story of New Zealand, The,186)

>  <b>1866</b> The pilgrim toiled for his crop. ... Shortly the pilgrim and prophet agreed The plough and the crook couldn't live far apart. (Canterbury Rhymes) [NOTES: [1851] 1866 Canterbury Rhymes 5, 9, 125 `Pilgrims and Prophets'. [title of Poem] 9.[NOTE 1866] 125. During the first year of the Settlement, Canterbury was invaded by a body of sheep-farmers from Port Philip (Victoria) who were regarded by the settlers partly with admiration as successful Colonists, and partly with horror as disbelievers in the art of colonisation and the `Canterbury System'. The visitors found the country admirably adapted for sheep-farming, and they treated with some contempt the raw emigrants from England who looked to agriculture as the foundation of their fortunes. One of the vistiors, who seem to have delighted in the soubriquet of `Shagroon', ventured to prophesy, in a letter, which found its way into print, that the `Canterbury Pilgrims' would soon be ruined and their country left for occupation by his more enlightened comrades. The `pilgrims' sought no harsher revenge than to nickname their Port Philip visitors `prophets' and to take example from their experience in pastoral pursuits. The Canterbury pasturage system was quickly adapted to the requirements of sheepfarming on a large scale, and `pilgrims' and `prophets' were soon merged into one class of Canterbury runholders.]

>  <b>1877</b> <i>PRATT</i> In the `Dream of a Shagroon' which bore the date Ko Motinau, April 1851, and which first appeared in the `Wellington Spectator' of May 7th, the term Pilgrim was first applied to the settlers; it was also predicted in it that the `Pilgrims', would be `smashed' and the `Shagroons' left in undisputed possession of the country for their flocks and herds. (Colonial Experiences,234)

>  <b>1886</b> <i>HART</i> An old `Shagroon', as those who were here when the settlers arrived were called, had given us the salutary advice to cut a ditch around our hut ... <i>Ibid.</i> 18 In the earlier months of the year 1852 the country to the northward and southward of Christchurch began to be taken up for pastoral purposes. This was carried out principally by stock owners from Australia, who, to distinguish them from the Pilgrims or those who came from England direct to Canterbury, were called Shagroons. What this title is derived from is not quite clear. An amusing piece ... respecting the climate of New Zealand, and particularly Canterbury, was published about this time, and as it shews what opinion our Australian visitors held of our vaunted New Zealand climate, perhaps to reproduce it would be interesting. ... our Australian bard, under the title of `The Shagroon's Lament,' discourses as follows:- (Stray Leaves,10)

>  <b>1913</b> <i>CARR</i> When the flax arrives at the mill it is weighed and credited to the cutter. The `bench loader' then takes two or three bundles and puts them in a barrel (heavy end down). He then takes the longest leaves and places them on a bench convenient to the `feeder'. ...[44] The `feeder' takes each blade separately and places the butt end into the `stripper' which takes the green outer covering off. ... The fibre as it leaves the stripper is caught by the `fly boy', who collects enough to make into a hank, which he places convenient for the `shaker'. The latter, with a motion like cracking a whip, gets rid of as much rubbish as possible, after which he places the hank handy for the `washer'. This man places the fibre in a vat, through which ... clean water is running. (Country Work,43)

 <i>n.</i> New Zealand

>  <b>Oct 2000</b> Three expression found in Australian dictionaries.. testify to New Zealand's susceptibility to earthquakes. <i>AND</i> has <i>Shaky Isles</i> (also <i>Shakey isles</i>) and <i>Shivery isles</i>, both of these again being associated with the <i>Bulletin</i>, and both dating from 1933 (just after Napier, that is). (NZWords,4 : 2)

>  <b>Apr 15, 1931</b> Even the ghastly disaster which laid the towns of Napier and Hastings in ruin and revived overseas references to these "Shaky Isles" had its amusing side. (Aussie (NZ Section),III)

>  <b>Nov 30, 2011</b> I suppose it's to be expected in the Shaky Isles, but the clear division of red votes to the west and blue votes to the east of the Southern Alps, and likewise about the fault line through the Hutt Valley did surprise. (Dominion Post,B4)

>  <b>1941</b> <i>BAKER</i> New Zealand ... became <i>the Dominion, the Shakey Isles, the Quakey Isles, [etc]. (NZ Slang,49)

>  <b>1986</b> <i>Shaky Isles colloq</i>. New Zealand. (NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,701) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

>  <b>Jul 27, 2003</b> The Australian media was reverberating with the awful prospect of a blackwash weekend. Two-zip to the Shaky Isles on top of the netball. (Sunday Star Times,B4)

>  <b>Nov 29, 1924</b> This week's mail from the other side brought the news that in the near future Albert Lloyd, the heavyweight, who was over about four years ago, is making tracks back to the Shaky Isles. (NZ Truth,10)

>  <b>Nov 20, 1930</b> She took an engagement in New Zealand, and while she was in the Shaky Isles, she said, she sent Carey some of her salary to support him. (NZ Truth,8)



## Shaky Town
 
 <i>n.</i> Christchurch, following the earthquakes of 2010-2011.

>  <b>Sep 19, 2011</b> Shaky town is coming apart as a spluttering prophet says end is night [hdg]. THE TAXI DRIVER I selected from the Auckland Airport cab rank asked me where I'd come from and when I said, "Christchurch", he raised his left hand from the wheel, shook it in an imitation of a tremble and asked: "So how is shaky town?" (Dominion Post,B5)

>  <b>Apr 1, 2011</b> We were with friends Melanie and Andrew from Christchurch. Equally stressed and looking to escape "shaky town" for a few days, they too were trekking new territory. (Waikato Times,A15)

>  <b>Sep 13, 2010</b> Helping out in shaky town [hdg] (Timaru Herald,A3)

## shandy rating
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1971</b> The Australians have a name for mixed rating systems. They call it `Shandy Rating'. `Shandy' is a mixed drink usually beer and lemonade and shandy rating is a mixture of rating systems such as Unimproved or Land Value rating and Capital or Annual Value rating in one local body area. New Zealand has had `shandy rating' for years in Christchurch and Invercargill for example. ... New Zealand can do without shandy rating. (Rating Bulletin, The) [NOTES: 1971 Jun The Rating Bulletin issued by NZ Unimproved Value Rating Assn (Griffiths Collection)]



## shandygaff
 
 <i>adj.</i> wishy-washy, compromising

>  <b>Jun 24, 1905</b> He might have dropped an inky tear or two about our shandygaff footpaths - half tar and half mud. (NZ Free Lance,6)

>  <b>Jun 16, 1911</b> How long are the workers going to stand this treatment at the hands of this shandy-gaff Government, wherein the honest ale of democracy is drowned by the washy lemonade of alleged Liberalism? (Maoriland Worker,15/2/3)



 
 <i>n.</i> a crossbred dog

>  <b>1971</b> <i>NEWTON</i> <i>Shandy-gaff:</i> A dog bred from the crossing of heading dogs and huntaways. (Ten Thousand Dogs,169)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a mixture of stock in one locality or a mixture of wet and dry sheep.

>  <b>Nov 25, 1933</b> Shandygaff.- various sorts of sheep mixed together in a yard. Wet and dry sheep together. Hence the verb use: to put wet sheep with dry ones in the woolshed in order to deceive the shearers. (Press, The  (Acland Glossary),15)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>LOUGHNAN</i> shandygaff: (i): various sorts of sheep mixed together. (ii): damp and dry sheep mixed together. (Loughnan Glossary,70)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [ sheepdogs] a cross between a huntaway and a heading dog.

>  <b>1971</b> <i>NEWTON</i> If I remember rightly, she was a shandy-gaff (by a heading dog out of a huntaway) ... (Ten Thousand Dogs,54)

>  <b>1975</b> <i>NEWTON</i> A real mainstay-type, Mike is a 'shandy-gaff' by a huntaway out of a heading bitch. (Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,60)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>LOUGHNAN</i> shandygaff: (iii): dog of a huntaway/header cross. (Loughnan Glossary,70)

>  <b>Dec 15, 1983</b> Shandy Gaff - Offspring from a heading dog/huntaway cross - invariably unplanned - 'by midnight out of a drover dogbox.' (NZ Journal of Agriculture,45)



## shandygaffing
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a mixing of wet and dry sheep prior to shearing.

>  <b>May 10, 1933</b> The boss a bit anxious to keep the sheep up to the men, the showers had been frequent, but the carrying capacity of the shed, which held up to 3,000 sheep, supplemented by a good shandy-gaffing of the wet with the dry kept them going .. at this particular time, the shandy-gaffing had been carried out under fairly heavy bursts of rain. (NZ Worker,7)
