## shanghai
 
 <i>n.</i> in darts

>  <b>1989</b> <i>McGILL</i> <i>shanghai</i> a double/triple/bull in three darts. (Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,92)



 
 <i>n.</i> a child's catapult [from Scottish dialect shangy, a stick split at one end for putting on a dog's tail, a variant of Gaelic seangan]

>  <b>1972</b> <i>GEE</i> He made me shanghais and bows and arrows. (In My Father's Den,44)

>  <b>1982</b> <i>NEWBOLD</i> A few of the guys had made shanghais, and were beginning to fling stones and fencing staples around the camp. (Big Huey, The,212)

>  <b>Nov 6, 1982</b> The nearby bush close to the river also served as a happy hunting groung for games of cowboys and Indians, bird-nesting, or using "shanghais" - complete with lead pellets, made from the melted-down lining of tea chests - to startle the native pigeons. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),131)

>  <b>1961</b> <i>CRUMP</i> I asked the girlfriend if she wanted to come down to the tip with me the next day, shooting rats with shanghais. (Hang on a Minute, Mate,152)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>McLINTOCK</i> Some of our specially New Zealand words have curious and quite unexpected histories. For example, <i>shanghai</i>, a catapult, imported from Australia, proves to be a Highland Scottish word <i>shangie</i> for a forked stick used to keep a dog's tail down. (Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/679) [NOTES: Wall NZ Speech]

>  <b>1968</b> <i>SLATTER</i> Tank was renowned for his mighty deeds, for hitting Donnelly's bull fair on the wally-bar with a shanghai shot, ... for putting razor blades in his fly to stop other kids zipping him, for wringing younkers' necks and blowing up frogs. (Pagan Game, The,230)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>SUTTON-SMITH</i> The primary piece of equipment made with the pocket-knife was a shooter: a shanghai. Shanghais have been the all-time most popular improvised weapon of New Zealand boys. Occasionally they were known as catapults. (History of Children's Play,99)

>  <b>1897</b> <i>WILMOT</i> Andy knocked over a nice crow with his shanghai ... (Journal) [NOTES: 1897 Wilmot's Journal in 1950 Reed and Reed Farthest West 138]

>  <b>1898</b> <i>MORRIS</i> <i> Shanghai, n.</i> a catapult. Some say because used against Chinamen. The reason seems inadequate. (Austral English,410)

>  <b>1898</b> <i>Shang&#769;.hai&#769;.</i>(sh&abreve.ng&#769;.h&imacr.&#769;.),<i> n. [Add.] 2. </i>A forked stick with elastic band for throwing small stones, etc.; a catapult. (Merriam-Webster Third International,2031)

>  <b>1923</b> This species [red-fronted Parrakeet] ... still occurs far back in the great timbered areas, but is much more timid than in the old `shanghai' days. (NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/86) [NOTES: Myers]

>  <b>1884</b> `Rolls any cask, beats any carpet, flies any kite, uses any bows and arrows, or catapult, or shanghai, or plays at any game to the annoyance of any person in any public place.' (NZ Statutes) [NOTES: `Police Offences Act, New Zealand,' sec. 4, subsec. 23:]

>  <b>1957</b> <i>PASCOE</i> It has saved generations of robins from the shanghai of the small boy. (Mr Explorer Douglas) [NOTES: 1899 C. Douglas in Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas (1957) 272]

>  <b>1901</b> I caught a whisper of `Watch him while I get my shanghai,' ... (TrNZI,32/216) [NOTES: (Hutchinson)]

>  <b>1904</b> Mr. George Byers, of Stirling, wounded a cuckoo with his `shanghai' ... (TrNZI,36/129) [NOTES: Fulton]

>  <b>May 10, 1919</b> Alas! the small boy's shanghai spares nothing! (Quick March,35)

>  <b>1919</b> They were so tame that a boy with a `shanghai' could soon make a fair bag. (TrNZI,51/222) [NOTES: Philpott]

>  <b>Oct 10, 1921</b> In Wellington the scope for the `shanghai' is not so extensive, for public opinion ... is fiercely against catapults and similar things. (Quick March,25)

>  <b>1929</b> <i> ~ n.</i> a catapult.-shanghai'-shot' n. a short distance; a stone's throw. [Shanghai] (Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,10)

>  <b>1934</b> <i>LEE</i> We trapped birds that came to peck half-digested oats out of dung, played leap-frog, sailed round pools on planks, broke windows with the careless use of the shanghai. (Children of the Poor,145,1949 ed.)

>  <b>1941</b> <i>BAKER</i> Children prefer<i> shanghai</i> to catapult [as in Australia]. (NZ Slang,62)

>  <b>1949</b> <i>DAVIN</i> ... shang-eye (Roads from Home,135)

>  <b>1964</b> <i>SARGESON</i> shanghai: boy's catapult. (Collected Stories,303)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>~ n.</i> a boy's catapult; <i>v.tr.</i> to shoot with a catapult. (NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),624)

>  <b>1968</b> <i> shanghai ... n.</i> boy's catapult; <i>v.t</i>. shoot with a catapult. (NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),17)

>  <b>1975</b> <i>DAVIN</i> .. Mick felt in his pocket and pulled his shangeye out gently by the prong. (Breathing Spaces,18)

>  <b>1982</b> <i>shanghai ... 3. Austral. & N.Z.</i> to shoot with a catapult.<i> ~ n. 4. Austral. & N.Z.</i> a catapult. (Collins Concise English Dictionary,1060) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 702; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 446]]

>  <b>Oct 24, 1863</b> (Listener (New Zealand Listener),17, COL. 1)

>  <b>1901</b> Two small boys saw him [morepork] at the same time. I caught a whisper of `Watch him while I get my shanghai,' ... (TrNZI,33/216)

>  <b>May 2001</b> Phillpotts, in 1919, noted their decline: "They were so tame that a boy with a shanghai could soon make a fair bag; but now it would be difficult to get within gun range." (NZ Geographic,51/10)

 <i>v.</i> to hit or kill (birds etc.) with a shanghai

## shanty
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> a rough wooden hut or shack, often in the bush (See [cf. bush shanty](../B#bush-shanty))

>  <b>Dec 19, 1906</b> A TYPICAL NORTH ISLAND BUSH SHANTY. (Otago Witness,15) [NOTES: Photo Caption]

>  <b>Jan 12, 1985</b> Virtually every settlement in the youngcolony originally clustered around itstaverns - even if they were only tatteredcalico shanties. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

>  <b>1852</b> Kororarika is still the principal settlement, and contains about [296] twenty houses, ... and many shanties, besides tents. It is chiefly inhabited by the lowest order of vagabonds, mostly runaway sailors and convicts, and is appropriately named `Blackguard Beach'. (U.S. Exploring Expedition,1/295-296) [NOTES: 1840 Mar in 1852 Wilkes U.S. Exploring Expedition]

>  <b>1882</b> <i>HAY</i> There are shanties and shanties. It is necessary to explain. Primarily, in its Canadian and original sense, the term means a log-house - a hut made of rough squared logs, built up upon each other. Such log-huts are not common in this country, though they may be seen here and there. ... The native whare[e-grave] of thatch is quickly and easily raised, serves all requirements, and lasts for years ... A shanty here, is a name applied to almost any kind of nondescript erection, which would not come under the designation of [117] whare[e-grave], or be honoured by the ambitious title of house. Rough edifices of planking are the common form. a hut (cf <i>built a warre </i>Jan 6) (Brighter Britain,1/116)

>  <b>1947</b> <i>BEATTIE</i> He [the pioneer pastoralist] has built a domicile of some sort, be it of canvas, calico, bagging, sticks, ferntrees, grass, slabs, mud, clay, stone, or wattle and daub. He may call it various names according to its materials, but three names would not enter his head - i.e., crib, bach, or shack. He may call it a cabin, a shanty, a cottage, a warrie [whare], but probably he would use the commonest term of all - hut. (Early Runholding in Otago,38)

>  <b>1953</b> <i>REED</i> A shattered site having been selected near to running water, an advance party would be sent to clear the necessary space and build a `shanty' which, in the earlier days, served inclusively as dormitory, dining hall and cookhouse. 1953 <i>op.cit.</i> 142 (Mrs. Brown's account) On our first arrival at a new camp we generally lived in a nikau whare until my husband could split the palings and build a shanty for us; the men lived in another and larger shanty. (Story of the Kauri, The,130)

>  <b>Jan 13, 1851</b> Built a shanty at the creek. [He uses <i>warre</i> on Jan. 6] (Torlesse Papers,191,1958 ed.)

>  <b>1860</b> <i>RIDGEWAY</i> Why a `bushman' would run up a `settler's first home' at a tithe of the expense .... his trained and ready hand runs up his hut - `shanty', or whatever you like to call it. (Voices from Auckland,67)

>  <b>Mar 23, 1861</b> [Dunedin's] first shanties have given place to goodly stone edifices, ... (Otago Witness,5)

>  <b>Oct 15, 1912</b> At an inquest on Richard Benjamin Harris, who was found burnt to death after a fire in his shanty at Waitete on Sunday, the Coroner returned a verdict of accidental death. (Evening Post,8)

>  <b>Nov 29, 1862</b> Lowe left with sheep went to Lowes shanty. (Puketoi Station Diary)

>  <b>1864</b> ... two roomed wooden shanties fetch [a pound] per (Saturday Review,10/120) [NOTES: 1864-67 Saturday Review (Dunedin) X/120]

>  <b>1871</b> <i>MONEY</i> was much amused by a trio who arrived in the township and put up opposite my `shanty' (Knocking About in NZ,17)

>  <b>1873</b> <i>LADY BARKER</i> We reached the little shanty [i.e. bushman's log hut] (Station Amusements in NZ,20)

>  <b>1971</b> <i>HALL-JONES</i> ... he pulled up at a bush accommodation house, here called a shanty ... [116] ... made not less welcome the miserable `shanty' in which we took refuge (Mr Surveyor Thomson,115) [NOTES: 1876 visit to West Coast in 1971 Hall-Jones Mr Surveyor Thomson 115, 116 (Griffiths Collection)]

>  <b>1888</b> <i>D'AVIGDOR</i> I am writing in a little frail wooden shanty, pompously called the Otira Hold. (Antipodean Notes,134)

>  <b>1902</b> A group of what are termed `shanties' are erected [built with palings and roofed with shingles] (NZ Illustrated Magazine,5/372) [NOTES: (`Bush Life')]

>  <b>1920</b> <i>MANDER</i> Later on, Bruce and many other men built shanties and houses for themselves, ... (Story of a NZ River, The,59,1974 ed.)

>  <b>1925</b> <i>MANDER</i> He had now a dozen customers on the field, but in his ramblings he had never yet come upon a hut or shanty. (Allen Adair,53,1971 ed.)

>  <b>1931</b> <i>R. MASON</i> I can remember this use in Auckland district 1931-8. Old abandoned shanties in the Waitakeres were still called by that name then. (Personal Communication) [NOTES: ca1931-1938 R.Mason p.c.]

>  <b>1970</b> <i>SEVERINSEN</i> The night was spent at the Fohs [?] Hut, a rough, dark, musterers' shanty. (Hunt the Far Mountain,97)

>  <b>Jan 30, 1930</b> The tin shanty which was supposed to protect the locomotive used on haulage work from the ravages of rust and decay. (NZ Truth,1)

>  <b>Apr 8, 1899</b> The City Council's medical officer inspected and condemned no less than 36 shanties in one street. (West Coast Times,2)

>  <b>1957</b> <i>PARK</i> So they come into the Dunstan, one long street of tents and shanties. (One-a-pecker, Two-a-pecker,50)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> (obsolete) a small, wayside public house or inn, mainly unlicensed and often rough-and-ready; a grog-shop; a low-class ACCOMMODATION HOUSE (See [cf. grog-shanty](../G#grog-shanty))

He rises at half-past two a.m., and musters his cows, has to get them miked by seven o'clock, take his milk to the factory; and after that has to feed over 90 calves, and about thirty pigs. He has to provide root crops for his pigs, and see that he has a sufficient supply of hay, etc., for his cows in the winter, keep his fences in repair, and stump what ground he requires to grow his crops. There is no eight hours for that sharemilker. (Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

>  <b>1963</b> <i>BACON</i> <i>sharemilker</i>-One who contracts to milk a herd of cows for a share of profits. In general, sharemilkers fall into three categories: first, the 29 per cent sharemilker, second, the 39 per cent man, third, the 50 per cent man. The 29 per cent man contracts to milk the farmer's herd and attend to their wants only; he helps at haymaking, etc. as part of the herd's `wants', but in general, once the cows have been attended to for the two daily milkings, his time is his own. The 39 per cent man contracts to milk the herd owned by the farmer and to do all the other general farm work. For this he receives 39 per cent of the herd profits. The 50 per cent sharemilker runs his own herd of cows on another man's land. He does all the farm work, and receives 50 per cent of the profits. Many farmers who today have their own farms in New Zealand started off as 39 per cent share milkers, saved enough to buy their own herds and so became 50 per cent milkers, then saved again to purchase land themselves (or on which they put sharemilkers!) (In the Sticks,183)

Under this system the owner usually provides the land, plant, and herd, while the share-milker provides labour and receives in return one-third to one-half of the gross returns. In other cases the sharemilker also provides the dairy herd and receives two-thirds of the gross receipts. (NZ Journal of Science & Technology,24/231a)

>  <b>1974</b> [Hdg] The sharemilker represents the greater part of the experienced, stable farm labour that is available to the New Zealand dairy farmer. A sharemilking agreement allows men with little capital to share in a dairy farm's production and profits. (NZ Agriculture,88)

>  <b>1920</b> <i>POWDRELL</i> <i>Share-milking</i>. - The earliest form of this system grew out of the difficult problem of dairying labour. ... [9] ... share-milking is an annual contract in which the landowner provides the land, buildings, stock, and machinery, and the tenant all labour ... (Dairy Farming in NZ,8)

>  <b>1943</b> A feature of dairy-farming in New Zealand has been the development of share-milking, akin to the old French system of me[acute]tayage or the sharefarming common with annual crops such as cotton in the United states of America. Under this system the owner usually provides the land, plant, and herd, while the share-milker provides labour and receives in return one-third to one-half of the gross returns. In other cases the sharemilker also provides the dairy herd and receives two-thirds of the gross receipts. (NZ Journal of Science & Technology,24/231A)

>  <b>Mar 3, 1950</b> She's right!', said Miss Cooper [a Fulbright student], with a good Pig Islander's inflexion. (Listener (New Zealand Listener))

>  <b>Jan 30, 1963</b> Sir, - I read `The Dominion's' second editorial of Jauary 25, `Our `She'll-Be-Right' Attitude,' with interest, but as a Grim Dig I feel that it is my duty to point out to the younger generation the origin and meaning of the expression `she's right' `She's right' or `She'll-Be- Right' originated in the Army and was only used when the person using the saying was satisfied that he had done his particular job to the best of his ability and took pride in it. If, on the other hand, he had done the job to the best of his ability but he was not satisfied with the job, he used the phrase `She's not too good' or `She's pretty poor' Never was the phrase `She's right' used in the sense that politicians and various other people not in the know use it to refer to a job badly done or done with a `couldn't-care-less' attitude. This was never necessary because in the Army we had other phrases to cover such contingencies when things did not go according to plan, such as NAFU and SAFU, the first being a non-adjusting fiasco, and the second being a self-adjusting fiasco. To say the least of it, I feel strongly that it is disrespectful to the originators of the saying `She's right' to use it in the present accepted sense, and I feel also that all Grim Digs should rise up in righteous wrath, but `don't do your scone boys.' Belmont. INFANTEER. (Dominion,8)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>she's right</i>: popular term to say that everything will be alright in the end; e.g., `She'll be right mate, don't worry about it.' (NZ Police National Headquarters) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

>  <b>1988</b> <i>McGILL</i> right secure state philosophically important to traditional Kiwi person; I'll see you right reassurance that hospitality or a loan will be extended; she's right/she'll be right/she's jake/she's apples/she's sweet/too right all emphasising that all is secure and settled. NZA. (Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,92)

>  <b>2005</b> 'Get y'a beer?' 'Nah she's right thanks,' I say, giving my new full jug a nudge. (Huia 6: Contemp. Maori Fiction,29)

>  <b>Mar 18, 2003</b> The words he might have used, but didn't need to, are honoured shorthand on both sides of the Tasman: "She's right, mate."... So let's say to Bichel and to every Australian: "Good on ya, mate!" (Dominion Post,B4)

## shearing blast
 
 <i>n.</i> Shearing-blast may be of two kinds. True shearing-blast is caused by the comb of the shearing-machine actually damaging the surface of the skin. This defect is seen as numerous lines parallel to each other running in various directions on the skin. The other defect [in pelts] often described as shearing-blast is really due to sunburn.

Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. ## sheepholder
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1915</b> The owners of original bush and scrub areas ... are the most numerous sheepholders in the Dominion. (NZ Sheepfarming,31)

>  <b>1947</b> <i>BEATTIE</i> When I first read this inscription [in the Memorial Church, Cave], the word `sheep-men' made me involuntarily flinch. Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.' The word `sheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... [12] Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `runholder' was the most used, and it is the word that I think should be substituted. (Early Runholding in Otago,11)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sheep farmer [1800s.]

>  <b>Oct 1, 1877</b> I trust some scientific sheep-holder may be induced to take up this question. (NZ Country Journal,I iv  272)

 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to place breeding sheep and their statistics on a national record.

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a national record of specific sheep and their qualities for breeding.

>  <b>Jun 11, 1981</b> The sheep he has chosen have high Sheeplan breeding values ... (NZ Farmer,121)

>  <b>Jan 20, 1982</b> Sheeplan gives a ranking of rams on their likely productive value in important traits ... (Manawatu Farmer,5)

>  <b>Jul 1983</b> Their next logical step was to join Sheeplan, a scheme tailor-made for farmers interested in increasing the dollar return from their breeding enterprises ... Sheeplan is not a breeding plan, it's simply a means of identifying more productive individuals. The next decision rests on which 2-tooths should go onto Sheeplan from the lambing paddock. (NZ Journal of Agriculture,15)

>  <b>1994</b> <i>DAVIS</i> By 1976 the new scheme was up and running and was renamed Sheeplan. In 1985 after the scheme had become Sheeplan, there were 407,000 ewes of 30 different breeds recorded in 1,303 flocks. (Lab Coats to Gumboots,163)

## shellfish
 
 <i>n.</i> [An Australian lexicographer points out there is a difference between most dictionary definitions and what the public see as a shellfish; likewise in NZ the fishery regulations define for their convenience shellfish as including, from memory, crayfish, sponges and possibly even sea-grass. The sensible thing would be to redefine using as the basic definition the scientific one. The present OED definition is: Any animal living in water whose outer covering is a shell, whether testaceous, as an oyster, or crustaceous, as a crab. This wording is followed by Random House and Macquarie whereas the general public and scientists tend to think of a shellfish as a member of the class Mollusca, i.e. mostly animals with a hard calcareous shell or shells.]

## shepherd's hut
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Feb 12, 1853</b> We remember passing over this same spot in the first year of the Settlement, when a solitary shepherd's hut spoke of the habitation of man. (Otago Witness,2)

>  <b>1939</b> <i>BEATTIE</i> The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. In this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late 'fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.' <i>Ibid.</i> 12 . provisions became `rations' ... when served out to the man at the `shepherds' huts' (or out-stations). (First White Boy Born in Otago,11)

>  <b>Jul 30, 1920</b> At times during the four years of his wandering he had called at outlying station camps and shepherds' huts for food and clothing, and had been seen by others spearing and abstracting rabbits from their burrows with a pointed stick; but he had always managed to remain outside the reach of the law. (West Coast Gold Rushes,526)

(Bright Fine Gold,200)

>  <b>1986</b> <i>shicer n. NZ & Austral</i>. unproductive mine or claim; sl. swindler, cheat. [G <i>scheisser </i>contemptible person] -->b. (? hence) anything useless or worthless (NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,705) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

## shick
 
 <i>adj.</i> occas. abbrev. of SHICKER n and aj., often applied as a friendly term of address; in mod. >  <b>1987</b> <i>LOCKWOOD</i> Yiddish became a main source of <i>Rotwelsch</i> [the cant language of thieves, etc.] In the course of time a number of originally cant words of Hebrew provenance passed into general use in German, though tending to remain at a more or less substandard level. ## shickery
 
 <i>adj.</i> shaky; ricketty

(Daily Southern Cross,2)

## shilling
 
 <i>n.</i> to express a degree of intellectual or mental handicap, or eccentricity, on the part of the addressee on a rough scale based on 20 shillings = 1 pound; and graded from say 1/6 IN THE POUND, TWO SHILLINGS IN THE POUND (of low intelligence, highly eccentric) to say NINETEEN SHILLINGS (slightly abnormal or missing): PAY variant from horseracing betting the metaphor resembles those implying that the person is NOT ALL THERE, is MISSING see also BOB, QUID, SHILLING; small entry only at POUND (check)

 <i>n.</i> a piece of split (now also sawn) wood, usually rectangular used for roofing is general English (OED from 1200) but OED quotations (esp. in combinations) seem to have a provincial, and later a `colonial' flavour, although the sense does not occur in EDD. Certainly in early NZ, shingles were perhaps the commonest roofing material. British observers in the 19th century often feel obliged to explain the term. e.g.

>  <b>1777</b> <i>FORSTER</i> The latter [sc. argillaceous slate] is commonly found in great quantity, and broken pieces, on the sea beaches, and is what our seamen call shingle, by which name it is distinguished in the account of captain Cook's former voyage. (Voyage Round the World,1/204)

>  <b>1848</b> <i>WAKEFIELD</i> ... shingles, N.Z. [per] 1000, 6s. to 8s. ... whalebone [per] ton, 135l. to 140l. - finners, 40l. (Handbook for New Zealand, The,180)

## shingle face
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a steep slide of angular rock pieces on the side of a hill or mountain.

>  <b>Oct 22, 1896</b> I saw the black gorges, the grey shingle faces, the river with death in its blue foamy track, / And I said: "I'll be with you - we'll face it tomorrow, though it's odds on it, Allan, we never come back." (Otago Witness,41)

>  <b>1949</b> <i>NEWTON</i> .. the old hind, joined by two others, was sidling through a shingle face downwind. (High Country Days,142)

>  <b>1951</b> <i>MCLEOD</i> The same dog on a hot shingle face in mid-summer is likely to go and lie under a bush instead of climbing a thousand feet to hunt a dozen woollies through a bluff. (NZ High Country,45)

>  <b>Mar 23, 1967</b> The country above me was a great open shingle face ... (NZ Farmer,35)

>  <b>Apr 12, 2001</b> It [the property] also includes large areas of unproductive flats leading into rolling valleys and some steep shingle faces. (NZ Farmer,38)

## shingle fan
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a broad slope of loose angular stones that have been washed down by water action between hillsides. (See [fan](../F#fan))

>  <b>Jan 17, 1895</b> At 9 o'clock, after drying the things left on the shingle fan, we began to ascend the Tasman spur, and reached the Bivouac at 12.30 p.m., where we boiled the billy with some scrub that we had carried up, and had dinner. (Otago Witness,50)

>  <b>1971</b> <i>TEMPLE</i> .. snow covered the shingle fans of creeks. (Mantle of the Skies,76)

>  <b>1978</b> <i>BECKETT</i> shingle fan - slopes of loose shingle, generally brought by water action, very often tussock-covered. (Mountains of Erewhon, The,x)

>  <b>May 1994</b> When Mrs Scott declared a cook unnecessary, the hut was carted through the Tekapo township and Lilybank Station and across the Godley River to a new site on a high wide shingle fan. (NZ Historic Places,36)

>  <b>Jan 8, 1921</b> We pass shingle fans of all dimensions, landslides from the treacherous hills, gaily bubbling brooks showing green tracks down the tawny hillsides, and cosy hidden gullies where lurk the few trees, if one can call them trees, that grow up here. (Ashburton Guardian,5)

>  <b>Dec 18, 1936</b> Fan Creek, flowing west from Tauherenikau into the Tauherenikau River. Name suggested by the Tararua Tramping Club because of the shingle-fan at the mouth of the creek. (Evening Post,7)

>  <b>1879</b> <i>HAAST</i> For two miles more we kept along the eastern side of the valley, travelling mostly on the slopes of huge shingle-fans, ... (Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,131)

>  <b>1915</b> A number of introduced plants ... have made their appearance on the shingle-fan and in the river-beds ... (TrNZI,47/334)

>  <b>Sep 18, 1874</b> I have shown how in post-pliocene times from the material brought down by the enormous glacier torrents, forming huge shingle fans at the foot of the glaciers, two bars were thrown across the sea ... (Star, The,2)

>  <b>Jul 12, 1881</b> Across the Canterbury Plains, the Selwyn flows "along the depression between the two huge shingle fans formed by the Rakaia and Waimakariri, emptying itself into Lake Ellesmere, into which it has already advanced its delta considerably." (Star, The,3)

>  <b>Apr 9, 1903</b> Mr H. McLean wrote, re shingle fan in the dam paddock. (Ashburton Guardian,2)



## shingle flat
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1937</b> (NZ Alpine Journal,7/24/57) [NOTES: [see quot. bush-hiking]]

## shingle gut
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a narrow vertical stony pass in steep grazing country.

## shingle heap
 
 <i>n.</i> shingle slip

>  <b>Nov 14, 1906</b> What were a few years ago rich level fields, on which cattle and sheep browsed knee deep in succulent clover and grasses, are now, Mr Mackenzie said, waste desserts of great barren shingle heaps. (Otago Witness,26)

>  <b>1864</b> <i>HOOKER</i> Shingle heaps on the alps (Handbook NZ Flora,142) [NOTES: R.Mason's note: `Sinclair, Travers, Haast ...? or Hooker's term?]]

 <i>n.</i>

## shingle pit
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a quarry from where sharp stone fragments are taken for use in building tracks or roads.

>  <b>1999</b> <i>MUDGWAY</i> The same creek, a short distance up Argyle Road, had once been a shingle pit. (125 Years Off the Beaten Track,204)

>  <b>May 8, 1874</b> .. and in the principal streets where no asphalt has yet been laid the City Council have caused a quantity of the metal screenings obtained from the Lincoln road shingle pits to be spread. (Star, The,2)

 <i>n.</i>

(Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

 <i>n.</i> a plant which grows on shingle slips

Wall Alpine and Sub-Alpine Flora in Natural History of Canterbury 151 ...]

 <i>n.</i>

## shingle shooting
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the killing of several ducks or geese at once, by firing a bullet into shingle.

## shingle short, a
 
 <i>phr.</i> . [aka a shingle off, a shingle loose. 1953 16 M A33 Thames DHS 2 SHINGLE SHORT (with variations) `a screw loose' perhaps deriving from <i>have a tile loose</i>, with shingle a metaphor for head or hair (cf thatch); or from be a bit short, missing on top; to be not all there (on top)] (See [take a shingle off](../T#take-a-shingle-off))

>  <b>Jun 13, 1889</b> A man would have been thought a shingle short if he had said 15 or 20 years ago that the present reapers and binders would be invented ... (Otago Witness,34)

>  <b>Dec 2, 1901</b> The same member of the Board, later on, speaking of another tenant, said that after a conversation of half an hour's duration with the tenant the conviction came to him that "the tenant should have been a shingle-splitter instead of a selector - for he was a shingle short!" (Wanganui Herald,2)

>  <b>Jul 3, 1876</b> Fool, idiot, lunatic, daft, "shingle short,' are easily said. (North Otago Times,2)

>  <b>May 17, 1876</b> Is the man sane who wrote it, or has he a shingle off, or does he suffer from some severe hallucination of the brain? (Grey River Argus,2)

(Manawatu Standard,2)

>  <b>Oct 15, 1861</b> .. in short it was his firm opinion that Maitai himself could not be held responsible for his actions; and he should very soon begin to think that those who advanced him money were, in vulgar parlance 'a shingle short.' (Colonist, The,2)

>  <b>Nov 29, 1941</b> No, Melisande, Sancho Panza is not the patron saint of the German talk divisions. He rode an ass and his master, Don Quixote, a sorry steed, but although the Don was a shingle short and tilted at windmills, he was a kind-hearted, chivalrous gentleman, which is more than can be said of the Nazi panzer commanders. (Evening Post,8)

>  <b>1865</b> Screws loose in the head are rivetted. Shingles off are fixed. (Punch in Canterbury,73)

>  <b>1865</b> We think there are more shingles loose than he speaks of (Punch in Canterbury,7/24)

>  <b>1899</b> <i>GRACE</i> I smiled, and ranked him [an eccentric major] a shingle short. (Sketch of the NZ War,22)

>  <b>1968</b> <i>18</i> <i>shingle short, to be a v.</i>not completely balanced mentally. (NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins))

>  <b>1868</b> <i>LYTTELTON</i> Mr. Acland used an odd colonial phrase for a half-witted person: `shingle-short' Wooden shingles being used, like wooden church-spires in Kent and Sussex, for house-roofs, it means, weak in the head. (Two Lectures,34)

>  <b>1891</b> <i>COTTLE</i> He was a `shingle short' without doubt (Frank Melton's Luck,6)

>  <b>1908</b> <i>BAUGHAN</i> <i>Shingle-short</i>: Australasian for `a tile loose.' <i>Anglice</i>: Wanting in intellect. Aj. (Shingle-Short,11)

>  <b>Apr 16, 1910</b> His Worship: `Was the accused sober?' Witness: `Well, he looked muzzy.' His Worship: `What do you mean by that?' Witness: `He looked either drunk or a shingle short.' >  <b>Sep 1985</b> Back on that first day mustering down to the hut, he got lost and tried to come down a shingle slide. (NZ Journal of Agriculture,43)

(Ashburton Guardian,3)

>  <b>1952</b> <i>THOMSON</i> Where bush and tussock had grown before, bare and barren shingle slides began to fan out. <i>Ibid.</i> 81 Higher up the valley it [the track] petered out completely for several miles, because of the many large shingle slides. (Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,15)

>  <b>1958</b> A term used in New Zealand for steep mountain sides covered with loose, sliding stones, in England called `screes' (Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),365)

>  <b>Apr 21, 1928</b> The result is that the sides of the stream are merely shingle slides, and the former series of deep holes and strong ripples is merely a chain of shingle bars. (Evening Post,17)



## shingle slip
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a steep slide of running scree or loose stones [usually on high mountain or hill country. ]

>  <b>Jun 2, 1855</b> Turning a little along the ridge to the left, we descended a steep shingle slip of some 300 or 400 feet, and following down a gully with loose stones, alpine plants, and finally black birch, found ourselves, by about four, p.m., on the S.E side of the range, and to our joy, once more upon the banks of the East Wairau, which here pierces right through the mountains, and leads directly to our camp of the morning. (Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

>  <b>Aug 26, 1895</b> The runs on [t]he east side of Lake Tekapo are [s]till practically wholly white, the only contrasts being shingle slips, new slips and wind-swept rocks. (North Otago Times,1)

>  <b>1873</b> <i>BARKER</i> .. a deep drift of snow still lingered, filling up a furrow made in former years by a shingle-slip. (Station Amusements in NZ,82)

>  <b>Jan 20, 1919</b> .. the sub-alpine shingle-slips have increased in size. (NZ Journal of Agriculture,6)

>  <b>1920</b> <i>MCCASKILL</i> Do not burn on greywacke mountains in the vicinity of shingle-slips or where the soil is hallow and slips are already made. (Hold This Land,151,(1973) ed.) [NOTES: Report App. House Reps]

## shinplaster
 
 <i>n.</i> (See [see also Southland shinplasters](../S#see-also-southland-shinplasters))

(Otago Witness,14)

>  <b>Jun 29, 1850</b> Depend upon it, fellow colonists, if they could not keep their mercurial fingers off the sacred fund of the widows and orphans, they will have small respect for those provisions of the Colonial Ordinance which professedly provide a security for the payment of the shin plasters. (Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,69)

>  <b>Apr 19, 1895</b> He hurled denunciations at the head of Sir John in particular, and the Stock Exchange in general, and in heroic language declared that New Zealand was a self-reliant, non-borrowing colony, and that Sir John and the Stock Exchange could depart for Sheol forthwith, and that he and Seddon and M'Kenzie could run the show by the aid of Consols, Postal notes, and shin plasters of a variety of patterns till further orders, and be d--d to him. (Evening Post,4)

The Government debentures were for 5s, but the private ones were for sums ranging down as low as 3d. (Otago Daily Times,17)

>  <b>Jun 27, 1925</b> But these war advances we got from J.B. were, perhaps, part of the shin plaster J.B. borrowed from Uncle Sam, and Downie Stewart may have learned from U.S.'s pawnbrokers exactly how England funded her huge war debt with them. (NZ Truth,5)

>  <b>Dec 18, 1935</b> And Sir Samuel/Hoare - he goes / With shin plaster / On his nose ... (Evening Post,8)

>  <b>1871</b> <i>JOSEPH MASTERS</i> Many tradesmen [in the early 1840s] had to make their own money on strips of paper called by the settlers `shin plaisters'. Governor Grey [sic] established a bank issue and issued one pound promisery [sic] notes, to get change for one of these, you would get a hat full of shin plaisters. (Autobiography,26)

>  <b>1910</b> <i>MACDONALD</i> I do not know exactly how wholesale mercantile business was carried on, but the retail business in the town [?Wellington] was carried on [c1840s] mostly by means of little bits of printed paper, issued by shopkeepers, for from one penny to two or three shillings. This currency went by the general name of `shin plaster'. <i>Ibid.</i> 117 When eggs fell from six silver shillings per dozen to one shilling of `shin plasters', the Hutt, Porirua Road and Karori settlers looked anxious. (Reminiscences,109) [NOTES: c1840s in c1910 Macdonald Reminiscences (TS:VUW) 109]

>  <b>1941</b> <i>SUTHERLAND</i> <i>Shinplasters</i>.- The fact that private traders found it necessary themselves, to issue paper notes in denominations below five shillings suggests that at the outset ... the Fitzroy notes were not issued for values below five shillings. The private paper notes were issued for small change, redeemable mostly in `Five Shillings, in Government debentures.' Both the debentures and the private notes were issued on poor paper, and soon became known as `Government Rags' and `Shinplasters' respectively. The term `Shinplaster' for paper money appears to have come to New Zealand from America, via New South Wales. *[fn] In the latter Colony the issue of paper money of a denomination lower than twenty shillings was prohibited in 1826 to promote the circulation of sterling instead of a colonial currency, and the prohibition was welcomed by the people as `preventing the Colony being inundated with beggarly rags' and dollar and half-dollar notes `used often as a paltry contrivance to evade payment of debt,' <i>vide "The Australian," </i>19 July 1826. [fn] Various reasons have been given for the origin of this curious term for paper money issued in the forties. The most likely explanation comes from America (p. 650 <i>The Numismatist,</i> 1938), where it is stated that in the good old days post-boys and out-riders, wearing high boots, were required, at times, to pay toll-fees at toll-gates, and in order to facilitate progress they placed paper money or coins in bags in their boot-tops, against their shins - hence the term `shin-plaster.' (Numismatic History of NZ,158)

>  <b>1972</b> <i>HARGREAVES</i> The [Governor Fitzroy's (1844)] Debentures, popularly known as `government rags', were given various nicknames such as<i> assignats,</i> `shinplasters', and `flash notes'. All these terms had reference to worthless paper money, some of which had been issued in the past. <i>Assignats</i> was the name given to large amounts of paper money issued in France during the French Revolution, but which depreciated to such as extent to be almost worthless. `Shinplasters' - sometimes written `skinplasters' - had its origin in North America, and again referred to depreciated paper money, while `flash notes' was a popular term in use for any counterfeit money or worthless forged paper money. (From Beads to Banknotes,40)

>  <b>1961</b> <i>CRUMP</i> He'd probably never miss the Old Girl if he shot through on her. <i>Ibid.</i> 190 What'd y' do, Sam? Shoot through on `im? (Hang on a Minute, Mate,11)

>  <b>1963</b> <i>DUCKWORTH</i> `Why are you home, anyway? I thought you had a job up north?' He shrugged. `Did have. Bob's shot through on me'. `What?' He was using expressions picked up from Bob [an Australian] and I wasn't sure of their meaning. (Barbarous Tongue, A,158)

>  <b>1965</b> <i>WATSON</i> to desert ... that's what I come [sic] all the way up here for, to get me old mate Tommy, he wouldn't shoot through on a man. (Stand in the Rain,57)

## shooter
 
 <i>n.</i> a marble

>  <b>1972</b> <i>SUTTON-SMITH</i> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. (Folkgames of Children,174)



## shooting block
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an area of bush or back-country allocated to hunters and cullers by the Forestry Service.

>  <b>1952</b> <i>THOMSON</i> Ron, the packman, left us early next morning to continue packing other parties to their shooting blocks. (Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,70)

>  <b>1964</b> <i>THOMSON</i> ... they wouldn't unduly interefere with our shooting block, otherwise I was to send them 'down the track.' (Deer Shooting Days,81)

>  <b>1996</b> <i>HOLDEN</i> .. he had found himself turning increasingly to the wilderness as an alternative means of making a living - possum hunting in the winter and transporting hunters in his boats to the various 'shooting blocks' across the lake at almost any time of the year. (Great Hunting Yarns,70)

These are the black stilt, now limited to a few pairs nesting on high ground in the centre of the South Island; the shore plover, confined entirely to a small island off the Chathams, where its numbers are fairly strong; and the New Zealand dotterel, red-breasted in summer, rather curiously nesting in two discrete groups, one in the Hauraki Gulf, the other far away at and around Stewart Island. (House Above the Sea,181)

>  <b>1897</b> <i>Thinornis novae-zealandiae</i>, Gmelin. (New Zealand Shore-plover.) ... I observed the young of the above rare species ... obtained at the mouth of the Ccargill River [Southland]. (TrNZI,29/191) [NOTES: (Buller)]

>  <b>Nov 2002</b> The secret and quirky behaviour of the endangered New Zealand shore plover has been internationally exposed by a DOC officer involved with their recovery on the Chatham islands. (Footnotes,No. 18/2)

>  <b>Jun 2008</b> Shore plover occurred throughout New Zealand until the mid-1800s. Introduced predators wiped them out on mainland New Zealand, and they were reduced to about 130 birds on Rangatira (South East) Island in the Chatham Islands. (Footnotes,11)

## shore-party
 
 <i>n.</i> a party engaged in shore whaling; operating from a shore whaling station, not from a mother ship

>  <b>Jan 25, 1850</b> In recent numbers we have reported the arrivals of several whalers in the northern ports; who, we are glad to learn, have been very successful in their operations off our coasts. We are also gratified to find that several shore parties on the east coast have been equally fortunate. (Daily Southern Cross,3)

>  <b>Nov 1831</b> <i>BELL</i> The black whale fishery was tried in New Zealand some years ago, but it was abandoned until last year, when it was renewed by one vessel and two shore parties from Sydney, and one vessel from Hobart Town. (Letter) [NOTES: 1831 Nov Bell Letter in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 3]

>  <b>Nov 1831</b> <i>BELL</i> If the fishing is to be carried on by a shore party, the try pots and huts are erected on the beach ... The boats are sent out at daylight every morning, and when ... they kill a fish it is towed ashore and flinched and boiled upon the beach. (Letter) [NOTES: 1831 Nov Bell Letter in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 9]

>  <b>Apr 28, 1836</b> <i>CAPT. JOY</i> ... it was told to me by our toungers [sic, at Cloudy Bay] that the cost [of a shore-hut] was trifling. ... Indian Cunning was plainly to be seen and as far as regards White men I fear their honesty will prove Something Equivocal. (Log of Mary Mitchell) [NOTES: 1836 Apr 28 Capt. Joy Log of <i>Mary Mitchell</i> in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 435, 436]

## short head
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a dog trial event for heading dogs.

>  <b>Dec 15, 1983</b> Short head and yard - Standard dog trial event. (NZ Journal of Agriculture,45)

>  <b>1987</b> <i>HALL</i> With the heading events there is a long pull and a short head and yard .. (Shepherd's Year, A,59)

>  <b>Feb 24, 2000</b> Locals Bernard Murphy and Gold won the long head and Ken Lobb and Star took out the short head and yard. (Taranaki Daily News,20)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an area or course over which the short head trial for heading dogs is held.

>  <b>Sep 27, 1973</b> I remember hearing a liberator at Rotorua on the short head telling me about the run-outs of all the dogs while he was putting the sheep out on the mark. (NZ Farmer,71)

>  <b>1993</b> <i>THOMSON</i> Today the short head has a razorback ridge for the head and awkward broken papa country to pull on. (Taranaki Dog Trialing,6)



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) [heading dogs] to stop closely on the shoulder of a mob of sheep with inadequate control of the whole mob.

>  <b>1927</b> <i>WHYTE</i> It is fault for a dog to short-head his sheep i.e. not go sufficiently round, but to stop on the shoulder. (Sheep-Dog, The,44)

>  <b>1964</b> <i>MILLS ET AL</i> If Boy stops to the right of this line he is said to have 'short-headed' .. From a distance it is often difficult to be sure if a dog has stopped on the point of balance, or overrun his head, or has short-headed .. by shortheading he leaves the other side - the escape side - wide open. (Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,36)

## short tussock
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Nov 2003</b> Less grand and altogether less fortunate are the short tussocks. Growing up to half a metre in height, they include such hardy species as blue tussock (<i>Poa colensoi</i>), silver tussock (<i>P. cita</i>) and hard, or fescue, tussock (<i>Festuca novaezelandiae</i>. With a penchant for lower country, short tussocks have had to compete over the last 200 years with the runholder's arsenal of fire, exotic grases and grazing stock, and also wih the runholder's enemies - weeds and rabbits. [29] While the grass family is most likely to have originated in South America, our short tussocks appear to have arisen from ancestors that moved to, and diversified in, the northern hemisphere and then trickled back south. ... Short tussocks migrated up-slope from dry valley bottoms to meet them. (NZ Geographic,No. 66/28)

>  <b>Nov 2003</b> Less grand and altogether less fortunate are the short tussocks. (NZ Geographic,No. 66/28)

 <i>adj.</i> NZ colloquial usage follows US and earlier British usage in assigning a main sense of `ill, unwell, ailing' to this word, esp. in the phrase <i>be sick </i>; contrast modern British usage with main sense `vomit'. That is, NZ usage follows OED a. I 1. Suffering from illness of any kind; ill, unwell, ailing. Now chiefly literary and U.S. [9-19c]. rather than 2. Having an inclination to vomit, or being actually in the condition of vomiting [18-20c]. An ambiguous statement, e.g., `I was sick on Thursday' would usually be interpreted in NZ as `I was ill' etc; in Britain probably as `I vomited etc' (Dr. R. Savage); and this can lead to some immediately horrifying images for Englishmen in N.Z., needing quick reshuffling to extract the correct sense: e.g., I was sick in bed last Thursday. Unambiguous statements naturally assign themselves appropriate senses, mainly on aspectual grounds: I was sick twice before breakfast; I have been sick for months. `Ill' is often used in NZ by, e.g. mothers and nurses, as a euphemism for the `vomit' sense: Little Tommy has just been ill all over his shoes. (When used as a verb, sick is always `vomit': N.Coghill and C. Tolkien have an interesting note to l.71 of their edition of Chaucer's <i>The Nun's Priest's Tale </i> (Harrap pp 94-5). l. 71 Repleccioun [overeating] re made hire nevere sick `sick': `ill', not `sick'. The withering away of the old sense of sick is relatively recent, and has not taken place in America; cf also <i>sickbay, sickroom, a sick man,</i> etc. Chaucer knew the word <i>ill, but for him it was a word characteristic of the North and East of England (it was of Scandinavian origin), and he only used it to give an impression of dialect in the talk of John and Aleyn, the Two Cambridge students from the North of England in the Reeve's Tale; for them, in any case, it meant `bad, evil'. Chaucer's word for being sick (in our sense) was <i>spew</i>.'

>  <b>1937</b> <i>MARSH</i> ... and I must say he did look a bit sick. (Vintage Murder,96)

## sidle
 
 <i>n.</i> an act of sidling; a track that runs at an angle across a slope. [ca1953 R. Mason e.g. make a high sidle to avoid the bluffs, or a broken ridge.]

>  <b>1960</b> <i>PASCOE</i> When the Whitcombe River is in flood there are many such whirlpools which the usual route avoids by a high steep sidle in the thick bush. (Over the Whitcombe Pass,33fn) [NOTES: 1863 Lauper in 1960 Pascoe (ed) Over the Whitcombe Pass 33 fn]

>  <b>2008</b> Near the head of the creek, the track climbs over a saddle of regenerating forest to begin a sidle towards Kaitoke... (NZ Geographic,94/30)



 
 <i>v.</i> to negotiable a steep slope of a hill by going round the side of it rather than straight up to the crest. (probably a back form from SIDELING.)

>  <b>Sep 1958</b> To <i>sidle </i>, to go around the side or across the face of a hill, is a characteristic New Zealand expression, strange to the Englishman or Australian. The example of 1821 in O.E.D.: `Ye know the footpath sidles down the hill', suggests that something of the New Zealand meaning was not unknown in England, but it cannot have been well known, or mountaineers would not have started to use <i>traverse </i>, both as a noun and as a verb, towards the end of last century. <i>Sidle </i> is well known among high-country musterers. As it is a word most likely to be used in open hilly or mountainous country, one may guess that musterers and up-country people gave it currency, whence it was adopted by mountain club people. If ski-ing had not brought its more or less international vocabulary with it we should no doubt be sidling slopes, on skis, that we now traverse... From 1936 to 1938 in <i>The Tramper </i> there are a number of references to `sidling tracks' and `sidling routes'. Towards the end of 1938 comes `after sidling round the head of the said stream', and, a year later, `we sidle the top of Three Johns', and from then on the verb flourishes. In 1940 comes `on a long sidle', and from then on the noun is as common as the verb. <i>Ibid.</i> 41 From the top basin we sidled up tiresome scree, ... and at last emerged on the top of the divide. (Tararua,29) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail']

>  <b>Aug 18, 1862</b> Often, with back bent low, he must thread [sic] the dirty overgrown bed of a steep little watercourse, or, still with back bent, sidle along the muddy slope of a steep hill, through a tunnel in the koromiko copse; or, straightening his back with a sigh of relief as he emerges on the open shingle-bed, find that he has to ford and ford again and again the cold rapid stream, slipping ahd splashing over weed-covered stones. (Daily Southern Cross,3)

>  <b>Jun 2, 1855</b> A few blows with the tomahawk, a fire-stick judiciously employed, and, should the brook be high, a little sidling over a low bank or two, is the most that can be needed, though the gorge being very narrow, its aspect may at first appear discouraging for a mile or two. (Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

>  <b>Oct 3, 1894</b> We sidled along the spurs, slipping and stumbling over the steep, wet, frozen, stony ground, for three of four miles, which seemed interminable, there the river Mataura approaches the hills, and made our course more westerly; a little further on we crossed the Otamita, a mountain stream, that came rushing out from between the hills, with a clear stony bottom. (North Otago Times,1)

>  <b>Sep 6, 1905</b> Come and let us sidle up thes bonnie brae and ha'e a look roond. (Otago Witness,86)

>  <b>Sep 6, 1905</b> Come and let us sidle up this bonnie brae and ha'e a look roond. (Otago Witness,86)

>  <b>1956</b> <i>BLAIR</i> There was heavy snow as we sidled along above Bealey gully. ... and carelessly sticking to the ridge I carelessly continued sidling. (Life & Work at Canterbury Agricultural College,83) [NOTES: (1926 Hilgendorf in) 1956 Blair Life and Work at Canterbury Agricultural College 83]

>  <b>1933</b> To work one's way round, up or down a facing by an easy grade. Usually sidle out, sidle round etc. (Press, The) [NOTES: Acland]

>  <b>1933</b> <i>JONES</i> .... sheer precipice for thousands of feet. One could not sidle round in mustering, but had to go under or over the top. (Autobiography,82)

>  <b>Jan 27, 1934</b> <i>Sidle </i>.-To work one's way round, up, or down a facing by an easy grade. Usually <i>s. out, s. round,</i> etc (Press, The,15)

>  <b>1949</b> <i>NEWTON</i> Sidling to a handy shoulder, he scanned the basin ahead. (High Alps of NZ,30)

>  <b>Oct 1950</b> (NZ Journal of Agriculture,295/1)

>  <b>1952</b> <i>THOMPSON</i> We then sidled for a few miles on a slight uphill grade until we reached a long sloping spur. 1952 <i>Ibid</i>. 55 ... Errol and I ... then sidled round the cliffs until we reached the basin at the head of the stream. (Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,42)

>  <b>1953</b> <i>R. MASON</i> `To go around the side of; to go along a hill-side. (tramping.) To sidle a hill; to sidle along a valley (not on the ridge, not on the valley floor, but along the hillside.) In common use among trampers. The term was not understood by Dr. I.V. Newman, lecturer in Botany, V.U.C., an Australian.' (Personal Communication)

>  <b>1953</b> <i>STRONACH</i> Most of the Clarence block is `sidled'. That is to say, the spurs are so big that it is necessary to have several men sidling on the `face' or side of each spur. I have seen as many as ten men on a face sidling along about half a mile apart. The man on the top beat, in all but exceptional circumstances, keeps a little in front, and each man down the face is a little behind the man above. (Musterer on Molesworth,23)

## Silent Army
 
 <i>n.</i> the NZ armed forces in WW1 (See [also Silent Division](../A#also-silent-division))

>  <b>1946</b> <i>SOLJAK</i> But even in his lighter moods the New Zealander reflects the dour outlook of his Scottish forbears [sic], a characteristic which in 1914-1918 won for Dominion forces the name of `the silent army.' (New Zealand (various authors/titles),85)



## Silent Division
 
 <i>n.</i> [1917-18 Dial Sights (250 NFA) The Silent Division. -->[cf also Ormond Burton's book-title?]] (See [also Silent Army](../A#also-silent-army))

>  <b>1921</b> <i>STEWART</i> With a highly developed esprit de corps, the troops generally impressed the outsider as stern dour and grim. On the march the cheerful and spontaneous gaiety of the English regiments was conspicuous by its absence. The undemonstrative reception of battalions returning after notable achievements suggested to an English observer the not inapt name of `The Silent Division'. (NZ Division,616)

>  <b>Mar 1921</b> On the march the New Zealanders never sang: the Australians scarcely stopped singing. But the men of `The Silent Division' had at times a wistful sense of loss. (Quick March,15)

>  <b>1936</b> <i>TREADWELL</i> In France the New Zealand troops were always known as the Silent Division because of their disinclination to sing on the march ... (Recollections of an Amateur Soldier,21)

>  <b>1984</b> <i>PUGSLEY</i> `Silent' is the word invariably used with New Zealanders - in France the New Zealand Division was called `The Silent Division.' Not for them the singing to and fro from the trenches. In appearance and speech they displayed `a peculiar inhibition, seeking as it were, to avoid all distinction.' (Gallipoli: the New Zealand Story,23)

>  <b>Feb 27, 1919</b> News of the armistice was received so quietly by the New Zealanders in France that as a result they have been nicknamed the Silent Division. (Grey River Argus,2)



## silent migration
 
 <i>n.</i> the post-WW2 migration of Maori to the cities

>  <b>Dec 29, 2001</b> The title of this book, <i>The Silent Migration</i> sounds a bit solemn as if it's going to he a serious sociological treatise on the urbanisation of the Maori. (Dominion Weekend Magazine,7)

>  <b>Nov 10, 2001</b> Two weeks before the publication of <i>The Silent Migration</i>, a magnificent new book that recalls the great urban migration of Maori in the middle of the 20th century, Agnes "Bubs" Broughton had a stroke... <i>The Silent Migration</i> maps the journeys of young Maori from rural villages to a "sea of Pakeha faces." (Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)



## silent policeman
 
 <i>n.</i> a judder bar (cf. British sleeping policeman)

>  <b>1971</b> <i>WATT</i> In June, 1925, the council had erected what was known as a `silent policeman' at the intersection of Dee and Esk Streets. On August 13, 1936, the council decided it should be replaced by a dome and centre line. The inspector said the `silent policeman' had been the means of training motorists to keep to the left of the centre line. (Centenary of Invercargill,70)

>  <b>Feb 2, 1920</b> An American system of directing traffic at street intersections, known as "the silent policeman," is to be given a trial by the Hamilton Borough Council. At a recent meeting Mr H. H. Howden, who has just returned from America, said that domes, about five inches high and 15 inches in diameter, were used in the principal cities of America as a guide to those likely to cut the corner. (Ashburton Guardian,4)

>  <b>Dec 17, 1935</b> The bylaws committee reported that as "silent policemen" were recognised as out of date, it preferred to use painted white discs. (Evening Post,7)

## silver beech
 
 <i>n.</i> <i>Nothofagus menziesii</i>, often popularly and locally called silver birch, a variety of native beech found mainly in rainy areas.

>  <b>1902</b> Silver-beech and entire-leaved beech are found as far south as Preservation Inlet and the Tautuku Forest, while the mountain-beech prefers higher levels, ... (Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,120)

>  <b>1908</b> [Silver-beech] (AJHR) [NOTES: (And) Report on a Botanical Survey of the Tongariro National Park]

>  <b>1909</b> [silver-b] (AJHR,C-11) [NOTES: Botanical Examination of the Higher Waimarino District]

>  <b>1918</b> <i>Fagus Menziesii.</i> - The commonest name of this tree is `silver-birch,' but it is often called `brown-birch,' `red-birch,' and `white-birch' in different localities. >  <b>1936</b> The chief indigenous trees of commercial value are: Kauri (<i>Agathis Australis</i>), Kahikatea or white pine ... red and hard beech (<i>Nothofagus fusca</i> and <i>Nothofagus truncata</i>), silver beech (<i>Nothofagus Menziesii</i>), black beech (<i>Nothofagus Solandri</i>) ... >  <b>1973</b> <i>MARK & ADAMS</i> Usually it is silver beech <i>Nothofagus menziesii</i> with small toothed leaves but in the drier areas, especially Canterbury, eastern Nelson and Marlborough in the South Island and on the highly porous soils of the volcanic plateau in the North Island, silver beech is replaced by mountain beech with small, smoothed-edged leaves. ## silvery
 
 <i>adj.</i> ?holding

>  <b>Sep 15, 1906</b> If they are `silvery' they will walk out again; if `stiff' they will work a week or two to get a few shillings to take them on the road again, ... (NZ Truth,65/3/6)



 
 <i>adj.</i> as a descriptive epithet in the names of plants and animals see cotton plant; grass, hair; oarfish; grass, sand; tauhinu,



 
 <i>n.</i> cucumber smelt (See [cf. whitebait](../W#whitebait))

>  <b>1940</b> <i>PHILLIPPS</i> NEW ZEALAND SMELT <i>Retropinna retropinna</i> Richardson. ... The smelt is the cucumber fish of some localities and the silvery of others. <i>Ibid.</i> 54 In some other localities these young [smelt,<i> Retropinna</i>] are called tuarenga. The half-grown fish is termed tikihemi and the adult paraki. Certain races of fish have a broad silvery band running along the side; hence the term `silvery.' It is to be regretted that in Canterbury the term smelt is still used to apply to the minnow, <i>Galaxias attenuatus</i>. (Fishes NZ,53)

>  <b>1940</b> <i>STUDHOLME</i> When the silveries (cucumber smelts) were running up the [Canterbury] rivers in the spring of the year, Maoris would catch huge quantities of them in nets. <i>Ibid.</i> 236 Enunga[sic] Smelts (mature whitebait) and silveries (Cucumber smelts). (Te Waimate,22)

>  <b>1986</b> <i>PAUL</i> <i>Common smelt Retropinna retropinna</i> Also called silvery, estuarine smelt, or cucumber (from the smell of freshly caught fish). Silvery, particularly along the sides. (NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,49)

>  <b>Feb 15, 1905</b> "A novel sight was witnessed in the north branch of the Waimakariri, near the railway bridge, last week, when for a chain in length and width a shoal of silveries were [sic] seen making their escape from a shoal of trout. .." (Otago Witness,59)

>  <b>Jan 16, 1890</b> The silveries were little fish about 6in long, but the herrings were of a good size, some weighing 1/2lb, and they had very silvery scales which flashed in the morning sunlight like polished metal. (Otago Witness,30)

>  <b>Mar 3, 1882</b> The fact demonstrates that the New Zealand waters are peculiarly adopted [sic] for the production of fine fish; and no doubt one reason for this is the superabundance of silveries in some of the streams. (Grey River Argus,2)

>  <b>1925</b> <i>Vernacular Name.</i>- Powell [TrNZI 2/84] was the first to point out that two fish were referred to as `smelt' in north Canterbury. These were <i>Galaxias attenuatus </i> and <i> Retropinna retropinna</i>. At present Canterbury residents refer to </> R. retropinna</i> as `silvery,' on account of the silver line running along the side of the half-grown fish. Maoris refer to this `silvery' as `tikihemi,' and to the adult as `paraki.' (NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/291) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

>  <b>1927</b> <i>SPEIGHT</i> The Silverside (<i>Argentina elongata</i>) is another common marine member of the order, while the smelt or silvery (<i>Retropinna retropinna</i>) lives partly or mainly in the rivers (Natural History of Canterbury,195) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 195]

>  <b>1937</b> <i>BUICK</i> Then there came [up the Waitaki] what from its bright appearance was known as the `silvery' (<i>Argentina retropinna</i>), and, from its odour when young, as the `cucumber' smelt. (Moa-Hunters of NZ,174)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>WILSON</i> SMELT A common little fish often confused with - and caught with - whitebait. He is the bitter, silver fellow the sharp-eyed whitebaiter discards from his nets. Smells like cucumber, hence one of his other names Cucumber-fish. Also called Silvery. ... Several types of smelt occur around New Zealand - Canterbury, Chatham Islands, Rotorua, Sea Foam, Southland and Stokell's - but it takes a real expert to tell them apart. <i>Ibid.</i>288 SILVERY The bane of professional whitebaiters. This small, silver fellow is usually removed by hand from the catch when he appears not so much because he doesn't taste good but because he looks like a `foreigner'. The Silvery is the young of the smelt ... (Fisherman's Bible,208)

>  <b>1956</b> <i>GRAHAM</i> SMELT (PARAKI) <i>Retropinna retropinna</i> (Richardson) ... They are often referred to as Silvery, while in other parts they are called Cucumber Fish. (NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,113)

>  <b>1956</b> <i>GRAHAM</i> SMELT (PARAKI) <i>Retropinna retropinna</i> (Richardson) ... They are often referred to as Silvery, while in other parts they are called Cucumber Fish. (NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,113)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>DOOGUE & MORELAND</i> SMELT ... <i>Other names: Retropinna sp.</i>; silvery, cucumber-fish; inanga-papa (Maori). (Sea Anglers' Guide,196)

>  <b>1967</b> <i>NATUSCH</i> New Zealand smelts [<i>Retropinnidae</i>] are true smelts, but here they are often called by the pretty name of silveries. (Animals of NZ, The,208)

>  <b>Apr 3, 1984</b> You will catch; flounder fry; tiny shrimps; glass eels; silveries, cockabullies and baby stargazers; ... (Dominion,6) [NOTES: [Keri Hulme]]

## six o'clock swill
 
 <i>n.</i> a popular name for the 5-6 p.m. drinking rush during the six o'clock closing of bars before 9 October 1967 [[AND see SWILL: six o'clock swill 1955]]

>  <b>Jun 1999</b> I also worked in the Great Northern Hotel in the days of the six o'clock swill - everybody was paralytic at six. (Metro,56)

>  <b>Aug 13, 1963</b> Sir, - Like the great majority of New Zealanders who finish work at 5 or 5.30 p.m. I like two or three beers and a chat to my friends before I go home for dinner. That is when I feel like a drink, and when I enjoy it. They call it the `six o'clock swill,' but we enjoy it. After all, when service is required by so many at the same time, there must be a crush. (Dominion,4)

>  <b>Jul 23, 1963</b> New Zealander's liquor hours, notably the `five to six swill' produced gusty debate and plenty of laughs at the National Party Conference yesterday. (Dominion,1)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>TURNER</i> This gives in New Zealand the terms <i>vertical drinking </i>(in crowded bars with standing room only), <i>the six o'clock swill</i> and, at least among students in Wellington about 1940, the <i>shicker express</i>, the first tram after six o' clock ... (English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,131)

>  <b>Jun 25, 1972</b> The rich linguistic legacy of the election rituals would draw thousands. Coaches would tour vivid re-enactments of the six o'clock swill, staged by Richard Campion and choreographed after extensive interviews with the survivors.[check with MITCHELL cit???] (Sunday Times (NZ),35/2)

>  <b>1972</b> <i>MITCHELL</i> Coaches would tour vivid re-enactments of the six o'clock swill ... . (Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The,14)

>  <b>1979</b> <i>GEBBIE & McGREGOR</i> We had knocked off one Thursday night after [47] the six o'clock swill and were having a drink in the upstairs bar about nine o'clock ... (Incredible 8-Ounce Dream,46)

>  <b>1980</b> <i>LELAND</i> <i>six o'clock swill</i>: Prior to 9 October 1967, bars in New Zealand had to close at 6.00p.m. (now they close at 10.00p.m., often 12.00p.m. ..) on weekends. (Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,92)

>  <b>Jun 29, 1967</b> <i>Wellington</i> New Zealanders will choose in a referendum later this year between their notorious 6 o'clock swill and a more civilized style of drinking liquor. .. Paradoxically, the appalling conditions of the 5-to-6-o'clock swill have strengthened the opponents of reform. (San Francisco Chronicle,4) [NOTES: 1967 July 29 Ian Templeton in San Francisco Chronicle 4]

>  <b>1986</b> <i>HOLCROFT</i> We were then .. in the heyday of the six o'clock swill, an institution so notorious that visiting Americans .. were taken to selected hotels to see for themselves an operation otherwise unbelievable. (Sea of Words,9)

>  <b>1986</b> <i>six o'clock swill NZ & Austral. colloq.</i> (formerly) period of rapid consumption of alcoholic drinks immediately before six o'clock closing-time of bars. (NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,717) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

>  <b>Sep 21, 1987</b> `Privatisation', `Corporatisation' and `market-driven forces' are now as common in our vocabulary as the `six o'clock swill' and `Don Clarke' was to our forebears. (Salient,5)

>  <b>1988</b> <i>McGILL</i> <i>six o'clock swill </i> rapid male drinking in male-only public bars in the lead-up to 6 pm pub closing time, usually from end of work at 5 pm. Perceived as piggish and the closest we got to a direct connection between beer hoses and customers. (Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,103)

>  <b>Mar 13, 1988</b> Though the six o'clock swill ceased in 1967 .. there was still a powerful linkage between drinking beer and masculinity. (Dominion Sunday Times,16)

>  <b>Feb 22, 1997</b> We introduced daylight saving time when it suited us, abolished the six o'clock swill and have reshaped the school year into four terms. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

>  <b>Jan 20, 1993</b> They have become booze barns run by a private company which is still in the six o 'clock swill mode . (Independent Herald (Wellington),1)

>  <b>Aug 13, 1990</b> Maybe one day we'll look back on Sunday closure with the same amazement with which we now view the six o'clock swill, but surely never with the same horror. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

>  <b>1997</b> <i>GOLDSMITH</i> These establishments [sc. illegal beer houses] catered for those who wanted to drink past the '6 o'clock swill'. (John Banks : A Biography,40)

>  <b>2003</b> <i>Michael King</i> With the abolition of six o'clock closing of hotel bars in 1967 and an eventual relaxation of restaurant licensing laws, alcohol became available at more civilised hours and in more civilised circumstances than in the days of the 'six o'clock swill'. (Penguin History of New Zealand,389)

>  <b>Feb 10, 2001</b> The teen-age binge-drinking so evident at the New Year is part of a New Zealand tradition that goes right back to the six o'clock swill, known affectionately as the six o'clock spill. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

>  <b>Sep 19, 1987</b> For husbands, release from their emotional repression came only with the "six o'clock swill" at the pub or Saturdays at the footy. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),31)

>  <b>Apr 8, 2000</b> In the dim glow of yellow lights, you can smell again the perpetually beer-soaked carpets of the six o'clock swill and consider that you are just another battery hen queueing for a fix. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),52)

>  <b>May 4, 2009</b> When licensing laws were relaxed in 1989, and again in 1999, to allow the sale of alcohol in supermarkets and, it turns out, dairies, the changes were supposed to reflect a new, more mature, attitude to drinking. Unfortunately, the attitude of some is unchanged from the days of the 6 o'clock swill; they just don't have to travel as far to buy alcohol. (Dominion Post,B4) [NOTES: Editorial]

>  <b>Jun 2004</b> This hurried hour of drinking between 5 and 6 was known as 'the 6 o'clock swill' and the decibels spilling out of the public bar onto the streets got louder and louder as six o'clock approached. (NZ Memories,No. 48/6)

>  <b>Apr 23, 1983</b> Those were the days of six o'clock swill, when alcohol could not be sold after 6pm and only hotels could operate bottle stores. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

>  <b>1991</b> <i>WOLFE</i> And so 6 o'clock closing - or the '6 o'clock swill' as it became known - was enforced. (Kiwi,54)

>  <b>Sep 18, 2010</b> For half a century, from 1917 to 1967, the six o'clock swill artificially prolonged the rough male pioneering culture, according to historian Jock Phillips, in his book <i>A Man's Country</i>. (Your Weekend,9)

>  <b>1964</b> There's nothing at all to compare with the thrillOf Kiwis unleashed at the six o'clock swill...Oh, the pleasure or rushing to get a new fillIn the sardine-like squeeze of the six o'clock swill. (Matamata District Chronicle,[10]) [NOTES: From a poem by someone called John Reid]

>  <b>Oct 17, 1992</b> These are philosophical matters which could well have been aired had the 25th anniversary of the end of the 6 o'clock swill been properly respected. (Evening Post,8)

>  <b>1959</b> <i>BOLLINGER</i> After the Second World War, a returned serviceman termed it the '5 to 6 o'clock swill'. (Grog's Own Country,4)

>  <b>1976</b> I have some wonderment as to whether we may not have transferred that peculiar New Zealand phenomenon, the 6 o'clock swill, into the 10 o'clock brawl. (NZ Parliamentary Debates,407 : 3569)

## skillion

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a section of a woolshed where sheep are kept under cover.

>  <b>1863</b> <i>BUTLER</i> In a woolshed the aisles would be called skilions .. All the sheep go into the skilions. (First Year in Canterbury Settlement,158)

>  <b>1865</b> <i>BARKER</i> A constant succession of woolly sheep being brought up to fill the 'skillions' ... (Station Life in NZ,34)

>  <b>Dec 2, 1933</b> He looked into his woolshed and said, 'Oh yes, there's plenty of room in the skillions.' [skilion] (Press, The  (Acland Glossary),15)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> (obsolete) (in pl.)

>  <b>1863</b> <i>BUTLER</i> The wool-shed .... has a large central space, and an aisle-like partition on each side. These last will be for holding the sheep at night. ... In a wool-shed, the aisles would be called skilions (whence the name is derived, I know not, nor whether it has two `l's' in it or one). All the sheep go into the skillions <k>Ibid.</i> x/158 In a wool-shed the aisles would be called skilions (whence the word is derived I know not, nor whether it has two l's in it or one). All the sheep go into the skilions. The shearers shear in the centre ... [and] pull the sheep out of the skilions as they want them. (First Year in Canterbury Settlement,139)

>  <b>1865</b> <i>BARKER</i> ... a constant succession of woolly sheep being brought up to fill the `skillions' (from whence the shearers take them when they want them), and the newly-shorn ones ... being turned out after they have passed through a narrow passage, called a `race,' where each sheep is branded ... (Station Life in NZ,34,1870 ed.)

>  <b>Dec 2, 1933</b> <i>Skillion</i>.- [Variant of 'skillin' and skilling', recorded from the fourteenth century, all late examples being provincial English; origin unknown. --A.W.] In old Australian and New Zealand books (up to about 1880) it is common and means the sheep-holding part of a woolshed. I can remenber an old hand mentioning the word in the 'nineties. I have tried it on several elderly shepherds since the war I and none of them understood it. I imagined the word had gone completely out of use until last month (May 1933), when I bought five tons of chaff from a man and asked him to store it for a few weeks. He looked into his woolshed and said, `Oh yes, there's plenty of room in the skillions.' I felt as if I had met a notornis. ' . . called skillions (whence the name is derived I know not, nor whether it has two l's in it or one). All the sheep go into the skilions.' (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 139). `A constant succession of woolly sheep being brought up to fill the skillions.' ([1874 Lady Barker Station Life], p. 34). (Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>1979</b> <i>TEMPLE</i> ... he saw the clearest satisfaction in the sunlight falling through the skillion door over the heaving backs of the sheep and on to the board, slick with wool grease ... (Stations,99)

>  <b>1975</b> <i>LANDS & SURVEY</i> This wasting disease or condition in ruminant stock was known locally by several names: 'Tauranga disease' .. 'The Skinnies' which graphically described the physical appearance of affected stock; and 'Bush-sickness' ... (Prosperity from Pumice Land,7)

>  <b>Oct 20, 1925</b> The existence of the trouble had been recognised for the past 40 years under the local names of "Bush Sickness," "Bush Disease," or "The Skinnies." (Evening Post,10)

>  <b>Jun 22, 1928</b> For long the "coasty sickness", "pluing", "vinguish" and "daising" of stock on King Island off the coast of Tasmania, in the Kedong Valley of Nairobi, and among the Cheviot Hills of the North of England were not associated with New Zealand "bush sickness" or "the skinnies" as it is graphically labelled by the farmers of this country. (NZ Free Lance,7)

## skinplaster
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1972</b> <i>HARGREAVES</i> The [Governor Fitzroy's (1844)] Debentures, popularly known as `government rags', were given various nicknames such as <i>assignats</i>, `shinplasters', and `flash notes'. All these terms had reference to worthless paper money, some of which had been issued in the past. <i>Assignats</i> was the name given to large amounts of paper money issued in France during the French Revolution, but which depreciated to such as extent to be almost worthless. `Shinplasters'--sometimes written `skinplasters'--had its origin in North America, and again referred to depreciated paper money, while `flash notes' was a popular term in use for any counterfeit money or worthless forged paper money. (From Beads to Banknotes,40)

 <i>n.</i> =storm petrel (from its apparent ability to `walk' on water; cf dancing dolly, jesus christ bird)

>  <b>1982</b> <i>SALE</i> .. [The storm petrel] has many other names - skipjack, Dancing Dolly, frigate petrel - from the Pakeha; and takahikaremoana from the Maori. (Four Seasons,38)



 
 <i>n.</i> a click beetle

 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Oct 3, 1769</b> Saw some fish like skip Jacks and a small sort that appear'd very transparent. 5 [fn5] Any sort of fish that had a habit of leaping out of the water tended in the eighteenth century to be called a skipjack. In the twentieth century the name is sometimes given in Australia and New Zealand both to the Striped Tuna (<i>Katsuwonis pelamis</i>) and to more than one sort of Trevally (<i>Usacaranx</i> spp.). Early whalers gave the name to the Trevally. But that does not cast much light on the fish Cook saw, for which other candidates have been suggested, and which must be left unidentifiable. (Cook's Journals,1/166,1955 ed.)



 
 <i>n.</i> trevally (<i>Caranx georgianus</i>)

## slagged
 
<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of land or feed] topdressed with slag.

>  <b>1936</b> The relative merits of superphosphate and basic slag for pasture top-dressing are much discussed in certain districts, particularly North Taranaki and North Auckland. Many experienced farmers are firmly of the opinion that slagged pastures have better milk production and fattening capacities than ones treated with superphosphate. How much this may be due to a greater effect from slag, how much to some effect on the mineral content of the herbage, and how much due to management it is impossible to say. (Evening Post,10)
