## slather
 
 <i>v.</i> box, fight, do battle (See [slather n](../S#slather-n))

>  <b>May 23, 1914</b> On the 28th of this month, Gisborne stoush lovers will have another bonzer night, when the Gisborne Association will bring Bert Lowe and Bill Bartlett together. These two are scheduled to slather for fifteen rounds, but this is not going to be nearly all the fun. Viv Lowe and Poesy will try to deal out oblivion to each other during six rounds, while Mellow and Heany and also Harrison and Frurie will put up their 'dukes'. (NZ Truth,6)

>  <b>1927</b> <i>ANTHONY</i> They [sc. hungry cows] slathered at the mouth, with hunger and eagerness .. (Gus Tomlins,91,1977 ed. Sturm ed.) [NOTES: (?is this an authorial error)]



 
 <i>n.</i> vigorous 'unscientific' fighting; unrestrained toe-to-toe boxing action [from the idea of slathering or plastering blows on one's opponent (often in the collocation 'slather and whack'); see OED slather sense 3 to thrash, defeat thoroughly; see also open slather; compare slather-up n.]

>  <b>Aug 1, 1914</b> [In the last round they both tired visibly, and casting caution to the winds slathered each other.] ... A wild slather ended when Finnie missed with a left and came in with his head low, owing to the impetus. ... Early in the round, Bennetts emerged from a slather, shaking his head and seemed to forget all about his opponent. (NZ Truth,12)

>  <b>Dec 12, 1908</b> Then both warriors made a speech, which was lost amid the roar. It was a great slather and whack fight. There is no gainsaying Grim's pluck and ability to take punishment. But there is a big chunk of his reputation gone now that Griffin dropped him. (NZ Truth,3)

>  <b>Mar 4, 1922</b> Chris. Rusterholz (8.5) versus Cliff Pearce (7.12). This was the tit-bit of the evening and provided five rounds of ding dong slather of a high order. Both are quick two-handed fighters and they went at it hammer and tacks without a dull moment intervening. (NZ Truth,8)

>  <b>Dec 24, 1921</b> The feathers, J. Whittome (8.7) and C. McCarthy (8.5), followed, and they gave a clean, clever exhibition, more like a professional bout than that of amateurs. There was none of that wild slather, but good, scientific punching throughout. (NZ Truth,8)

>  <b>Aug 16, 1928</b> Seldom indeed has a crowd voiced its approval of an out-and-out boxing match as it did at Wellington last week. Scientific stuff nine times out of ten leaves the audience cold - it is the slather and whack artists that get 'em on their feet, yelling encouragement. But the exception was bumped into last week when Jack Carroll gained a points decision over Charlie Purdy. Carroll came to us with a reputation of a bit of a killer, but his first fight in Wellington showed he was more of a stylist. He showed up as a nice mover, possessing plenty of speed at both ends, but totally lacking as a purveyor of hefty wallops. (NZ Truth,10)

>  <b>Mar 28, 1914</b> BOXING AT GREYMOUTH. ...Now, when the time is ripe, it might be mentioned that Cook's exhibition throughout the mill, his genuine smile of good fellowship when picking up his opponent on a couple of occasions when he slipped, and his palpable desire to box instead of indulging in 'slather and whack', bears the impression that when his recent mill with Billy Hannan at Gisborne was declared 'no fight' and he lost his share of the purse, there was some truth in his words, 'I don't profess to be a fighter; I'm a boxer, pure and simple, and I tried my hardest to beat Hannan.' (NZ Truth,6)

## Sleepy Hollow
 
 <i>n.</i> Nelson town and city

>  <b>Aug 15, 1928</b> [Caption] No longer should Nelson be termed "Sleepy Hollow". (NZ Free Lance,33)

>  <b>Mar 23, 1912</b> "Sleepy Hollow" can now slumber on peacefully, and with a contented mind for another decade or so. (NZ Free Lance,26)

>  <b>Jan 21, 1871</b> Even Nelson - "sleepy hollow," as we call it - boasts of a magnificent water supply. (Evening Post,2)

>  <b>Feb 13, 1926</b> The roads about Sleepy Hollow are pretty good too. (NZ Observer,6)

>  <b>Dec 18, 1907</b> Nelson is a beautiful place and well-named "Sleepy Hollow". (Otago Witness,83)

>  <b>1906</b> <i>ELKINGTON</i> Nelson.. is a charming little place, very English and very sleepy - in fact, it is called "Sleepy Hollow". (Adrift in NZ,211)

>  <b>Jul 12, 1851</b> Sir George Grey is the Rip Van Winkle of New Zealand. During his quiet repose in Sleepy hollow, the colony has been advancing in opinion at railroad speed. And now that his Excellency has awakened, he finds everything about him strange and unexpected. (Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,84)

>  <b>Aug 22, 1867</b> Nelson being sometimes called "sleepy hollow," has been, until now, pretty free of such frolicsome characters, but it seems one or two individuals are begining [sic] buckyism practices; by inserting a few of the absurdities in your valuable paper may, perhaps, prevent the malady extending to others, as even the winners are found to be on the losing side when they appear in the Resident Magistrate's Court. (Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

>  <b>May 7, 1910</b> Was it hard to get money on in "Sleepy Hollow?" (NZ Truth,2)

>  <b>Oct 11, 1913</b> Nelson is no longer called "Sleepy Hollow." It had an earthquake recently. (NZ Observer,7)

>  <b>May 2, 1857</b> Nelson appears to have become a second "sleepy hollow." and unless we rouse ourselves speedily, we shall be known, like the inhabitants of "Tarry Town," as "sleepy-hollow boys" throughout the neighbouring country. (Nelson Examiner,2)

>  <b>Sep 25, 1890</b> I settled down in "Sleepy Hollow," a fully fledged banker. (Otago Witness,36)

>  <b>May 3, 1873</b> I have known Sir David Monro for 30 years, and have lived for some of that period in the same place with him, Nelson, a settlement for which the influence of minds like his has earned the designation of "Sleepy Hollow." (Auckland Weekly News,15)

>  <b>Sep 24, 1887</b> Our visit ended at Nelson - generally spoken of as "Sleepy Hollow." (Auckland Weekly News,28)

>  <b>1908</b> <i>BARR</i> ... before reaching `Sleepy Hollow', as the capital of Nelson is not altogether inappropriately called. (British Rugby Team in Maoriland,77)

>  <b>1910</b> <i>FANNING</i> In his time B. Fanning was in some fierce battles, and the roughest of them was at Nelson, misnamed `Sleepy Hollow.' (Players and Slayers,87)

>  <b>1947</b> <i>SMITH</i> From Blenheim we can proceed to Christchurch ... but this would involve missing Sleepy Hollow, or as it is called on the maps, Nelson. (From N to Z,72)

>  <b>1956</b> <i>SUTHERLAND</i> While we were driving along ... Nelson harbour ..., Glennie remarked: `They call this place `Sleepy Hollow', you know. I've heard it said that you'll sleep a couple of hours longer here than you will anywhere else - it's something to do with the air, they say.' (Green Kiwi,172,1960 ed.)

>  <b>1874</b> <i>BATHGATE</i> ... Nelson dubbed `Sleepy Hollow' (Colonial Experiences,275)

>  <b>1877</b> The `Sleepy Hollow' boys [sc. the Nelson football team] rode rough shod over boisterous Wellington. (Country Journal,1/251)

>  <b>1894</b> <i>WILSON</i> The air here is positively intoxicating, ... in summer, when the heat is semi-tropical, I am told that Nelson fully merits its soporific title of `Sleepy Hollow'. (In the Land of the Tui,218) [NOTES: 1891 Sep 24 in 1894 Wilson Land of the Tui 218]

>  <b>Oct 1937</b> In spite of the fact that Nelson is called "Sleepy Hollow" it seems to me always that it is Marlborough that is the quiet province. (NZ Railways Magazine,23)

>  <b>Mar 4, 1924</b> Sleepy Hollow is a misnomer. (Otago Witness,69)

>  <b>Nov 15, 1916</b> Oh, you're from Sleepy Hollow...Nelsonites rise to the bait. (Chronicles NZEF,I/6 : 134)

>  <b>Nov 2, 1929</b> At that time Nelson claimed among its citizens such prominent figures in the later life of the country as Sir William Fox, Mr. Alfred Domett, and Sir Francis Bell, the father of the late Leader of the Legislative Council, and it may not be a mere vain conceit to feel that the presence of such gentlemen in the midst of a community, remembering the charms of Captain Wakefield, did much to perpetuate in Nelson a measure of courtesy, hospitality, and integrity that gives "Sleepy Hollow" a charm that any community might envy. (Evening Post,10)

## slew
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) an angle left or right that sheep take when they are responding to a dog's direction to change course.

>  <b>Sep 1, 1925</b> Went clean through first flags without trouble and put in a good clean slew, which landed his sheep across the creek. Made a poor slew at the first flags ... (NZ Farmer,1343)

>  <b>Dec 15, 1983</b> Slew - the angles - left or right - of a hunt and the new direction sheep take when directed to by a dog. (NZ Journal of Agriculture,45)

>  <b>1998</b> <i>GORDON</i> By this time, the sheep would be finishing the first set and a right-hand slew had to be applied to line them up for the second set. (Three Sheep and a Dog,151)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [shepherding] to direct sheep in a particular direction.

>  <b>Sep 1, 1925</b> This dog's sheep drifted through first flags, with the dog not interested, but he slewed nicely and he crossed the creek with firm work. (NZ Farmer,1343)

>  <b>May 1933</b> if the driving was done by a huntaway dog, slewing the sheep would be in order. (NZ Farmer,317)

>  <b>1946</b> <i>ACLAND</i> .. if you slewed a mob of strong merino wethers too hard against a fence, the fence went flat. (Early Canterbury Runs,40)

>  <b>1949</b> <i>HARTLEY</i> The next lesson is devised to teach a dog in advance how to slew sheep. (Shepherd's Dogs, The,17)

>  <b>Apr 11, 1968</b> The 'Lake' country is mainly open shingle and it's mostly 'topside' work - slewing sheep downhill. (NZ Farmer,45)

>  <b>1970</b> <i>MCLEOD</i> Wait would head or hunt or slew with uncanny intelligence. (Many a Glorious Morning,142)

>  <b>2000</b> <i>KERR</i> Otairi's huntaways were used to lifting sheep; mine to slewing from above. (High Times in the High Country,173)



 
 <i>v.</i> to beat, outwit, baffle [SOED labels Aust. & NZ]

>  <b>1873</b> <i>PYKE</i> Of their reputation, the miners spoke with bated breath; ... The general impression seemed to be, that Jack Ketch had been `slued' (<i>anglice</i> - robbed of his dues) by the trio. (Wild Will Enderby,1/xi/41,(1889,1974) ed.)

>  <b>1875</b> In London the peelers down areas will go, / To make love to the cook and the victuals, /But here there're no areas down which to intrude, / So of course the New Zealand bobbies are slewed. (NZ Songster,No.3/89) [NOTES: Thatcher London and the Diggings]

>  <b>1889</b> <i>MITCHELL</i> ... or levant from Oamaru/ Without bidding them adieu/ And the merchants we will slew - let them catch us if they can. (Rhymes and Rambles,25)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Jun 3, 1897</b> "This Scott seems a nice, steady-going sort of a dog. That was a nice slew he made had it been in the right place." (Otago Witness,34)

>  <b>1971</b> <i>NEWTON</i> He [a sheep dog] was so fast that I'd have him away out, past, and beyond any sheep almost before they knew he was coming. In this way I could get in good slews ... <i>Ibid.</i> 169 <i>Slew</i>: To turn or change the direction in which sheep are travelling. To top-side slew is to turn or hunt them downhill. Slewing is done mainly with huntaways and in one of the huntaways events at our trials - Class III - the sheep are hunted on a zig-zag course. This is often called a slew. (Ten Thousand Dogs,26)



 
 <i>v.</i>

>  <b>Jun 1, 1893</b> T. Prendergast's Tom hunted his sheep out well about 300yds and slewed to the right, but failed to slew to the left. (Otago Witness,21)

>  <b>Apr 15, 1910</b> The dog had to head sheep, slew them, drive them a short distance along a ridge, and then pull to ring. (Hawera & Normanby Star,7)

>  <b>Jul 23, 1907</b> In class 3 Mr Reg. Black's Niss worked steadily in the hunt away, slewing well, was under good command, brought back in good style but should have been steadied more. (Taranaki Herald,8)

>  <b>1933</b> <i>ACLAND</i> .. When a dog heads or slews sheep, shepherds speak of his having done a good (etc.) <i>turn</i>. (Sheep Station)

>  <b>Nov 25, 1933</b> <i>Sheep dog</i>.- Dog to work sheep; <i>collie</i> (q.v.). <i>S.ds</i>. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called <i>heading ds.</i> (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to<i> lead </i>(q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to<i> huntaway</i> and are called <i>htwys</i> (q.v.). Some dogs will both <i>hd</i>. and <i>htwy</i> and are called <i>handy ds.</i> They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special<i> slewing d.</i>, but a well-trained, <i>hdg</i>. dog or <i>htwy</i>. will usually <i>slew </i>(q.v.). (C.) (Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>1949</b> <i>CRAWFORD</i> If you `slewed' a mob of strong merino wethers ... (Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury,40)

>  <b>1949</b> <i>HARTLEY</i> <i>Teaching Slewing</i> The next lesson is devised to teach a dog ... to slew sheep. (Shepherd's Dogs, The,17)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>NEWTON</i> <i>Slew</i>: To slew sheep is to turn them in a different direction to that in which they are going. If sheep are sidling round a face and they have to be turned downhill a dog is run out and above them to `slew' them down. (Boss's Story, The,190)

>  <b>1970</b> <i>McLEOD</i> <i>Slew:</i> A huntaway should be able to cast to the side on command and slew in the desired direction. (Glorious Morning,253)

>  <b>1971</b> <i>NEWTON</i> A mob of those wethers, slewed out of a high basin, would disappear down a spur in a cloud of dust ... <i>Ibid.</i> 169 <i>Slew</i>: To turn or change the direction in which sheep are travelling. To top-side slew is to turn or hunt them downhill. Slewing is done mainly with huntaways and in one of the huntaways events at our trials - Class III - the sheep are hunted on a zig-zag course. This is often called a slew. (Ten Thousand Dogs,15)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to defeat, overcome, get round (a problem)

>  <b>1863</b> <i>BUTLER</i> This [waterfall] `stuck us up', as they say here concerning any difficulty. We managed, however, to `slew' it, as they, no less elegantly, say concerning the surmounting of an obstacle. (First Year in Canterbury Settlement,v 67-68)

## sloven
 
 <i>n.</i> the splintered part projecting between the front and back scarf on a stump or on the butt-end of a felled tree

>  <b>1946</b> <i>SARGESON</i> The stumps still had the sloven sticking up. (That Summer,175)

>  <b>1961</b> <i>HENDERSON</i> When we reached the bushmen, we found them busy on their knees, cross-cutting the sloven, or rough outer edges, off a fallen silver pine, ... (Friends in Chains,69)

>  <b>Aug 1963</b> <i>J.E. BUCHANAN</i> I am interested in your letter because I had never come across the term before so had to get busy and `find' it. The definition I have run to earth reads: <i>Sloven</i>: The torn splintered portion of timber left on a stump or the end of a butt where the `key' finally broke when the tree fell. Syn. spaul, stub-chuck (American) ? also `Barbers'chair', the splintered stump of a newly felled tree. I hope this gives you the information you want. This is a new word to me and I am glad to have encountered it. (Letter) [NOTES: 1963 Aug 12 Letter J.A. Buchanan Forest Research Institute, Rotorua to Bill Pearson]

>  <b>1964</b> <i>SARGESON</i> sloven: the torn splintered wood left on a stump where the 'key' finally broke when the tree fell. The jagged splinters are the <i>spikes</i> in the story. (Letter,303)

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> by transf, the concaved portion of the centre of a split loaf of bread which projects when the bread has been split. [ca1940 Havelock]

 <i>n.</i> 1. a channel which carries or controls a flow of water. Short form of sluiceway. 2. a gate or valve used to control such a flow. sluice, verb, to send a stream of water out, over or through.

>  <b>Aug 3, 1883</b> Their sluice has a fall or grade of about 1 in 22 1/2, and the Kumara Channel 1 in 26. (West Coast Times,2)

In proof of this it may be mentioned that had the gold been fed into the watercourses at their heads the heavier gold would be found in its upper portions, the lighter and finer gold lower down the stream, and that the very fine gold had travelled the greatest distance; and such is found to be the case in all artificial sluices and tail races. (Otago Witness,13)

>  <b>May 23, 1862</b> The men are satisfied with the amount of gold found [in Otago] though it is not of a very good [40] quality, too fine, not nuggety enough to use a sluice well so they adopt the slower and surer way of cradling. (Chudleigh Diary,39,1950 ed.)

>  <b>Jan 2, 2010</b> Small-scaled skinks were first discovered on Motutaiko Island in 1971 and are native to New Zealand. (Dominion Post,A11)

However, O. microlepis [sic] requires looserocks on the ground surface and as a result is restricted to boulder river beds and naturaland artificial screes such as those that form below rocky escarpments and roads ... (Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.meridianenergy.co.nz/Documents/Final%20AEE/Appendix%20F%20Ecology/W07003-3_MEL_CentralWind_LizardsSnailsReport_071015.pdf]

>  <b>2008</b> As its name suggests, the elongate body of the small-scaled skink is covered in relatively small, glossy scales. .. (Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.arkive.org/small-scaled-skink/oligosoma-microlepis/]

>  <b>2005</b> The area is at about 700m above sea level with extreme winter conditions and is home to the Small-scaled skink (<i>Oligosoma microlepis</i>). (Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.nzaee.org.nz/skinks.htm Date is estimate]

## smallfarmer
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Jan 2000</b> What, then, is a smallfarmer? "A vertically challenged agriculturalist," runs the well-worn joke. While names like "smallholder" or the American "homesteader" might be less obvious butts, they are really no more descriptive. "Toy farmer" is obviously derisive, while "hobby farmer" rather unfairly equates small-scale farming with stamp collecting or restoring old cars. <i>Ibid.</i> 42 John Fairweather.. defines smallfarmers (or smallholders, as he categorises them) as people who have a commitment to effective land use, and who earn at least some farm income. They differ from a group he calls "lifestylers" - a term derived from the ubiquitous "life style block" dreamed up by real-estate agents when they began to sell the concept of country living 20 years ago. (NZ Geographic,No. 45/41)

 <i>n.</i> in New Zealand, a very small, usually silvery, freshwater fish, also called silvery; esp. <i>Retropinna richardsonii </i>, silvery,whitebait

>  <b>1848</b> <i>WAKEFIELD</i> Fish of all kinds ... abound off the mouth of the [Wanganui] river; and the <i>kawai </i>, as well as smelts, and the <i>aua,</i> or so-called herring, ascend the river .. (Handbook for New Zealand, The,212)

It is an Acanthopterygious fish ... Head, large, one third of the length of the body ... [86] The Silver-fish again belongs to the <i>Malacopterygii abdominales </i>, or fishes having soft fin rays, with the ventral fins placed below the abdomen. ... We now come to the ... fish ...called, by boys, the Smelt; but why a Smelt, I know not. ... the Smelt is a Galaxia ... (TrNZI,2/85) [NOTES: (Powell)]

## smokies
 
 <i>n.</i> opaque brown and grey marbles; also called OYSTERS [OED[S] check [1945 Baker Aust. Lay. 204 ca1950's Naenae, Wellington (p.c. G. Kennedy)]

>  <b>1949</b> <i>de MAUNAY</i> Once he gave him a bag of marbles, good ones, too, "smokies", not the useless little clay things. (Huntsman in His Career, The,136)

>  <b>1972</b> <i>SUTTON-SMITH</i> Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. (Folkgames of Children,174)

>  <b>1984</b> <i>KEITH & MAIN</i> Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. (NZ Yesterdays,288)

## smother
 
 <i>n.</i> [1933 see cit. v1]

>  <b>1945</b> Dangers of a 'smother' are real (NZ Geographer,1/27)

>  <b>1966</b> [check whether this refers to <i>smother </i>] (NZ Short Stories,210) [NOTES: 1963 Middleton in 1966 NZ Short Stories 210]

>  <b>1965</b> <i>MACNICOL</i> ... a large mob of sheep was allowed to mass on the road too quickly. This resulted in a `smother', the dread of all sheep-meu, and about sixty corpses were thrown over the edge of the road. ... (Skippers Road,141)

>  <b>1938</b> <i>BURDON</i> Difficulties arose only when they [sc. Merinos] started to go in the wrong direction and had to be stopped, or when a large mob was in hand and a steep, narrow gully had to be crossed; then there was always the danger of a `smother'. (High Country,108)

>  <b>1940</b> <i>STUDHOLME</i> The third day, as the sheep mobbed up, it was necessary to exercise great care in running a dog, for a rough turn could cause a bolt, or even a smother, if a deep gut came in the way. ... As soon as the whole mob was in hand and had been given a few turns, the danger of a smother lessened. (Te Waimate,123,1954 ed.)

>  <b>1952</b> <i>BLAKISTON</i> If such a mob runs into a steep-sided gully, they are likely to pile up at the bottom until those behind are running across a bridge of bodies, and, in hundreds, are suffocated. Shepherds dread a `smother', (My Yesteryears,20) [NOTES: [f. c1869]]

>  <b>1972</b> <i>McLEOD</i> Shepherds dread a `smother' ... (High Country Anthology,80) [NOTES: 1972 Blakiston `Sheep Station Life' in 1972 McLeod High Country Anthology 80]

>  <b>1962</b> <i>CRUMP</i> I've been off water for years, ever since we had a smother up the back and the creek ran dry before it came down in a stinking flood. (One of Us,88)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Feb 26, 1910</b> The rider of Nukuhan was in sore straits in the Scurry at Taranaki, as his instructions were to give the chestnut a good smother. Across the bottom bend he was on the outer, but then he came in to the rails, and despite the boy's efforts, he finished second. (NZ Truth,244/2/7)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [sheep] to suffocate when pushed together too closely.

>  <b>1848</b> PHARAZYN Journal Han 15 152 Teddy and W. to lambs to drive them to pen, smothered 10 in a blind gully ...

>  <b>1891</b> <i>CHAMIER</i> There's half a dozen sheep worried and a hundred smothered in the Great Gap ... (Philosopher Dick,248)

>  <b>1964</b> <i>MILLS ET AL</i> As shown by their speed and activity lambs are very susceptible to fright and are likely to pile up and smother at the slightest provocation. (Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,79)

>  <b>1987</b> <i>HALL</i> The man on the bottom beat got into trouble. Some sheep had been smothered through a bit of poor shepherding ... (Shepherd's Year, A,84)



 
 <i>v.</i> see cit. 1933

>  <b>Mar 1, 1885</b> There were <i>only ten</i> sheep smothered during the day. (Wairarapa Daily,2)

>  <b>Jan 10, 1867</b> <i>FORD</i> Aitken left a mob of sheep run [on] a wrong spur and smothered a large number ... [sic] (Diary) [NOTES: 1867 Jan 10 Ford Diary in 1981 Crawford Station Years 181]

>  <b>1987</b> <i>OGONOWSKA-COATES</i> <i>Smother </i>. If the pens in a woolshed are filled too tight sheep may smother during the night. Sheep are kept in the pens overnight before they are shorn. (Boards, Blades & Barebellies,97)

>  <b>Dec 2, 1933</b> <i>Smother.</i>- Run sheep especially merinos, are very easy to s. on broken hill ground. An injudicious turn with a dog in an abrupt gully may stop the lead and cause some sheep to be knocked over. Other sheep make a rush and are brought down too, so that in a second or two there is struggling heap; and before the shepherd can pull them off one another the bottom ones are <i>smothered </i>. They <i> sd.</i> 1200 once on the Stew Point country at Mount Peel, and I believe there was a still worse <i> s </i>. on a station called Roxburgh in Otago. People who fill their woolsheds too tight often <i>smother </i> sheep on a smaller scale: perhaps half a dozen or so in a night. (C.) (Press, The) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>1938</b> <i>BURDON</i> Difficulties arose only when they started to go in the wrong direction and had to be stopped, or when a large mob was in hand and a steep, narrow gully had to be crossed; then there was always the danger of a `smother.' Of all breeds the Merino is the easiest to smother, for he moves freer, faster, and more recklessly than any other. If pressed or carelessly handled, some of the leaders may fall or be knocked over and those behind will pile up on top of them until the gully is filled level to the top with struggling sheep. (High Country,108)

>  <b>Jan 15, 1848</b> <i>PHARAZYN</i> to lambs to drive them to pen, smothered 10 in a blind gully. (Journal,97) [NOTES: (also 152 chk) Teddy and W. [some of cit missing???]]

>  <b>May 2, 1862</b> In a minute half the mob were in. We pushed our horses in and prevented the others from going in. [36] If they had 3 out of 4 would have been smothered. (Chudleigh Diary,35,1950 ed.)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a suffocation of sheep, usually en masse [ when driven hard downhill or near water, or worried in a paddock by a dog and being forced together into a tight pack. ]

>  <b>1930</b> <i>ACLAND</i> They had a bad smother there. (Early Canterbury Runs,128)

>  <b>1952</b> <i>BLAKISTON</i> Shepherds dread a 'smother' and when the last creek was crossed, and the sheep safe in a holding paddock we were all very pleased. (My Yesteryears,20)

>  <b>1965</b> <i>GASCOIGNE</i> A smother like this is news and you'll be branded a bad shepherd and me a worse owner. A smother is one of the easiest things in the world to happen with sheep if the conditions are there, and we made them, in the first place by running a fence through that hole. (From the Top of a Hill,125)

>  <b>1976</b> <i>KERR</i> They [Merinos] roamed far in the days before fences, and mustering was difficult. The new chum found to his cost that 'they'd rush for miles at the sound of a bark, and you would have a pile up and a smother on your hands.' (From the Beginning: chronicles of a county,131)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>LOUGHNAN</i> smother: if sheep are bustled into any sort of a defile it only needs one of them to stumble and it will trip others. In next to no time there can be the dreadful and awful sight of a mass of struggling mutton, feet high. (Loughnan Glossary,74)

>  <b>1990</b> <i>WATT</i> Bad handling can cause many problems and one of these is smother. (Wild Horses & Me,150)

>  <b>1996</b> <i>STACEY</i> Care had to be taken there to prevent a big smother in the bog. (Tales of a Tussock Jumper,83)

## smothering
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the suffocating of sheep when forced together in a close mob.

>  <b>Jan 14, 2006</b> The innovation centres around a portable black box, known as a 'Snark', which contains a radio receiver, data logger and special computer software package. Staff can then come along with a portable mini-computer, plug it into the Snark, and find out what birds have been in the area overnight.  <i>v.</i> sawmilling: to trim the end of a log to obviate snagging while snigging; sc a log ?variant of snip

>  <b>1902</b> If the weather is favourable, the log is `sniped' or rounded at one end, an iron grip driven into it, and to this the team is fastened. (NZ Illustrated Magazine,5/375)

>  <b>1950</b> <i>R. GILBERD</i> A `ropey' will learn to `snipe' ... which is a highly-skilled operation. Butt-end of clean-trimmed log is trimmed of angles. Vees are cut at points opposite each other at the butt-end (usually) and are connected by a chopped Dee which runs around in a semi-circle from one to the other. In the Dee is laid a `strop', a short length of cable with an eye in each end. The eyes are connected with each other and to a short chain by a shackle; and the chain is attached to `the rope' with a hitch. (Personal Communication)

>  <b>1953</b> <i>REED</i> In order to prevent the log from `biting' into uneven ground, and enable it to slip over minor obstacles, it was `sniped' - that is, somewhat rounded or tapered at the front. (Story of the Kauri, The,179)

>  <b>1958</b> (NZ Timber Journal,87/2) [NOTES: [ca -1914]]

>  <b>1951</b> After the logs were cut, each was sniped. To snipe a log, the end is chipped all the way round so that it can be handled without catching humps in the ground, stumps and so on; in fact you might say that a log when it is sniped looks rather like the blunt end of a whale. (Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: H.S. McCarroll The Days of the Kauri Bushmen [Radio Talk 2: TS]]

>  <b>1952</b> SNIPE To round off the end of a log in order to facilitate snigging. (NZ Forest Glossary)

>  <b>1969</b> <i>MOORE</i> The front end of the log was carefully `sniped', that is, its sharp edge was rounded to allow it to skid like a sledge-runner. (From Forest to Farm,42)

>  <b>1986</b> <i>OWEN & PERKINS</i> First of all they tapered one end, rounding the log so that it would be able to slide over impediments in its path, because it had to be dragged along the ground. Now these men were called `snipers', and having sniped the log, they then made two cuts, one on each side of the log opposite each other, right into the rounded part - the sniped end. That was for the purpose of holding a heavy chain which attached the log to the yoked bullocks ... (Speaking for Ourselves,159) [NOTES: (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country)]

>  <b>Mar 2, 1878</b> <i>ENYS</i> New gate on road (the snow gate that rose in the air instead of opening sideways.) (Enys Papers)



## snow hut
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Jun 1952</b> Six weeks later A.J. Heine.. made another snow hut. (NZ Alpine Journal,14(39) : 365)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [sp. use, high country farming] a mustering hut above the snow line.

>  <b>1967</b> <i>HARPER</i> The three top snow huts, Waihi Top, Mt Edith Top and the Hat Top were kept provided with rations and blankets, which were stored in tin boxes, safe from rats and mice. Lean to-s were attached to several of the huts, all the top snow ones, for the musterers' dogs. (Kettle on the Fuchsia, The,88)



## snow in
 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) [of shearers] to make [the shed hands] unable to cope with the wool [by working too fast] (See [snowed in](../S#snowed-in))

## snow ink

## snow leggings

## snow muster
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [high country] an autumn muster.

## snow pea
 
 <i>n.</i> a variety of pea whose pods can be eaten along with the peas [Jim writes also <i>sugar pod</i> = sugar pea, mangetout. In NZPOD but not other dictionaries]



## snow pen
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a small enclosed snow-bound area, where groups of isolated, snowbound sheep gather.

>  <b>1987</b> <i>HALL</i> .. on this particular occasion, at Glencoe, we set out to trample a track through the snow for the sheep to follow once we'd freed them from their snow pen. I stayed at the bottom of the snow pen while Brian, the boss, brought them around to the track we'd made about halfway up the side of the pen. (Shepherd's Year, A,94)



## snow pole
 
 <i>n.</i> a pole placed upright to mark out a road or track when it is covered with snow.

>  <b>Apr 2, 1864</b> The erection of snow poles and wiresacross the Old Man Range is to becommenced on Monday. (Otago Witness,15)

>  <b>Aug 5, 1903</b> Persons who have had occasion to come over the Cardrona Saddle and other high roads since the snow fell would have found much help and guidance if snow poles had been erected. (Otago Witness,31)

>  <b>Jul 18, 1862</b> The miners ... appreciate the care and thoughtfulness of the Government in erecting snow poles between the Teviot township and Pomahawk Gully, and which, in these snow-covered regions, has been the means of averting much personal inconvenience, ... (Otago Witness,7)

>  <b>1875</b> <i>WOOD</i> ... they got snowed up at Potter's, and tried to make their way out by the snow poles over there. (Waiting for the Mail,36)

>  <b>1891</b> <i>DON</i> A bridle track marked by the remains of snowpoles. (Chinese Mission Work,18)

>  <b>1898</b> <i>HOCKEN</i> It was sought to make the track over Flagstaff, or the Snowy Mountains as they were then called, safer by erecting snow poles sunk into mounds, and of these there were seventeen to the mile; ... (Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,172)

>  <b>1988</b> <i>PICKERING</i> Out on the tops the old remedy for indicating a route was a pile of stones collected together - the cairn. Anyone can build them, and so once again a more official marking system had to be found. Routes became, as the maps put it, `poled', which [26] meant that metal standards were studded along the tops, These can also be called snow-poles or sometimes waratahs. (Hills, The,24, 26)

>  <b>1918</b> Snowpole track to Deep Stn. (NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No 19 (N.S.) map opp. p.40) [NOTES: (Tuapeka) Marshall]

>  <b>1947</b> <i>BEATTIE</i> It was sought to make the track over Flagstaff ... safer by erecting snow poles sunk into mounds, and of these there were seventeen to the mile ... (Pioneers Explore Otago,76) [NOTES: [Dr. Hocken's History]]

>  <b>1959</b> (Tararua,22/49)

>  <b>1870</b> <i>McLEOD</i> Coming down Starvation Gully, where the striped `snow-poles' marked the winding road for winter travellers,.... (Glorious Morning,219)



## snow river
 
 <i>n.</i> a snow-fed river

>  <b>Aug 26, 1939</b> In the North Island it [the oystercatcher] is never seen away from the coast, but in the South Island one species is widely distributed along the beds of snow rivers and in the barren uplands of Central Otago. (Evening Post,17)

>  <b>Sep 20, 1910</b> The wild West Coast, intersected by many bridgeless snow rivers, straight from the Southern Alps, and covered for the most of the part with bush, is probably the roughest bit of country that any New Zealand backblocks parson has to tackle. (Grey River Argus,1)

>  <b>Jul 1, 1900</b> THE trout streams of New Zealand may be divided into two classes - Rain Rivers and Snow Rivers. There are only one or two streams in the North Island that come under the later heading, but in the South all the great rivers are fed by melting snows. (NZ Illustrated Magazine,43)

>  <b>Aug 28, 1940</b> Within ten years of liberation of a stock of Scottish Burn trout, the waters in which they had been released had possessed all the so-called varieties of trout peculiar to the Old Country, from sea trout at the mouths of the snow rivers to the Scottish species in the small hill creeks. (Evening Post,8)

>  <b>Jan 4, 1859</b> But Canterbury is peculiarly favourable, having <i>snow</i> rivers. Salmon always live better in cold than in other water, especially prefering <i>snow fed rivers</i> and very rapid rivers. (Lyttelton Times,4)

>  <b>May 4, 1862</b> It [Waitaki] is a snow river looks milky before it rises. (Chudleigh Diary,36,1950 ed.)

>  <b>1863</b> <i>BUTLER</i> The Hurunui is not a snow river. (First Year in Canterbury Settlement,67)

>  <b>1871</b> ... The Rangitata, one of the great <i>snow rivers</i>, as they are termed. This stream, which derives its source from the glaciers which are embedded in the gloomy and secluded fastnesses of the Southern Alps, is periodically swollen by the melting of the snow and by the heavy rain from the north-west, ... (TrNZI,3/86) [NOTES: Potts]

>  <b>1881</b> <i>BATEMAN</i> Very many [in Canterbury] are known as `snow' rivers, owing to the icy coldness of the water. (Colonist, The,26)

>  <b>Mar 22, 1928</b> In all the snow rivers of Canterbury the fish have been running in considerable numbers for the last few weeks. (Evening Post,12)

## snow totara
 
 <i>n.</i> (Environment) a dwarf alpine variety of totara, Podocarpus nivalis

>  <b>Sep 1958</b> We followed deer tracks zigzagging up through snow totara and <i>Dracophyllum</i>, then plugged up through soft snow to Brodrick Pass (5,308ft., taking nearly two hours from camp. (Tararua,49)

>  <b>1973</b> <i>MARK & ADAMS</i> These shrubs, often no higher than the tussocks, vary somewhat from place to place but snow totara (<i>Podocarpus nivalis</i>), mountain toatoa (<i>Phyllocladus alpinus</i>) and some of the mid-sized species of <i>Dracophyllum (D. uniflorum) Hebe (H.odora)</i> and <i>Coprosma (C. pseudocuneata)</i> are widespread. (Plants of NZ,18,1979 ed.)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>DENNIS</i> Snow totara (Podocarpus nivalis</i>) is found here and there in the west [of Westland]. (Paparoas Guide,164)

>  <b>1988</b> <i>DAWSON</i> Snow totara (<i>Podocarpus nivalis</i>) forms low bushes in this community [sc. tussock shrubland]. (Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,170)

>  <b>Sep 2001</b> Snow totara, <i>Podocarpus nivalis</i>, also produces red berries, feeding kea and wood pigeons venturing above the bushline. <i>Ibid.</i> 50 [Caption] Seed disperser extraordinaire, a New Zealand pigeon gorges itself on the berries of a thicket of snow totara. <i>Podocarpus nivalis</i>. Unlike the mighty lower-altitude totara, this alpine species never grows to be more than a 3 m-high shrub. (NZ Geographic,No. 53/47)

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [S.I. high country] a tufty native grass, Danthonia raoulia or D flavescens.

>  <b>1983</b> <i>ROBERTS & TURNER</i> When high country settlement began in the mid-nineteenth century flax, toi-toi and snow tussock of enormous size grew in profusion, as did spaniard, slippery fern, lawyer bushes and matagouri. (NZ High Country Four Seasons,19)

>  <b>2000</b> <i>KERR</i> The fire was roaring up to a patch of silver tussock, which doesn't burn as high as snow tussock. (High Times in the High Country,107)

## snow-apple
 
 <i>n.</i> [Kolstad says these are species of <i>Gaultheria</i> and snow-apple in this sense does not appear to occur elsewhere, only in OED2 and US Dictionaries as an apple cultivar. Kerry Carman writes (Sep. 2000): I can supply no other literary reference to snow apples but am sure Neave was referring to the Alpine Snowberry <i>Gaultheria depressa</i> or, more likely, the closely-related <i>G.d.</i> var <i>novae-zelandiae</i> (Mountain Snowberry) with pure white apple-shaped fruits. These, at 1.5 cm, are the largest and juiciest berries in the genus.]

>  <b>Dec 9, 2000</b> It is certain that snow-apple is a colloquial colonial term for the plant we now refer to as snowberry - possibly the Bush Snowberry <i>Gaultheria antipoda</i>, which is common on Mt Somers. But more likely, from Naeve's description of the fruit, is the Alpine Snowberry <i>Gaultheria depressa</i>, or the closely related <i>G d novaezelandiae</i>, the Mountain Snowberry, distinguished by its pure white, apple-shaped fruits, which, at 1.5 cm, are the largest, juiciest and generally regarded as tastiest in the genus. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),45)

>  <b>1965</b> <i>ANDERSON</i> "We were up at 7.30 o'clock, took some sandwiches and started off to climb Mt Somers. Walked through bush and scrub and over stones, shifting shingle and boulders. Ate any amount of snow-apples, little white berries growing like cranberries and tasting like apples and cream". (Good Logs of Algidus, The,47) [NOTES: Quote from Frank Naeve, written 1864]

## snowball waltz
 
 <i>n.</i> A means of breaking the ice; a pre-selected split up when the music stops and each takes a new partner from others in the hall; this continues until all are on the floor. [Also the name of a book by Renee. Note on conversation with Deidre Macken (60 yrs) about her mother's story (86 yrs). She was in the Wellington Ballet Company in 1926 and on news of Pavlova's tour wrote to her manager enquiring how they could help make her tour and reception more pleasant, her favourite colours, foods, etc. She expressed a great liking for meringue (cakes) so they consulted a chef who produced 3 attempts (e.g. a square cake was rejected in favour of a round one); finally the `soft-centre' variety was chosen. In her honour they named it Pavlova (?cake) and they presented this to Pavlova (? at a gathering) and she liked it a great deal. D. Macken is to research this - ? Ballet company records, etc. Deidre Macken (04) 384-6073 - H.D. Macken, Nairn St.]

>  <b>Dec 13, 1997</b> At its compulsive best, The Snowball Waltz is an acutely rendered portrayal of human frailty and unexpected fortitude. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

>  <b>1997</b> <i>RENEE</i> The next dance, ladies and gentlemen, is a Snowball Waltz! We knew they did this at real dances because Gertrude played in real dance bands once, which was how our mother met the saxophone player. (Snowball Waltz, The,60)

## snowberry
 
 <i>n.</i> a name applied to a number of plants, including mingimingi (prickly heath). See also Taupo snowberry, rock snowberry, weka berry [Kerry Carman writes (Sept. 2000): <i>Gaultheria antipoda</i> is the Bush Snowberry; fruits are 15 mm and may be white, pink, red or purple. Confusing the issue are two other candidates, also commonly called snowberries. (a). <i>Pernettya</i> is also an edible Snowberry, sometimes white, sometimes red. Like <i>Gaultheria</i> it is of the <i>Ericaceae</i> with which it bydrisies freely in the wild. (b). <i>Leucopogon (Epacridaceae)</i> is another edible native Snowberry from the region. It ranges from white through pinks and red to purple.]

>  <b>1997</b> <i>CROWE</i> Snowberry <i>Gaultheria antipoda</i> Tawiniwini; bush snowberry <i>Gaultheria depressa</i> Mountain snowberry... ## snowed in
 
 <i>n.</i> of the condition when shearers are ahead of the wool table, so that wool is lying around the floor waiting to go on the wool table

>  <b>1956</b> <i>BOWEN</i> SNOWED IN. Describing the state of affairs when the shearers are ahead of the wool table, so that wool is lying around the floor waiting to go on the wool table. With a good run shearers can sometimes snow the pressers in. Shearers will be seen at their best when they get ahead of the rest of the shed. They enjoy this snowing in, and usually they make the wool flow faster than ever. (Wool Away!,157) [NOTES: (glossary: Shearing Terms)]

>  <b>Feb 26, 1965</b> <i>Snowed in</i>: The condition of the sorting table or the shearing board when shearers are working too fast for the shed hands to keep up. (Listener (New Zealand Listener)) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing)]

## solstice
 
 <i>n.</i> [Jim writes: As an attributive, in relation to the winter solstice, this has come into use in NZ recently in compounds such as <i>(winter) solstice carnival, solstice celebration, solstice dinner, solstice party</i>. Any similar usages in the Northern Hemisphere (none are recorded in NSOD or Collins) are likely to relate to the summer solstice, since the winter solstice coincides with Christmas. I havs also seen <i>winter Christmas</i> used in NZ. The development of "solstice" terms might usefully be watched.]

## southerly buster
 
 <i>n.</i> ? orig Canterbury, but general South Island and Cook Strait. see esp. buster, and see butt=ender; see also south-easter, souther, southern buster, sou'west buster, threeday sou'wester Acland's note and description (1933) applies (also CR. 68): A strong wind with rain, snow or sleet from a southerly direction. The ordinary man in the paddock in Canterbury recognises only three winds: <i> East </i> (from N.E.),<i> sou'wester </i> (from S.E., S. etc, S.W. etc), and nor'wester. <i> As a matter of fact a three-day so'wester usually only lasts two and a half. They are said to be less fierce than in the early days, just as the nor'wester is said to have been softened by the planting on the plains. It may be so in Christchurch </i>; but I cannot say I notice any difference up-country. The <i> nor'</i> wester <i> may come from any where between due north and due west. ## Southern Colony
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Jan 2, 1847</b> Though by no means faultless, the measure [1846 Constitution Act] seems calculated to be a fair opening to the true history of our great Southern Colony, after the preliminary chapters of tragi-comic blundering. It sweeps away the whole system of official machinery and self-impeding sophistry established by Lord Stanley - all the `Treaty of Waitangi' nonsense, and all the past Downing-Street plans for hindering the settlement of the islands.' ## spang-weazling
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1953</b> Perhaps the most intriguing game of this nature [sc. tormenting insects or animals] is `Spang Weazling'. This game was played at Denniston in 1930-35. A crawley was placed on the end of a stick the middle section of which lay balanced over a stone. Before the crawley could crawl off the stick a stone had to be thrown onto the other end of the stick so as to catapult the crawley off the stick and over the cliff. A variation of the same game was being played at Denniston when I visited there in 1949. It was called alternatively `Hit the Crawley' or `Strike the Crayfish'. In this version the other end of the stick was hit with a batting stick (as in Tip Cat) and when the crawley was catapulted into the air it was hit again with the bat. (Unorganized Games,1/406)

## Spaniard
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sharp-spiked native plant of spp. Aciphylla that grows in high tussock country. [also wild Spaniard] (See [giant Spaniard](../G#giant-spaniard),[bloody Spaniard](../B#bloody-spaniard),[wild Spaniard](../W#wild-spaniard))

>  <b>1856</b> <i>W.H.S. ROBERTS</i> Writing of the Waimea Plain in 1856: - `The ground was well grassed, but the speargrass was too plentiful. The pasturage was very good. There was a good deal of scrub in the bends of the Mataura known as `wire plant' (Olearia virgata). There were also manuka and koromiko. Maori-heads, a kind of grass tree about three feet high, abounded in the swamps, and in some we saw toitoi grass and raupo. We did not pass any cabbage trees to-day ... we proceeded slowly through tomatakuru scrub, speargrass, Spaniard, snowgrass, and other native grasses ... we camped in a bend with good feed at the Elbow and a swamp on one side. Maori cabbage abounded ...' (Diary) [NOTES: 1856 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 18]

>  <b>1978</b> <i>McARA</i> <i>Spalling</i>: Breaking up large rocks with a 12 lb hammer to make them easier to handle. (Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),332)

## spawn
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Feb 3, 1841</b> <i>WEEKES</i> A very strange appearance presented itself in the water this morning - streaks of a muddy yellow colour extending for miles. Supposing it to be caused by animalculae I had a bucketful drawn on deck. The water was full of them, having a transparent body with a row of yellow spots round the head. They had long tentaculae, and moved briskly through the water backwards, which motion was effected by ejecting water from two openings situated at the base of the tentaculae. These creatures are generally called [32] `spawn' by sailors; being by them considered the spawn of fish and the food of whales. (Journal) [NOTES: 1841 Feb 3 Weekes Journal in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 31-32]

## SPCZ
 
 <i>abbr.</i> South Pacific Convergence Zone [ORIGIN: acronym]

>  <b>(26/0/2005)</b> To get an early fix on how the cyclone season will shape up, meteorologists look to what is known as the South Pacific Convergence Zone (SPCZ) - a long line of clouds and rain that forms where the south-east trade winds meet the easterly Pacific winds. (Dominion Post,E2)



## speak up
 
 <i>exclam.</i> (Rural) a command given to a dog to bark.

>  <b>1981</b> <i>LOUGHNAN</i> speak up: the command for a dog to bark. (Loughnan Glossary,76)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [mustering dogs] to bark in order to locate other dogs or musterers.

>  <b>1940</b> <i>STUDHOLME</i> There are numerous little tricks of the trade that make for a successful muster, such as raising a smoke occasionally to show where you are, making a dog `speak up', ... (Te Waimate,119,1954 ed.)

>  <b>1990</b> <i>GIBSON</i> I made the dogs speak up (bark) but the reply was only another weak single bark. (Among the High Hills of Canterbury,76)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [pig or deer hunting dogs] to bark when they have found their quarry.

>  <b>1996</b> <i>NGAWHIKA</i> We sat there in the moonlight, engulfed in the silence of a lovely warm summer's night, waiting for one of the dogs to 'speak up,' but as time passed we knew they had moved out of earshot. (Tell Them I've Gone Pighunting,71)

## spear
 
 <i>v.</i>

>  <b>1955</b> <i>BOWEN</i> ..., shearers started to `spear' the belly off, usually by laying the sheep almost flat on its back. ... From there the faster men developed spearing the belly off with the sheep in a more upright position. (Wool Away!,21)



 
 <i>n.</i> applied to Maori or Moriori weapons (often erroneously)

>  <b>Aug 7, 1878</b> Yesterday morning on opening the Lands Court, after two days' adjournment to give the natives time to send in their names for certificates for the Kaingaroa Block lately passed through the Court, and awarded to several hapus, the Tapuaka and Ngatipakio hapus, headed by Te Pokiha, and all armed with spears and other weapons, took possession of the Court House. (Evening Post,2)

>  <b>Feb 12, 1777</b> <i>EDGAR</i> Their Weapons consists of Spears darts and battle Axes & Patoo Patoos - the Patoo Patoo's is an instrument made of bone of large Fish or Stone -it is in shape of a battledore [cf WADDY 1]& about 16 or 18 Inches long, (Log) [NOTES: 1777 Feb 12 Edgar's Log in 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/225]

>  <b>1777</b> <i>FORSTER</i> ... we heard a loud hallooing on ... an island, which on this occasion obtained the name of Indian Island; and standing on the shore we perceived one of the natives ... He stood with a club or battle-axe in his hand, ... and behind him ... two women, each of them having a long spear. ... held a long speech ... swing round his club, on which he leaned at other times. (Voyage Round the World,1/137)

>  <b>Nov 29, 1791</b> But both their Spears and Clubs were subject to great variety. Some of the Spears were very long and pointed only at one end, without much neatness. Their Clubs were rough pieces of Wood, ... and a very few had two stones lashed on at one end, which gave them the appearance of a double-headed maul. (Journal of Voyage in HMS 'Chatham') [NOTES: [a Moriori spear] 1791 Nov 29 Journal of the Chathamin 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/506]

>  <b>1807</b> <i>SAVAGE</i> The spear ... is nearly thirty feet long; it is made of hard wood, and is sometimes pointed at each extremity, but not universally. (New Zealand (various authors/titles),66)

>  <b>Mar 24, 1826</b> <i>SHEPHERD</i> Tommy said it was next to impossible to attack a New Zealander with a sword ... as they have a method of pushing such weapons aside ... and generally kill the person with a Maree or axe or spear before he has time to make a second thrust. (Journal) [NOTES: 1826 Mar 24 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 364]

>  <b>1833</b> <i>SHERIDAN</i> ... in former days when in battle ... [they had] only their own implements of destruction - spears, nipes, and an instrument made out of beautiful blue or green marble stone, which they call a Mary, none but a chief is allowed to take them to battle, they are very scarce and very dear. (Letter) [NOTES: 1833 Sheridan Letter from <i>Sydney Monitor</i> in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 48]

>  <b>1835</b> Most of these men had their stone marees (axes) slung to their wrists, and their spears placed in order ... (Boultbee Journal,82,1986 ed.)

>  <b>1835</b> <i>YATE</i> (New Zealand (various authors/titles),112)

>  <b>1904</b> <i>TREGEAR</i> The principal weapon of the Maori warrior was the spear (<i>tao</i>). A short spear of from four to six feet in length was the almost invariable appurtenance of a chief ... (Maori Race, The,308)

>  <b>Jul 20, 1913</b> Planted Ake rautangi [dodona viscosa] the leaves that weep for ever. The wood of this tree, not a large tree, is hard and tough and took a keen edge and was cultivated by the Maori for spears and battle axes. (Chudleigh Diary,463,1950 ed.)

>  <b>Nov 2, 1892</b> With his 'mere,' Tohi smites; / With his spear, brave Mohi fights. (Observer (Auckland),17)



 
 <i>n.</i> gum-spear

>  <b>1873</b> <i>TINNE</i> They generally work in parties ... taking it in turn to remain at home to ... scrape the gum clean ... The first time I saw them at work with their gum-spears, they puzzled me ... The `spear' is simply a spike of iron, about a foot long, on the end of a pole ... (Wonderland of the Antipodes,54)

>  <b>1882</b> <i>HAY</i> For work, each man straggles about all day by himself, with his spear and spade and such. He tries every likely looking place with his spear, which is simply an iron rod, sharp at one end, and with a wooden handle at the other. (Brighter Britain,2/26)

>  <b>1901</b> The spear is a long, slender piece of steel, four-sided and tapering to a point. When set in a handle it is easily driven into the soft ground, and the grating of the point will tell when it has touched gum. (NZ Illustrated Magazine,3/208)

## spearfish
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1943</b> <i>BENNETT</i> A <i>spell </i> in New Zealand means a period of rest, rather than of work, and `to have a spell' is to take a rest; in this sense it is probably a remnant of the speech of the New Bedford and Nantucket whalers who once frequented New Zealand waters, `spell oh!' being recorded (in <i>Moby Dick </i>, for example) as a call to cease work or strenuous exercise. [fn.] 15. It is thus much older than `l.C. 19-20,' the date given in Partridge,<i> op. cit.</i>, p. 807, and possibly it is many centuries older; cf. <i>The Owl and the Nightingale,</i> l. 258, `lat thine tunge habben spale' where <i>spale </i>is more appropriately translated by `rest' than by Skeat's `turn of work.'  <i>n.</i> (See [cf. spot v](../S#spot-v),[spoiling; gridironing](../S#spoiling;-gridironing))

>  <b>1968</b> <i>OLIVER</i> The runholder was protected against intruders: cottages, fences and homesteads gave him a pre-emptive right over a set number of contiguous acres. Fences and cottages could be so disposed as to give the runholder rights over the best of the land - sources of water and wood, strips surrounding isolated and thus inaccessible pockets. `Grid-ironing' and `spotting', as these selective practices were called, were certainly used by many runholders to tie up large areas, but probably not to the extent alleged by horrified land tenure radicals in later years. (Story of New Zealand, The,108)

>  <b>1949</b> <i>CRAWFORD</i> `Gridironing' was the practice of buying twenty acre sections fronting on a road, so spaced as to leave sections of nineteen acres between them, and as these had to be auctioned the small farmer stood litttle chance of outbidding the run-holder who usually retained them without having to purchase them. `Spotting' was buying up key positions, fertile land, and leaving the barren, water courses, entrances to valleys, road lines, ... . (Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury,94)

>  <b>1948</b> <i>SCOTTER</i> When investigating the change from pastoral lease to freehold in any locality, the student, brought up on Pember Reeves (see e.g. S.E.I. [State Experiments 1902] 234) searches immediately for evidences of the methods by which the runholder retained his grasp of the land. These practices called gridironing and spotting can be defended: there is no need to do so here. If spotting is practiced - the purchase of selected areas with water and shelter for the control this gave over the surrounding country - a study of the Crown grant index maps and of the dates of the original titles supplies no evidence of it. (Run, Estate and Farm,13)

>  <b>1856</b> <i>CARR</i> The practice of which I speak is called in New Zealand <i>`spotting'</i> or <i>`spoiling'</i> country. [???a verbal not nominal use] (Waste Lands of Wellington, The,30)

>  <b>1865</b> <i>Green</i>, one of the settlers, is endeavouring to purchase land in various places <i>spotting ... . </i> (McLean Papers,25/132 [1866 xxv/139]) [NOTES: (Harris, Tauranga)]

>  <b>1981</b> <i>CRAWFORD</i> McLean brought to light some of the pitfalls of spot freeholding when he wrote in September 1970: The promiscuous `spotting' of this run with small blocks of freehold ... [sic] may have in a measure attained the primary object of excluding extensive purchase ... (Station Years,47) [NOTES: 1870 Sep in 1981 Crawford Station Years 47]

>  <b>1898</b> <i>MORRIS</i> <i>Spotting, n.</i> New Zealand equivalent for the Australian `picking the eyes out,' and `peacocking.' Under <i>Free-selection</i> (q.v.), the squatter spotted his run, purchasing choice spots. (Austral English,431)

>  <b>1929</b> spotting <i>n</i>. selecting the best parts of an area; peacocking.-spot v.t. (Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,11)

>  <b>1938</b> <i>BURDON</i> The other and yet more harmful method was to buy isolated sections all over a run to prevent or hinder large purchases by anyone else; to pick out the fertile and leave the barren; to take the grain and leave the husk. This was called `spotting.' (High Country,123)

>  <b>1941</b> <i>BAKER</i> <i>Spotting</i> was applied to provinces other than Canterbury ... It was probably formed on the basis of the Australian terms <i>pick the eyes out of the country</i> and <i>peacocking. </i> (NZ Slang,26)

>  <b>1959</b> <i>SINCLAIR</i> `Spotting' was the purchase of strategic points, such as the mouth of a gorge, river-banks and other watering-places, so as to exclude rivals from large areas of adjacent land. (History of New Zealand,156)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>spotting N.</i> in New Zealand selecting the choicest parts of an area, picking the eyes out and leaving the poorer parts. See gridironing. (NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),625)

>  <b>1968</b> <i>spotting ... n.</i> in N.Z., selecting the choicest parts of an area, picking the eyes out, and leaving the poorer parts. See <i>gridironing. </i> (NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),18)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a purchase of scattered strategic and productive areas of land to dissuade other purchasers.

>  <b>1859</b> <i>FULLER</i> For the capitalist, by what is colonially termed 'spotting a Run', that is, picking out parts of it only to buy, may command the pasturage of the whole of the remaining portion ... (Five Years' Residence in New Zealand,72)

(Letter) [NOTES: a1843 (1837-1843) Best's letters in Mitchell Library undated newspaper article in Journal (1966) 410]

## stamp
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>1978</b> <i>McARA</i> <i>Stamps</i>: The stamps pulverised the ore after it had passed through the crushers and been reduced to minus-two-and-a-half-inch size. They crushed it to a pulp, with water, until it passed through the 10-mesh (to the linear inch) screens on the mortar-box. There were five stamps (each weighing 1250 lb) to a mortar-box and they operated at 110 drops a minute from a height of 8 ins, crushing approximately 7 tons per 24-hour-day. They were driven by a camshaft, tappets attached to the long stamp stems being lifted in a particular sequence and then the whole weight of the stamp allowed to fall on the ore. Wear of iron was approximately half a pound per ton of ore crushed; the shoes and dies were cast in the Waikino foundry. (Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),333)

>  <b>1887</b> <i>HOPEFUL</i> [Colonial slang] When one friend meets another very often the greeting will [135] be, `Are you going to stand `shout'?' in other words, `Are you going to stand drink or `treat'?' If this is agreed to they will adjourn to the nearest inn, or hotels as these poor little match-boxes are called; and in fact there is a great deal of standing `shout' in the Colonies, both in public and in private. (Taken In,134)

>  <b>1950</b> <i>JOSEPH</i> Live in a state house, raise forcibly-educated children/ Receive family benefits, and standard wages ... (Imaginary Islands,25) [NOTES: (`Secular Litany')]

>  <b>1979</b> a house built and owned by the State for rental at a low rate to the public (Heinemann NZ Dictionary,1074)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>TURNER</i> ... <i>state houses</i> (owned and let by the government) are <i>occasionally</i> double-unit <i>houses</i>. (English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,172)

>  <b>1982</b> <i>state house n. N.Z.</i> a house built by the government and rented to a state tenant. Brit. equivalent: <i>council house. </i> (Collins Concise English Dictionary,1135) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 750; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 472]]

>  <b>Dec 20, 1986</b> `State houses' - the words have a Kiwi magic. ... A nation grew up on the notion of <i>Savage, Semple</i> and <i>Lee</i> - immortalised in a famous photograph - carrying furniture into the first state house in 1937. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

>  <b>Oct 17, 1987</b> [caption] September 18, 1937: John A. Lee and Michael Savage carried the table into the first state house [12 Fife Lane]. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

>  <b>Dec 21, 1942</b> A State house, a State farm, a State high chair and cot and State education for the occupants thereof. (NZEF Times,2)

>  <b>1985</b> <i>McGILL</i> This was where people moved from rundown Wellington suburbs after the war, in the big state house drive. (G'day Country,77)

>  <b>Oct 17, 1987</b> Maybe it wasn't even the first house occupied under the reforming Labour Government's state house scheme ... (Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

>  <b>Nov 3, 1919</b> Tenders have been let for 50 State houses in Wellington and Masterton. (Thames Star,2)

>  <b>Jan 28, 1984</b> That's the sort of situation I grew up in, a working-class household, five kids in a small state house, and all my peers, and we're not deprived. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

>  <b>1998</b> <i>IRELAND</i> This was early 1950s New Zealand. The nation was a huge baby farm. State houses were being built by the thousands. (Under the Bridge & Over the Moon,148)

>  <b>May 15, 1946</b> Already 714 square feet of brickwork had been completed, utilising just nearly enough bricks for a State House. (People's Voice,1)

>  <b>1941</b> <i>SUTCH</i> In the building of State houses of high quality a suggestion as to necessary standards has been made. (Poverty & Progress in NZ,153)

>  <b>1978</b> After years of waiting, they got a State house last summer. (Islands,15)

>  <b>Oct 5, 1996</b> [Marilyn Waring says] Although I wouldn't mind living in the two big state houses - a gay governor-general! (Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

>  <b>Nov 21, 1992</b> When I left that state house, Romona says, I left it a whole lot better than when I found it. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),39)

>  <b>Jul 29, 2001</b> They look bloody awful, like run-down state houses. (Sunday Star Times,A3)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>Bernard Gadd</i> This state house had been empty a long time. The grass was about half a metre high, and rags of dirty curtains hung in the windows. (Where to Go?,63)

>  <b>Jan 29, 2003</b> Many Wellingtonians grew up in a state house. Wainuiomata, Porirua East, Naenae, Epuni, Taita, Miramar and Strathmore Park are all state house suburbs. And there are many pockets of state houses scattered through other suburbs such as Khandallah, Karori and Northland. (Capital Times,5)

>  <b>1995</b> <i>ELDRED-GRIGG</i> The families in our street were better off than the families who lived in state houses. Kids from state houses sat alongside us in the classroom, and played with us in the playground, and looked and talked like us - but we always knew who came from a state house. (Mum,43)

>  <b>Jun 24, 2000</b> Most of our fathers commuted into Wellington to work, the stout state houses were home to nearly everyone, the people in general were hard doers and the kids, by and large, were tough outdoor types. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

>  <b>Oct 2, 1920</b> He knew that the timber was required in Christchurch, and the Government themselves wanted it for the contractor who was building 70 or 80 State houses there. (Ashburton Guardian,6)

>  <b>Feb 1, 1937</b> STATE HOUSES .. It is anticipated that tenders will be called for the building of Government houses at Orakei about February 9. (Evening Post,10)

>  <b>Jun 26, 1947</b> We had moved from a friendly little suburb to a "Government block" where we are surrounded by State Houses. (NZ Woman's Weekly: The First 60 Years,16)

>  <b>Mar 1954</b> Put them in State Houses, give them Social Security and they're still restless. (Landfall,8(1) No. 29: 18)

## state integrated school
 
 <i>n.</i> a religious school joining the state education system on terms that protects its "special character" under the Private Schools Conditional Integration Act of 1975. [headword not present in the citation]

>  <b>Nov 2001</b> The long-term effect of these developments was to convince Norman Kirk and his third Labour Government (1972-75) to pass the Private Schools Conditional Integration Act (1975), which allowed religious schools to join the state education system, on terms that protected their "special character". (NZ Geographic,No. 54/29)



## state of bob
 
 <i>phr.</i> a state of excitement, confusion; a state of nerves or trepidation. [ca1935 Havelock]

>  <b>Jul 26, 1862</b> We struck the river opposite the A.C. house and came out 5 miles up the stream. Cooper and I had a swim and we were always in a state of bob. (Chudleigh Diary,50,1950 ed.)



## state school
 
 <i>n.</i> any primary or secondary school financed and maintained at public expense for the education of all the children and youth of a district.

>  <b>Sep 24, 1864</b> We see that a measure is before them which aims at establishing a system of State schools in the long run, while giving aid to the schools already established by the religious denominations or others; and even sanctioning and subsidizing the establishment of new schools by similar means, apart from the system specially encouraged. (Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,4)

>  <b>Oct 25, 1872</b> .. that there shall be no right of denominational interference or control in State schools, and that the educational system shall be brought directly under the control and supervision of Parliament. (Evening Post,2)

>  <b>Jan 18, 1921</b> The question of free carriage of private school children on the railways ought to be considered. This was taking away bread and butter from those who were connected with the State school system. (Ashburton Guardian,5)

>  <b>Sep 23, 1902</b> A society was formed last night for the promotion of Bible teaching in State schools. (Hawera & Normanby Star,3)

>  <b>Sep 12, 1895</b> " .. I would not ask them to move to get the Bible, or any Irish or any other textbook of religion pushed into our State schools ..." (Marlborough Express,4)

>  <b>Nov 27, 1890</b> Take one of them (sc. a child), send him through the State schools, then the secondary, and give him a year or two at our universities. (Otago Witness,16)

>  <b>Oct 27, 1885</b> The pupil of a State school is not told that one form of Government is better than another. (Wairarapa Daily,2)

>  <b>Mar 31, 1993</b> We'd.. kick schoolbags across the grounds and bounce stones at the proddy cats from the State school down the road. (NZ Tablet,33)

>  <b>Dec 13, 1879</b> Though the State schools were denounced by Archbishop Vaughan as "seed-plots of future immorality, infidelity, and lawlessness, calculated to debase the standard of human excellence, and to corrupt the political, social, and individual life of future citizens," some five hundred Roman Catholic teachers occupied the fattest appointments in them without incurring the censure of the Church. (Auckland Weekly News,8) [NOTES: With reference to the Australian system]

>  <b>Nov 27, 1847</b> However, in most Christian nations, that is, in those nations of which the great majority of those who profess to believe in any religion have adopted Christianity, it will probably be found to be in accordance with the wishes of the people that religious knowledge should be taught in the State schools. (Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,152)

>  <b>1965</b> <i>McLAGLAN</i> A State school was improvised for the children. (Stethoscope & Saddlebags,180)

>  <b>1979</b> a school organised and financed by the [state]. (Heinemann NZ Dictionary,1074)

>  <b>1988</b> <i>JACKSON</i> We had just moved into a State House ... (Rainshadow,3)

>  <b>1882</b> <i>ANDERSON</i> Had he the advantages that every State school now gives, I will warrant he would have made such good use of them that I question whether Pitt's Island would have held him. (Chatham Islands, The,24)

>  <b>Aug 4, 1911</b> Many persons think that the only objection to the introduction of Bible teaching into our State schools is the fact that our community is so divided in religious opinion. (Maoriland Worker,3)

>  <b>Nov 3, 1898</b> A case of interest to State School teachers was begun in the Court of Appeal yesterday. (NZ Times,2)

>  <b>Dec 2, 1924</b> The boys go to the State school, and are getting on. (Otago Witness,30)

## State tenant
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Apr 8, 1882</b> AT some time in the future, when the land question shall have been satisfactorily settled by the wiping out of freeholds, and by making every man, woman, and child in the colony a compulsory state tenant of fifty acres of land, with a "pay as you please" clause in the leases, and the cruelty of an eviction swept away for ever, the position of the people will be somewhat different from what it is under the present crude and unsatisfactory system in which the relations of landlord and tenant, and of master and man, if not in full force, retain at least a portion of their ancient vitality. (Wanganui Chronicle,2)

## Staten Landt
 
 <i>n.</i> original Dutch name for New Zealand

It has been used in both these senses in Australia (whence the word came) since the 'thirties. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (1) The original sense is still preserved up country, where the men always speak of <i>in at the s</i>., when they are out on the run; also in the word <i>out-s</i>. (q.v.), which has no other meaning than the house, yards etc. (2) The secondary sense of a property with freehold, leasehold, buildings, and stock. (5) Since the 1890s, auctioneers in their advertisements have taken to speaking of <i>s. lines</i> of sheep, though 70 per cent. of those so designated at the autumn ewe fairs come from farms or grazing runs. >  <b>1947</b> <i>BEATTIE</i> The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. In this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late `fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.' (Early Runholding in Otago,11)

>  <b>Jul 21, 1856</b> It is usually understood that in the early days the word `station' denoted the owner's house and its immediate buildings, while `run' meant the whole property. Strange to say, I only noted the word `station' twice, and each time with a diverse meaning. On July 21, 1865, the diary says: `Sold 17 head of cattle - remaining on station 15 head.' Then on September 11, 1865, we read: `Wilkinson returned to the Home Station.' The first of these entries means the whole run - the second the homestead or main buildings. (Puketoi Station Diary) [NOTES: 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 115 quoting 1856 July 21 Puketoi Station Diary]

So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.' ## steelie

There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. (NZ Yesterdays,288)

## Stephen(s) Island wren
 
 <i>n.</i> the extinct Traversia lyalli [also as Island wren (1897 below)]

>  <b>1897</b> (Buller)<i> Xenicus insularis </i>, Buller. (Island Wren.) Very diligent search has been made on Stephen Island for further specimens of the Island Wren, but without success ... (TrNZI,29/,188 ed.)

>  <b>1923</b> <i> Traversia lyalli </i> Roths. Stephen Island Wren. No reports of the Stephen Island wren have been recorded since its supposed extinction by lighthouse-keepers' cats soon after its discovery. (NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/87) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

>  <b>1936</b> <i>GUTHRIE-SMITH</i> ... there might yet lurk furtive in the scrub the Stephen Island Wren (<i> Traversia lyalli </i>). (NZ Naturalist,93)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>McLINTOCK</i> A small bird of similar colouring and size [to the rock wren], but of a different genus, <i> Traversia lyallii </i>, now extinct, was known as the Stephen Island wren. Several specimens of this bird were recorded in 1894, but it has not been seen since. (Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/689)

>  <b>1970</b> 242. <i> Xenicus lyalli </i>(Rothschild, 1894)<i> Stephen Island Wren </i> (Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,64,1980 ed.)

>  <b>2004</b> [Hdg]The tale of the lighthouse-keeper's cat: Discovery and extinction of the Stephens Island wren (<i>Traversia lyalli</i>)... The Stephens Island wren <i>Traversia lyalli</i> is widely quoted as having been discovered and promptly exterminated from its only locality, Stephens Island, New Zealand, by a single lighthouse-keeper's cat. Examination of archival and museum records indicates that this account is oversimplified... (Notornis,51(4): 193) [NOTES: Galbreath & Brown]

>  <b>Feb 29, 1916</b> The following birds are now extinct, or very nearly so, some only to be found in un-get-at-able places to the human, but not to the stoat and its relatives, or luckily on the sanctuaries: The saddleback .. the Stephens Island wren .. and stitch bird. (Evening Post,3)
