## Stewart Island oyster
 
 <i>n.</i> aka Stewart Islander (Bluff oyster, dredge oyster, Foveaux Strait oyster [from the southernmost major island of New Zealand]

>  <b>Jan 29, 1864</b> While spending money to introduce salmon, do not let us by our own carelessness lose the Stewart's Island oyster, which we much fear will be the case unless some steps are at once taken to stop the wholesale destruction which is at present taking place, not only from residents here, but from Otago. (Southland Times,2)

>  <b>1898</b> <i>MORRIS</i> name given to the oyster, <i>Ostrea chiloensis</i>, Sowerby; so called because it is specially abundant on Stewart Island off the south coast of New Zealand. The Stewart Island forms are mud oysters, those of Sydney Cove growing on rock. See <i>Oyster. </i> (Austral English,436)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>Stewart Island oyster n.</i> New Zealand oyster, abundant on Stewart Island. (NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),625)

>  <b>May 25, 1918</b> Nobody knows exactly how the debate began; ... but probably every member of the N.Z.E.F. on Gallipoli took part in the discussion of the oyster question : Auckland v. Stewart Island. ... whether the delicacy and daintiness of the little rock were better or worse than the noble fatness of the Stewart. (Quick March,1)

>  <b>1919</b> <i>WAITE</i> The oyster question raged furiously. ... with an Aucklander present, it was never safe to say that Stewart Island oysters were the finest in the sea. (New Zealanders at Gallipoli,182)

>  <b>Aug 10, 1921</b> ... just mention Stewart Island oysters ... (Quick March,31)

>  <b>1934</b> THE STEWART ISLAND OYSTER (Ostrea angasi). (NZ Journal of Science & Technology,15/395)

>  <b>1947</b> <i>SMITH</i> Stewart Island oysters are very popular especially with Scotsmen with large families - (From N to Z,35)

>  <b>1947</b> <i>POWELL</i> STEWART ISLAND OYSTER (<i>Ostrea sinuata</i>). Occurs throughout New Zealand and is usually found unattached on mud in shallow water and to a depth of about fifteen fathoms. The richest beds of these shellfish are in Foveaux Strait, from 10 to 15 fathoms, where they are extensively dredged by a fleet of small vessels operating from the port of Bluff. (Native Animals of NZ,20)

>  <b>1962</b> <i>BEAGLEHOLE</i> [fn]Possibly... they were <i>Ostrea sinuata</i>, which occurs throughout New Zealand, but in the largest beds in Foveaux Strait - whence its popular name of Stewart Island Oyster. But they may have been `Auckland Rock' Oysters, (Banks Journal,1/431)

>  <b>1964</b> <i>DEMPSEY</i> It was sad to have to disillusion these nice people and confess that we rarely saw an oyster, unless we crossed over to the Other Side and saw them in the fish shops of Invercargill. The far-famed Stewart Island oysters are dredged from Foveaux Strait ... (Little World of Stewart island,92)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>McLINTOCK</i> Stewart Island Oyster .. .. tio, tio para, tio-repe .. .. <i>Ostrea angasi </i> (Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

>  <b>1971</b> <i>Oyster, Ostrea angasi</i> found throughout New Zealand; commonly known as Stewart Island oyster (New Zealand's Heritage,1/71)

>  <b>1982</b> <i>BURTON</i> A lesser-known name for the Bluff oyster is the Stewart Island oyster ... (Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,70)

>  <b>1986</b> <i>PAUL</i> <i>Dredge oyster Tiostrea lutaria</i> ... Alternatively Bluff, Foveaux Strait, or Stewart Island oyster. Native to New Zealand, with a similar species in Chile. <i>Ostrea glomerata </i>Gould, an admirably delicate species. (NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,166)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>WILSON</i> BLUFF-OYSTER: The Bluff or Stewart Island Oyster is the gourmet's delight and its annual harvest in awaited throughout the country with much interest. (Fisherman's Bible,171)

>  <b>Oct 10, 1901</b> [reprinted from the London Daily Express] The oyster which New Zealand is sending over is known in the antipodes as the Stewart Island oyster. (Hawera & Normanby Star,4)

>  <b>May 14, 1904</b> "Two shillings' worth of Stewart Island please, and be sure the pearls are black." "Yes mum; certainly!" (NZ Free Lance,12)

>  <b>Jul 2, 1879</b> The Oyster Season commences on the 1st April, on and after which date I shall be prepared to supply an unlimited number of Stewart Island Oysters, at 1s. per dozen. (Tuapeka Times,4)

>  <b>Oct 21, 1872</b> STEWART ISLAND OYSTERS, Ex Taranaki. (Evening Post,3)

 <i>n.</i>

 <i>v.</i> in phr. stuck up with porpoises: of a whale, to be slowed by playful porpoises

>  <b>1982</b> <i>GRADY</i> <i>Stuck-up with porpoises</i> - Porpoises that have slowed a swimming whale down by playing with it. This assisted the whalers. (Perano Whalers)



 
 <i>v.</i> to bring (a vehicle, thing, a person, a job) to a standstill (often in passive form: be, get stuck up) [(1) The regular word for the action of bush-rangers stopping passers-by on the highway and robbing them.(2) In the case of a bank or a station, simply to rob. [1846] (3) Humorously applied to a collector or a beggar. In `Twenty - five Years of St. Andrews' (vol. ii. p. 87), A. K. H. B. tells a story of a church dignitary, who was always collecting money for church building. When a ghost appeared at Glamis Castle, addressing the ghost, the clergyman began - that `he was most anxious to raise money for a church he was erecting; that he had a bad cold and could not well get out of bed; but that his collecting-book was on the dressing-table, and he would be `extremely obliged' for a subscription.' An Australian would have said he `stuck up' the ghost for a subscription. [1890]]

>  <b>Jun 1860</b> - if you get stuck up by any creeks you'll very likely see cattle marks ... (a creek is a stream) but there is nothing that ought to stick you up at all if you keep out of the big swamp at the bottom of the valley. (Forest Flora,37,1960 ed.)

>  <b>Jul 9, 1862</b> The cow and steers stuck us up at the yards so we left them in the paddock. (Chudleigh Diary,47,1950 ed.)

>  <b>Feb 21, 1863</b> An old cow stuck me up about a mile from the stockyard ... Millett and I worked our whips well on her. When she rushed one, the other stock-whipped her. (Chudleigh Diary,78,1950 ed.)

>  <b>1863</b> <i>BUTLER</i> At last we came to a waterfall. This `stuck us up', as they say here concerning any difficulty. (First Year in Canterbury Settlement,64)

>  <b>1875</b> <i>MEREDITH</i> We started all right [on our journey], but had not got beyond the city boundary when the horses stuck us up. (Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,80,1935 ed.)

>  <b>1879</b> <i>WHITWORTH</i> ... when we told him ... we'd been stuck up by the water, he ... said ... `Ah, stuck up, were you?' (Spangles and Sawdust,26)

>  <b>1884</b> <i>REID</i> Push on or you will be stuck up. Not by bushrangers, ... but by time and tide which wait for no man. At the first opportunity he `stuck up the mail' ... merely to secure a passage to town (Rambles on the Golden Coast,73)

And when the last is scrubbed and the chain is switched off, going down for a shower ... I'd like to see them on the chain. Even the learners' chain. In that narrow cell of concrete with the lambs swinging in quick time up the ramp from the sticking-pen ... Lambs hooked on to the chain and progressing slowly along while the row of men standing alongside slash and tear and nick with knives while others punch briskets or pull the skins from the swinging carcases. More men rip out the guts and throw the heart and liver on to the small-goods table ... and the skins and innards and hooves and ears all go by chutes to the departments below. <i>Ibid.</i> 227 The tourists ... never see the dogs running over the backs of the sheep jammed in the saleyards or the pet sheep leading them slyly up the ramp into the sticking pen at the works ... Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. (Folkgames of Children,174)

>  <b>1984</b> <i>KEITH & MAIN</i> Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles. (Yesterdays in Maoriland,288)

>  <b>1987</b> Stinkies - these were marbles made from clay, they did not work very well. (Alfredton,75) [NOTES: Quote from c1935]

>  <b>1992</b> <i>PARK</i> One steelie to twenty-four ordinary clay stinkers was what I charged, and a fair price it was. (Fence Around the Cuckoo,62)

>  <b>1962</b> <i>ADSETT</i> Sixpence was a hell of a lot of money when you come to think of it. Worth about twenty marbles, more if they were only stinkies. (Magpie Sings, A,124)

## stock unit
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Mar 22, 1997</b> A few more years of graft and, by March 1994, they could afford 184ha of Manawatu hill country, running 1800 stock units. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a measure of land's carrying-capacity [ the annual feed requirements of an animal, e.g. 1 ewe = 1.0 SU, 1 Jersey cow = 6.0 SU. One stock unit requires approx 520 kg of good quality pasture dry matter per year.]

>  <b>Apr 20, 1928</b> Eighty years ago New Zealand was without grazing animals or herbage, but to-day its stock unit was 71 as compared with 100 of the Mother Country. (Evening Post,8)

>  <b>1982</b> <i>MAF</i> Stock unit .. also referred to as ewe equivalent. It is the feed requirement used as the basis of comparison for different classes and species of stock. It expresses the annual feed requirements equivalent to one 55 kg ewe rearing a single lamb. (MAF Agricultural Glossary,7)

>  <b>Aug 1984</b> Stock units are based on the conversion ratios first recommended by Professor Coop from Linclon College in 1965. These ratios are ewes per head 1.0, hoggest [sic] 0.6, others per head 0.8, cows per head 6.0.. (NZ Journal of Agriculture,28)

>  <b>Sep 1986</b> Steers are equivalent to about six stock units ... (NZ Journal of Agriculture,8)

>  <b>1987</b> <i>GORDON</i> One young couple is running over 20,000 stock units in a low labour system that was established by a lot of hard work ... (People, Places & Paddocks,46)

>  <b>Apr 28, 2004</b> In the sheep pens store lambs made good money, however fat lambs were in the buyer's favour mainly because of the back log of lambs waiting to go to the freezing works. (Wairarapa News,13)



## store market
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sale of store animals.

>  <b>May 10, 2002</b> .. on Wednesday farmers flooded the store market at Stortford Lodge with 8000 lambs ... (Dominion,16)



## store pen
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sale pen of livestock that require fattening or finishing.

>  <b>Aug 8, 1996</b> .. in the store pens the best line made $67.20. (NZ Farmer,35)



## store sheep farmer
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a hill country farmer who runs sheep to sell to finishing farmers and for wool.

>  <b>1961</b> <i>REED</i> The store sheep farmer produces wool and some store lambs, and sells his older ewes to the fat lamb farmer. (Pastoral Farming in New Zealand,14)



## store sheep run
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a property that is basically a grazing and breeding pastoral property, where stock are sold for finishing.

>  <b>1965</b> <i>GASCOIGNE</i> Between the shearing shed practice of the store sheep run and the fat lamb farm there should be a fundamental difference so far as the owner or manager is concerned. (From the Top of a Hill,165)



## store stock
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [sp. use] lambs, sheep and cattle that have the potential to be fattened or finished.

>  <b>Aug 18, 1900</b> At the Newmarket yards, on Tuesday, dairy and store stock were penned in usual numbers. (Hawera Star,4)

>  <b>Aug 4, 2001</b> The property is run in conjunction with a 3500 acre breeding unit at Rangiwahia and serves as the finishing unit for the store stock produced on the Rangiwahia farm. (Dominion,33)

>  <b>Nov 7, 2002</b> Over many decades the Waverley district was a key area for priming stock and provided a home for a significant portion of the province's store stock. The bulk of the store stock movement out of the province is to the southern regions of Wanganui, Rangitikei, Manawatu, and Hawke's Bay. (Taranaki Daily News,13)



## store-conditioned
 
 <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of livestock] that require finishing or fattening.

>  <b>Aug 8, 1996</b> Mated ewes that were in better order met a firm sale while the old store conditioned dry ewes for finishing had a strong demand. Store conditioned dry ewes - light $18 to better at $26. (NZ Farmer,35)

>  <b>Aug 15, 1996</b> Store conditioned old ewes were $18 for light and aged store rams $16-$22 (NZ Farmer,35)

>  <b>Aug 22, 1996</b> Store-conditioned dry ewes sold to $20 for the best ... [store conditoned] (NZ Farmer,35)



## store-roll
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a style or method of rolling a wool-fleece, where the fleece is folded from both sides and rolled from both ends.

>  <b>1955</b> <i>BOWEN</i> The much-used store-roll, where the fleece is folded in from both sides, and then rolled from the ends, has the following disadvantages ... (Wool Away!,92)

>  <b>1955</b> <i>BOWEN</i> With the store-roll the bulk of the wool showing is back wool, which is not a fair example of the average fleece. (Wool Away!,94)

## storekeeping
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>Jan 26, 1907</b> This storekeeping business is all absolutely bally right, don't you know. (Observer (Auckland),19)

>  <b>Oct 18, 1944</b> For quite a number of years he and his brother ran a storekeeping business in Karori, then a sparsely-populated area. (Evening Post,6)

ISAACS, Importers of every description of Merchandise, are now prepared to supply the Trade only with the various goods required in General Storekeeping, comprising:- Manchester goods - Shirts. ## storm petrel
 
 <i>n.</i> (aka Jesus Christ bird, skipjack, dancing dolly, (all from its apparent ability to `walk' on water), =takahikaremoana ) a very small black seabird with a white rump, which follows ships and whose appearance was thought to announce a coming storm. [also storm bird]

>  <b>Oct 18, 1905</b> When seeing you two months ago, I promised to send you a couple of storm petrel's eggs. (Otago Witness,67)

>  <b>May 28, 1921</b> Birds that, like the albatross and storm petrel, live far out to sea except at nesting time, cannot obtain fresh water. (Ashburton Guardian,4)

>  <b>Oct 31, 1888</b> Came a storm petrel flying past; / Perched upon the bending mast. (Tuapeka Times,6)

>  <b>1917</b> <i>WILLIAMS</i> <i>Reoreo, ... Garrodia nereis, storm-petrel</i>. [so 1957/336 ...grey-backed storm petrel] (Dictionary of the Maori Language,391)

>  <b>1978</b> <i>HARPER & KINSKY</i> If.. the albatrosses.. and the storm petrels.. are separated from the other Procellariiformes, a large and varied assemblage of birds still remains: to many people these are the 'true' petrels. (Southern Albatrosses & Petrels,41)

>  <b>Jan 5, 1893</b> WHICH BIRD CAN LIVE THE LONGEST TIME WITHOUT WATER? - - The petrels, especially the Fulmar petrel, which rarely strays from the Arctic Ocean, and the storm petrel, which is met with in all parts of the world except very high nothern [sic] or southern latitudes. (Otago Witness,44)

>  <b>1982</b> <i>SALE</i> ... [The storm petrel] has many other names - skipjack, Dancing Dolly, frigate petrel - from the Pakeha; and takahikaremoana from the Maori. (Four Seasons,38)



## stoush
 
 <i>n.</i> [brawling; includes military and sports references as well as general interpersonal brawling, some fig.]

>  <b>Apr 13, 1912</b> Rugby is not a game of "stouch"... Theycannot be surprised if allegations of"stoush" are made against the name. (NZ Free Lance,24)

>  <b>Mar 9, 2000</b> When Ormrod took his idea to Sid Holland, the Prime Minister was fresh from his stoush over the waterfront lockout and wasn't much interested in dealing with an enthusiast who had been secretary of the local wharfies' band for 20 years. (Evening Post,7)

>  <b>Oct 20, 1923</b> Unquestionably the constable was wrong in dealing out stoush; a private citizen would have been wrong in so doing, but to err is human. (NZ Truth,6)

>  <b>Mar 3, 1900</b> Who gave H Mc stoush? (Observer (Auckland),21)

>  <b>Dec 1996</b> The popular impression of successive council-chamber stoushes is, in fact, erroneous. (North & South,97)

>  <b>Sep 26, 1999</b> Some people get gung-ho at the sight of soldiers and guns, at the thought of a stoush somewhere safely far away. (Sunday Star Times,D2)

>  <b>Oct 9, 1999</b> Through the veiled comments of bureaucrats, one detects that an almost stoush is going on behind the scenes over Kimberley. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

>  <b>Jun 22, 1901</b> But, then, the referee was not backed up by an Association and a Union. .. He heard any amount of "blanky" (in which his name was freely interspersed), and saw much "stouch." Did he order the offenders off? Not he. Knew better, had a family to keep. (New Zealand Free Lance,20)

>  <b>Aug 9, 1913</b> The proceedings in the House.. are what members politely call "stoush." (NZ Observer,3)

>  <b>Sep 13, 1913</b> Stoush? My oath! (NZ Observer,16)

>  <b>Jul 6, 1992</b> Everyone knew the worst stoush in history was looming [sc. in 1939] but no-one was game to throw the first punch. (Evening Post,6)

>  <b>May 12, 2001</b> Leo, together with ex-wife Sandra Lee.. fought the loop road stoush for years, but never once met the opposition. (Listener (New Zealand Listener),34)

>  <b>May 1, 1945</b> What's wrong? A stoush? Who's in it? (NZ Dairy Exporter,85)

>  <b>Mar 24, 1995</b> Hdg] Wharfies v Seagulls : Scene setfor big stoush on the Aucklandwaterfront. (Independent (Auckland),6)

>  <b>Dec 24, 1945</b> [Caption] You won't be forgetting Faenzain a hurry - Or the Stouch across theSenio, Santerno and Sillaro. (NZEF Times,IV/235 : 3)

>  <b>Aug 18, 2003</b> A small group of Hannon supporters then allegedly waded into the stoush with bottles. (Dominion Post,A2)

>  <b>Aug 8, 1919</b> We met opponents' boastsWith boots and stoush. (Hawke's Bay Herald,7)



 
 <i>v.</i> to fight, bash [stoush n. also stouch (1891 cit.) Also passive: to be fought, bashed.] (See [stoush n](../S#stoush-n))

>  <b>Sep 22, 1926</b> Py gorry, I go up Queen Street and stoush the first black man I see. (NZ Observer,3)

>  <b>Jul 17, 1901</b> And if any people want to try an' stoush your Royal pa, / We'll come an' 'elp 'im scrap 'em, every time! (West Coast Times,4)

>  <b>Aug 13, 1910</b> He began badly and got stoushed the whole way, eventually finishing well back. (NZ Truth,2)



 
 <i>adj.</i>

>  <b>Aug 2, 1913</b> A second medal was the special gift of two sports who were strong supporters of the Irish-Australian stoush artist. (NZ Truth,3)

>  <b>Oct 22, 1904</b> Maori is a most effective "stoush' [sic] language, and Mr. Kaihau used it with the skill of a pastmaster. (Evening Post,9)

## straggle
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [stragglers and wild sheep] to wander without direction.

>  <b>1921</b> <i>GUTHRIE-SMITH</i> In one way or another hundreds of sheep thus straggled from the run. (Tutira,140)

>  <b>1977</b> <i>WESTMACOTT</i> The sheep straggled up the valley and we followed ... (After-Breakfast Cigar, The,115)

>  <b>1987</b> <i>OGONOWSKA-COATES</i> .. sheep sometimes went wild, wandering the back country and straggling up the river flats. (Boards, Blades & Barebellies,11)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a small group of sheep evading muster.

>  <b>Aug 2002</b> These musterers who climbed several hundred metres around dawn to drive straggles of sheep down to the valley floor might work their way in time to be head musterer, foreman or manager, amd ultimately perhaps attain their own lease. (Forest & Bird,27)



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to find straggler sheep [and often to blade-shear bellies and under-necks so that they can walk out in a muster.]

>  <b>Dec 28, 1916</b> <i>MOWAT</i> McWhirter and self straggled the Trig. (Alexander Mowat Diaries)

>  <b>1953</b> <i>STRONACH</i> So after three days of mustering about the paddocks, with a dagging thrown in, we were glad to get away up Yoe Creek again to straggle the ewe country. To straggle a block of country means of course to muster in the stragglers. (Musterer on Molesworth,31)

>  <b>1977</b> <i>WESTMACOTT</i> In bush country they have to straggle the new burns after a first muster. (After-Breakfast Cigar, The,145)

>  <b>2000</b> <i>PETER</i> We straggle a block and trace the roughies as they usually have a double fleece. i.e. we muster for the stragglers and blade-shear bellies and under neck so they can walk out. (Peter Glossary)

>  <b>2001</b> <i>DOMINY</i> Now on occasion, when spotting or straggling, some run-holders save time by using a helicopter to drop them in the back country. (Calling the Station Home,169)



## straggle hunting
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) searching for straggler sheep

>  <b>1952</b> <i>NEWTON</i> His partner is a well-known flying man and is one of the originators of the practice of straggle hunting by air. (High Country Journey,13)



## straggle muster
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a secondary muster to collect stock missed in initial muster.

>  <b>Feb 1966</b> The local knowledge of each committee is and has been invaluable, particularly in ensuring proper mustering ands where necessary, subsequent 'straggle musters' before shearing and dipping operations. (NZ Journal of Agriculture,25)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to have a second muster to gather stragglers that have missed a first or main muster.

>  <b>1953</b> <i>STRONACH</i> For the rest of us, fifteen long days, if the weather kept fine, and then fifteen more days to straggle muster the same block. (Musterer on Molesworth,25)

>  <b>1964</b> <i>NEWTON</i> .. we finished up by straggle mustering the whole of the summer country again. (Straggle Muster,107)

>  <b>1980</b> <i>MACGREGOR</i> On one occasion we were out straggle mustering for sheep missed in the main muster. (Dog's Life, A,12)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>NEWTON</i> There was a good gang up the Ant.. at which the gang could camp during the fortnight the sheep were held there, and from which they could straggle-muster the rest of the country. (Boss's Story, The,38)



 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to clear the bar at closing time.

>  <b>Dec 15, 1983</b> Straggle muster - gathering sheep missed during the main muster. Also pertains to the [Dog Trial] Club Secretary on his third attempt at clearing the bar! [straggle] (NZ Journal of Agriculture,46)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) sheep that have missed an initial muster, and are gathered in the straggle muster.

>  <b>1989</b> <i>RICHARDS</i> Before leaving Otupae, Roger Pearce and I had been asked if we would return in three weeks to shear the 'straggle muster.' (Pioneer's Life, A,47)



## straggle tally
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a total number of sheep missed in an initial muster, but mustered in later.

>  <b>1947</b> <i>NEWTON</i> .. the Lake Coleridge station itself at that time shore 22,000 sheep and that season the straggle tally (sheep missed) was under 400. (Wayleggo,37)

>  <b>1964</b> <i>NEWTON</i> The other day the talk got round to 'straggle' tallies ( sheep missed in a muster.) I reckon that place must hold a world record for a straggle tally. (Straggle Muster,106)



## straggle-mustering
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a second gathering to collect stock missed in an initial muster.

>  <b>Feb 11, 1868</b> Straggle mustering. (Castle Station Diary,260) [NOTES: in Vance (1965) High Endeavour]

>  <b>1966</b> <i>NEWTON</i> This straggle-mustering after the autumn muster had never been practised at Mount White. (Boss's Story, The,38)



## straggler
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) 1.a sheep or cattle beast missed by a mustering team or a sheep or cattle beast that has strayed on to a neighbouring property, more common when natural boundaries preceded fences. 2. a ewe that is late to lamb; a late-lamber. 3. a slow-moving sheep at the back of a mob. (See [hermit; double-decker; double-fleecer; stray](../H#hermit;-double-decker;-double-fleecer;-stray))

>  <b>Apr 5, 1894</b> The bulk of the wools offered was made up largely of stragglers and other late shorn sheep, and its character therefore was not up to the usual average, and it could not therefore be expected to establish a high range of values ... (Otago Witness,13)

>  <b>Jun 3, 1904</b> The lamb was found by defendant in a paddock adjoining one of his camping paddocks, and taking it to be a straggler he had it killed under a custom which he said was long prevailed of accommodation paddock owners killing stragglers and accounting for them if called upon to do so. (Wanganui Herald,6)

>  <b>Jan 18, 1865</b> <i>ORMOND</i> A good shearing day - got through 1431 sheep - all greasy ewes with exception of stragglers from the wether block. Jan 19. David out all day clearing off stragglers. (JD Ormond Stockbook 1864-1866)

>  <b>Sep 13, 1865</b> <i>MURISON</i> Sent Wilkinson to Drysdales to head weaners whilst Read searches for stragglers. (Puketoi Station Diary)

>  <b>Mar 29, 1867</b> <i>MURISON</i> Shearing stragglers. (Puketoi Station Diary)

>  <b>Mar 1, 1879</b> CHS, TS, Kite and Jim went mustering the reserve for stragglers. (Tutira Station Diary)

>  <b>Nov 24, 1892</b> <i>BRABAZON</i> Went around big section. Saw no stragglers. (Brabazon Diaries)

>  <b>Apr 1896</b> One or two stragglers omitted in the dipping may infect the whole flock and the inspectors have lynx eyes for sheep showing vermin. (NZ Farmer)

>  <b>1919</b> An Inspector of Stock may require a stock owner to muster his flock on a given date for the purpose of returning stragglers to their owner. (Livestock in New Zealand,48)

>  <b>1952</b> <i>NEWTON</i> The ridge..runs to little over 5,000 feet and as it is all open snowgrass country it is inevitable that the two stations have an annual exchange of stragglers. (High Country Journey,156)

>  <b>1987</b> <i>HALL</i> Bob Metherell looking for stragglers in the Sly Burn, a tributary of the Greenstone River. (Shepherd's Year,  A,77)

>  <b>2000</b> <i>KERR</i> A nor'wester swayed the slack bridge and there were stragglers, perhaps 200 or 300 of them, peppered throughout the mob. 2. (High Times in the High Country,117)

>  <b>Oct 1926</b> There are several ways of dealing with the stragglers. If there is a small paddock at liberty, the ewes to lamb can be taken from the docking yard and put in it. 3. (NZ Farmer,01)

>  <b>1977</b> <i>WESTMACOTT</i> So we only had to keep the stragglers moving for a mile or so to the next crossing where they had bunched again when we came up to them. (After-Breakfast Cigar, The,157)

>  <b>1987</b> <i>HALL</i> I'm holding the front of the mob so the winter-weakened stragglers can catch up. (Shepherd's Year,  A,9)

>  <b>1987</b> <i>BARNES</i> Skilfully Fly weaves her way back and forth behind the mob, nudging the occasional straggler. (Country Calendar (TVNZ),123)

>  <b>1989</b> <i>RICHARDS</i> A sharp whistle and he will hold the lead until the stragglers catch up. (Pioneer's Life, A,85)

 <i>n.</i> (Rural) the shearing of sheep missed in an initial muster.

## straggler wool
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) long fleecewool shorn from sheep that have missed shearing.

## straggler's wool
 
 <i>n.</i>

## straggling
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a second mustering for missed stock.

>  <b>1966</b> <i>NEWTON</i> The boys also did a bit of straggling and collected quite a useful tally of woollies. (Boss's Story, The,81)

>  <b>1966</b> <i>NEWTON</i> Straggling: Mustering country a second time to get any sheep that have been missed. i.e. straggle-mustering. (Boss's Story, The,189)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>LOUGHNAN</i> scratch or scratch-mustering: as distinct from straggling or straggle-mustering, which is a full-scale operation to gather in stock previously missed, scratching - often just a one-man operation - is the task of seeking out pockets of stock known to have been missed. (Loughnan Glossary,69)

## straight hunt
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [dog trials] an uphill course that tests the skills of huntaway dogs and their owners.

>  <b>Dec 15, 1983</b> Straight Hunt - Class 4 in dog trialing and precisely what the name infers, to complete a 20 metres wide course that runs 400 metres up the hill. 52 points for hunt, 27 for style and 21 for noise. (NZ Journal of Agriculture,46)

>  <b>1998</b> <i>GORDON</i> One of those runs won the New Zealand Straight Hunt in 1983, despite the fact that, when the trio were nearing the top of the hill, they seemed to be considering a swing to their right. (Three Sheep and a Dog,140)

>  <b>2000</b> <i>KERR</i> Sheep - it is in their nature to be inconvenient - are invariably over or down or up there, and shepherds want them somewhere else. They must be hunted to that place, in dog trials off the flat and up the hill in the Straight Hunt. (High Times in the High Country,136)

## strap-toothed whale
 
 <i>n.</i> [strap-toothed whale]

>  <b>Feb 14, 1940</b> Believed from a description to be of the strap-toothed variety, a whale of about 35ft in length and over 6ft high has been washed up at Ocean Beach, Whatipu, about a mile from Huia, states the "New Zealand Herald." (Evening Post,8)

>  <b>1922</b> The strap-toothed whale (</i> Mesoplodon layardi <i> ) is, at least when adult, at once recognized by the two long strap-shaped teeth which, originating from the mandible in front of the hinder end of the symphysis, grow upwards and backwards, eventually curving round the upper jaw and preventing the mouth from being opened beyond a certain distance. (NZ Journal of Science & Technology,5/136) [NOTES: (Oliver)]



## Strathmore weed
 
 <i>n.</i> a shrubby native weed of spp Pimelea, poisonous to stock.

>  <b>1997</b> <i>CROWE</i> <i>Pimelea prostrata</i> Pinatoro; Strathmore weed... Part eaten : The berries. No other part of the plants should be eaten as Strathmore weed has been known to poison livestock. (Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,43)

>  <b>1970</b> <i>LEVY</i> Strathmore weed, a low-growing shrubby plant found on poor, friable soils, if eaten when stock are forced on it in a holding paddock, may cause staggers and death, particularly if the stock are afterwards driven. (Grasslands of NZ,305)

>  <b>Sep 6, 1910</b> A waggon broke down at Miki Miki, Wairarapa; the horses were turned out, and partook of "Strathmore weed," which the local horses will not touch. (Poverty Bay Herald,3)

>  <b>1900</b> I am forwarding you specimens of the Strathmore weed. I interviewed Mr Hewer, coach-proprietor, Strathmore and Stratford, re the matter. He informs me that the weed is very injurious to strange horses..This Strathmore weed proved to be two species of native plants, Pimelea lyalli and P prostrata. (Leaflets for Farmers,55  2)

>  <b>Sep 21, 1908</b> The first case of Strathmore weed poisoning known in the Wairarapa occurred some days ago ... (Dominion Post,5)

>  <b>Feb 24, 1966</b> Strathmore weed <i>(Pimelea prostrata)</i> this plant is fairly widespread throughout New Zealand. (NZ Farmer,29)

>  <b>1900</b> I am forwarding you specimens of the Strathmore weed. I interviewed Mr. Hewer, coach-proprietor, Strathmore and Stratford, re the matter. He informs me that the weed is very injurious to strange horses... This Strathmore weed proved to be two species of native plants, <i>Pimelea lyalli</i> and <i>P. prostrata</i>. (Leaflets for Farmers,No. 55/2)

>  <b>Jul 14, 1899</b> Mr. Gooch, Stratford cab proprietor, has had the misfortune to lose a horse, the animal having been poisoned by the "Strathmore weed," about which there was some talk a little while ago. (Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

>  <b>Sep 21, 1908</b> The first case of Strathmore weed poisoning known in the Wairarapa occurred some days ago, when out of a number of draught horses stricken two died... He noticed.. little clumps of a weed very like the garden daphne growing in the paddock where the horses had been feeding... The weed in question is native, and known by the names Mataikairanga and Strathmore. The name Strathmore was given after the name of the locality near Hawera, where the first reported case of animal sickness through eating the weed was made known some eight years ago... The first symptoms of Strathmore poisoning are loss of appetite, and then dullness. followed by tremors, staggering, distressed breathing, and convulsions, which in the severe cases are followed by death. (Dominion,5)

>  <b>1926</b> Strathmore Weed (<i>Pimelea prostrata</i>. The first outbreak.. was due to the plant <i>Pimelea prostrata</i> commonly known in the North island as "Strathmore weed". (NZ Journal of Agriculture,XXXIII/102)

>  <b>1934</b> There are several species of <i>Pimelea</i> in New Zealand... It is known in New Zealand generally as Strathmore weed, from the name of a Taranaki town where posoning of horses was first recorded. (NZ Journal of Agriculture,XLIX/152)

>  <b>Apr 1, 1920</b> .. there are many men acting as straw 'wallopers' who will put up a very decent stack and not make hard work of it. (NZ Farmer,438)

>  <b>1943</b> Farmer Jan 28. 5 The bagmen sure were busy while the straw walloper was nearly buried.

## street day

## strip
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [sp. use] to clear land of native bush.

>  <b>Jun 14, 2002</b> .. the council says the farmers have caused a runoff problem, having stripped the land of bush. The farmers say the land was stripped more than 90 years ago and they should not be blamed. (Dominion,11)

>  <b>Jan 16, 1890</b> The flax fibre, after being stripped from the leaf of the plant by means of the pipi shell or of the nail, had to be soaked in water so that the fibres might be separated. (Otago Witness,18)



 
 <i>v.</i> (in milking)

>  <b>Mar 11, 1924</b> I will go over to the cowshed tonight to strip the cows. (Otago Witness,63)

<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to milk the first and last milk from a cow by hand when machine-milking.

>  <b>1947</b> <i>DSIR</i> Strip cropping: rolling land is sometimes cropped in contour strips separated by strips of pasture. (Report,170) [NOTES: Soils & Related Agricultural Aspects of Mid-Hawke's Bay]

## strip grazing
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) break feeding, where grazing is restricted to small strips of pasture or crop by temporary fencing [normally without a back fence]

>  <b>1958</b> <i>RIDDOLLS</i> The electric fence gives control of stock with a minimum of fencing material, and is ideal for movable fencing, eg, for break or strip grazing of pasture and forage crops. (Farm Engineering,428)

>  <b>1961</b> <i>CONNELL & HADFIELD</i> Also called strip grazing, break feeding, and close folding, rationed grazing is a still more intensive method of achieving controlled grazing. (Agriculture,304)

>  <b>Nov 13, 1975</b> David is highly pleased with the strip grazing as he is using 25% less hay and the hoggets are in better order. (NZ Farmer,19)

>  <b>Jun 15, 1994</b> Mr Parks runs an all-grass system with winter ewe management a mixture of strip and block grazing. (NZ Farmer,31)

>  <b>1999</b> <i>WHITE & HODGSON</i> Strip grazing is where a temporary electric fence is used to offer a strip of pasture in a paddock each day to the herd/flock, normally without a back fence to keep animals off previously grazed pasture. Block grazing differs from strip grazing to the extent that the herd/flock is offered pasture on a daily basis with both a front and back temporaray electric fence, and daily blocks are rectangular in shape. (NZ Pasture and Crop Science,156)

## stripper
 
 <i>n.</i> a machine to extract fibre from flax [aka stripping machine, stripper mill, also attrib]

>  <b>Jun 6, 1928</b> After the removal of dead leaves and foreign matter, the plant is passed through the stripper for the removal of the green matter composing the major part of the vegetation. (NZ Free Lance,7)

>  <b>Oct 14, 1889</b> The strippers are raised on a platform some 6ft high, and the modus operandi is this: The flax is placed into stripper and pulled out from below by a boy. It is then put into the trough, where there is a continual flow of water, and then taken out and placed on the benches, then carted away to the bleaching and drying grounds. (Wanganui Herald,2)

>  <b>Jun 27, 1939</b> SUTTON DECORTICATOR - (FLAX STRIPPERS). TENDERS for the above close with the Secretary, Public Works Tenders Board, Wellington, at 4 p.m., on JULY 11 NEXT. (Evening Post,18)

>  <b>Nov 14, 1906</b> When last I wrote there were several flaxmills close to here, but the flax is all cut now, and the hum of the stripper is heard no more. (Otago Witness,79)

>  <b>May 15, 2005</b> The visitors all want Gordon Burr, who worked in the flax factory until its closure in 1973, to give them a demo on the flax stripper. (Sunday Star Times,ESCAPE p9)

>  <b>Nov 11, 1868</b> To Mr J. Anderson, a 1st prize is awarded for three screw wool presses; also, a 1st prize to the same exhibitor, for a flax stripping machine. (Star, The,3)

>  <b>May 2, 1941</b> There were 100 men working at and in connection with the stripper mill, and when the new machines were installed there would be not fewer than 150. (Evening Post,9)

>  <b>Feb 13, 1890</b> It is the stripper which makes that peculiar wild beast-like, snarling noise, which can be heard for miles. (Otago Witness,9)

>  <b>1895</b> R.M. Crosbie, Nelson, submitted a [flax] stripper with a revolving beater-bar, strong and easily cleaned and take to pieces. (Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,III/53)

>  <b>1987</b> <i>HUNT</i> In 1867 an Auckland engineer invented a machine which extracted fibre from the flax plant by beating the leaves between two metallic surfaces - a revolving metal drum (equipped with beaters) and a fixed metal bar... This machine (which became known as a 'stripper') heralded the beginning of large-scale production of flax fibre. (Foxton 1888-1988,111)

>  <b>1987</b> <i>HUNT</i> A second stripper.. was erected alongside the mill in 1889. (Foxton 1888-1988,13)

>  <b>Mar 17, 1869</b> Each stripping machine affords employment to a couple of boys; one of them feeds and the other takes the fibre away; but the company intend having the process so much altered that the flax will be delivered by means of a revolving-table. .. Each stripper will put through about one ton of green flax, producing about 4 cwt. of finished fibre per diem. (Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,4) [NOTES: Reprinted from the <i>Lyttelton Times</i> 16 February.]

## Subtropical Gyre
 
 <i>n.</i> an ocean current

>  <b>Nov 2002</b> New Zealand straddles the southern arm of the so-called Subtropical Gyre, the massive counter-clockwise flow of water around the South Pacific. From South America, water moves westward to Australia, turns south and strengthens as the East Australian Current; then off New South Wales it turns east as the Tasman Front, passing around Northland to spawn the weak West Auckland current (extending to Auckland) and the strong East Auckland Current (extending to East Cape). (Forest & Bird,306/15)

## summer sickness
 
 <i>n.</i> a form of food poisoning, a usually brief but prostrating illness characterised by vomiting and diarrhoea and associated with hot weather. [Jim writes : Not in DNZE or overseas dictionaries available to me. the British equivalent may be <i>summer flu</i>, a term I have seen in English fiction but itself not in dictionaries. <i>Summer sickness</i> has perhaps become less common with the ubiquity of refrigeration.I recall press references to it in the 50s and 60s. It is also more medically diagnosed these days - e.g. it is attributed to salmonella or campylobacter or even giardia. It has been associated with the collection of rainwater from house roofs - that can be contaminated by bird droppings.]

>  <b>Sep 13, 2008</b> .. our usually filled to overflowing Chemistry 1 lecture had only about 20 students present. On enquiring why, my New Zealand friend said in a hushed, embarrassed voice that it was "summer sickness". adding that the citizens of Auckland were laid low every year with this. I asked her what summer sickness was, and she quietly told me it was vomiting and "the runs". (Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

## sundowner
 
 <i>n.</i> formerly, a swagger who arrived at a place at sunset so that he could claim traditional food and shelter without the need to work for it.



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a dog reluctant to work in hot sunny conditions [ preferring to lie in the shade or in a water-trough. ] (See [sooner](../S#sooner))

>  <b>1953</b> <i>STRONACH</i> My dogs I tied to the iron fence outside the hotel. They were...; Maud, a bob-tailed bitch, one of the borrowed ones and already under suspicion as a 'sundowner.' (Musterer on Molesworth,2)

>  <b>1967</b> <i>MACNICOL</i> The playful pup grew to a large .. dog. He proved too easy-going and too much of a 'sundowner' for hill work. (Skippers' Canyon,129)

>  <b>1973</b> <i>SINCLAIR</i> He looked a true sundowner, and this job he was, but get him on lambs breaking at a gate at shearing time and he'd toil until his feet were raw. (Boot in the Stirrup,95)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>LOUGHNAN</i> sundowner: (i) a lazy dog. (Loughnan Glossary,81)

>  <b>1982</b> <i>MAF</i> Sundowner: Dog that leaves its work, especially when hot and noisy. A lazy dog. (MAF Agricultural Glossary,25)

>  <b>2000</b> <i>SCURR</i> Sundowner:- A dog that won't work in the sun. [sun-downer] (Rabbiters' Glossary,2)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a swagger or itinerant who arrives at a property in the evening when work is finished, hoping for a bed.

>  <b>1909</b> They are delighted to see the "sundowner" again; to see the "swagger" on the roads. (NZ Parliamentary Debates,146/102)

>  <b>Feb 22, 1871</b> Only let him occupy one of the many roadside farms to which he alludes for a few months, and be subjected to the daily and hourly pesterings to which we are subjected by hundreds of swagmen, sundowners, and other loafers - the majority of whom cannot do a day's work when they get the chance - and it strikes me very forcibly that his goodly Samaritan learnings [sic] would receive such a shock that he would experience no difficulty in understanding the reception he met with. (Bruce Herald,6)

>  <b>1894</b> <i>WILSON</i> .. they were odd members of the idle class known as the swaggers and sundowners. (In the Land of the Tui,248)

>  <b>1981</b> <i>LOUGHNAN</i> sundowner: (ii): a swagger who times his arrival just at the right time for the evening meal. (Loughnan Glossary,81)

>  <b>Feb 12, 1887</b> The moon was shining brightly as the three "sundowners" approached. (Auckland Weekly News,8)

>  <b>1883</b> <i>BRADSHAW</i> The [peripatetic labourers] in the colony are known by the name of `Swaggers' or `Sundowners' Swaggers, because they carry a swag or bundle on their backs ... Sundowners, because they never approach a habitable place before sundown lest they should be requested to take a further stroll. (New Zealand As It Is,26)

>  <b>1889</b> Old sun-downers told ... yarns of ferocious mastiffs ... It was quite certain that the most persistent swagger had never obtained the inevitable feed and shake down there. (Zealandia,1/31)

>  <b>1889</b> <i>DAVIDSON</i> Kelly [a detective] had on more than one ocasion swagged it for weary miles after his prey as an orthodox sundowner, or in taking his turn in the harvest field, or at a threshing mill. (Stories of NZ Life,2)

>  <b>1894</b> <i>WILSON</i> About these wayfarers Mr. Cameron had something to tell me, for they were odd members of the idle class known as swaggers and sundowners ... [249] So far as I could discriminate, swaggers (those who, snail-like, carry their worldly possessions on their backs) are men occasionally willing to do a day's work for a night's lodging and a couple of meals. Sundowners (those who have no possessions to carry) walk from station to station during the day, and, sleeping under a haystack until sunset, make their appearance at that hour before the `whares' or huts provided for them, and demand from the owners supper and shelter, which are generally granted. (In the Land of the Tui,248, 249) [NOTES: 1891 Dec 21 in 1894 Land of the Tui]

>  <b>1898</b> <i>MORRIS</i> a tramp who takes care to arrive at a station at sundown, so that he shall be provided with <i>tucker',/I>(q.v.) at the squatter's cost: one of those who go about the country seeking work and devoutly hoping they may not find it. (Austral English,444)

>  <b>Mar 20, 1890</b> Possibly before next harvest we shall hear a cry raised by the squatter.. that those who are about do not want work; that they are sundowners. (Otago Witness,15)

>  <b>1888</b> <i>BRADSHAW</i> fn The term `swagger' is applied to a man who tramps from place to place in quest of work, carrying all his worldly goods in a swag, or bundle, thrown across his back. The `sun-downer' is one who tramps from place to place pretending to seek employment, but, as a matter of fact living upon the supper and breakfast with which he is supplied at most up-country stations. He fears to arrive too early in the day, lest he should be requested to seek a bed elsewhere, and hence the name with which he has been endowed. (New Zealand Of Today,181)

>  <b>1873</b> <i>PYKE</i> Now, a `sundowner' or `tussocker' for the terms are synonymous - is a pastoral loafer; one who loiters about till dusk, and then makes for the nearest station or hut, to beg for shelter and food. (Wild Will Enderby,Bk III ch x 105) [NOTES: (1889)]

>  <b>1888</b> <i>D'AVIGDOR</i> Those who join it [the professional unemployed] are distinguished from `sundowners' ... by working chiefly in towns instead of in the open country, and in swarms instead of alone. It has, therefore, several advantages over `sundowning'. The professional unemployed need not tramp ten, twelve, or twenty miles a day, and he always has congenial company. (Antipodean Notes,154)

>  <b>1888</b> <i>D'AVIGDOR</i> The language of the Australian Colonies is not in the least like the last mentioned [`Daily telagraphese']. (Antipodean Notes,165) [NOTES: [check spg???]]

## supervision

[Jim Cameron writes : It subjects the offender to the oversight and control of a probation officer. <i>Supervision</i> in England is primarily a welfare order placing a child under local authority or probation officer supervision, although it may also be an adjunct to a suspended sentence. ## surfer

>  <b>Oct 1999</b> If they pulled a swifty on us then I don't think that's particularly helpful. (North & South,39)

>  <b>Feb 6, 2000</b> You would never accuse [him] of pulling a swifty on his client.. but you sometimes wonder if he's pulling the wool over your eyes. (Sunday Star Times,C7)

>  <b>1995</b> <i>McGill</i> Peat...said it was only a temporary setback, all because that bloody post joker did a sneaky job and pulled a swifty with the meeting. (Gold in the Creek,54)

>  <b>Apr 22, 2000</b> So would TV3, for instance, ever pull a swiftie and buy in cheap Aussie shows to meet the quota demands it might face in the future? (Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)



## swill
 
 <i>n.</i> beer dregs or slops

>  <b>1946</b> The word "dregs" refers to the drippings from the taps in a bar and to the overflow from the glasses as they are filled. These dregs are sometimes called "swill".. or "slops". When they are mixed with beer for sale the resultant liquid is colloquially known as "Wompo". The term has been in use among barmen for as long as one experienced licensee could recollect - from twenty to thirty years.., and it is known to the man in the street. <i>Ibid.</i> 115 The resultant "Wompo" was then served to the public. (AJHR,H-38/113)



## swim dip
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a long, deep sheep dip where sheep are driven in single file through the dipping fluid.

>  <b>1958</b> <i>STEVENS</i> A modification of the straight swim is the U-bath, which is in effect a straight swim dip turned back on itself with the two baths separated by a narrow concrete wall ... (Sheep.  Part 1, Sheep husbandry,86)

>  <b>1969</b> <i>NEWTON</i> There is the big tenstand woolshed, the station's elaborate power plant and most interesting of all the old wooden swim dip. (Big Country of the North Island,154)

>  <b>1973</b> <i>SINCLAIR</i> After the beautiful big long swim dip at Te Horoa, Ohinewairua had a dreadful little pot dip which was a horror among horrors. (Boot in the Stirrup,17)

>  <b>1994</b> <i>SALISBURY</i> On some swim dips I have used one could put through over a thousand sheep an hour ... (I Was So Lucky,165)

>  <b>Oct 20, 2001</b> The Working Dog. Do NOT put the dogs in the sheep swim dip or shower or use any sheep pouron. This could kill the dog. (Lifestyleblock.co.nz)



## swim-through
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sheep dip that consists of a long race filled with dipping fluid along which sheep must swim.

>  <b>1976</b> <i>WATERS</i> Dipping time was hard work in the old swim-through type of dip, especially if the sheep had 'ergot.' (Mostly a Farmer,11)

>  <b>1994</b> <i>DREAVER</i> Another well-remembered activity was a swim in the Catlins River after a long day's dipping in the long swim-through dip. (Catlins River Wisp Run,57)



## swine cress
 
 <i>n.</i> = NARROW-LEAVED CRESS (ruderale)

>  <b>1926</b> <i>HILGENDORF</i> NARROW-LEAVED CRESS (<i>Lepidium ruderale</i>) is also called swine cress, wart cress, way-side cress, wild cress, pepper cress, pepper weed, and scurvy grass. It is common on waste lands, especially near the sea. (Weeds of New Zealand,95,nf 1967 ed.)

>  <b>1969</b> <i>swine cress [=] twin cress: wart cress</i> [s] (Standard Common Names for Weeds,76)



## swing
 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) [ mustering] to move sheep across and down hillsides.

## swing bridge
 
 <i>n.</i> a bridge suspended on cables or ropes [OED : a form of drawbridge which turns horizontally on a pivot (either at one end or in the centre)]

## swing gate
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a double-hinged gate used in a drafting race, to swing in two directions.

>  <b>Jul 24, 1869</b> As the race has to be wide enough in all cases to admit of the passage of a large full-fleeced sheep, it often happens, in yards constructed on the old plan, that two small sheep get jammed and block up the way; but this becomes an impossibility upon Mr Sutherland's plan, as the sheep next the rollers easily draws a-head of the one next the rails, and therefore comes to the swing gate first. (Otago Witness,14)

>  <b>1878</b> <i>ELWELL</i> This was something like a 'race' for drafting sheep, with a swing gate. (Boy Colonists,214)

>  <b>Oct 1885</b> The swing gate was the most valuable invention ever applied to the rapid and correct working of sheep. (NZ Farmer,293)

>  <b>Dec 18, 1906</b> <i>MOWAT</i> Made a swing-gate for sheepyards. (Alexander Mowat Diaries)

>  <b>1922</b> <i>PERRY</i> The draining pen will be divided in two having a swing gate at the gangway end. (Sheep Farming in NZ,23)

>  <b>1990</b> <i>MARTIN</i> At the same time that fencing was becoming widespread, the swing gate was introduced for drafting. (Forgotten Worker, The,56)
